PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Tickner)—by leave—agreed to:
That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent notice No. 6, private members business, being called on forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the declaration by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs of 10 July 1994, as contained in Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No. S270, and made under subsection 10(1) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984, relating to Hindmarsh Island, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: As the local member for this area of Hindmarsh Island, which is situated at the lower reaches of the Murray River—one part of it faces the Murray mouth—I say at the outset that there is great consternation in the area about the enormous delay, the great number of reports and the fracas that has taken place regarding the building of this bridge. I was not in favour of government money going into this bridge. It seemed to me that such money could be better spent elsewhere. I have known the area all my life and I have never seen in that area more consternation about one particular development.

PARA.TAB: If I could take honourable members quickly through the history of this matter, in 1977 Binalong Pty Ltd, a company owned by the Chapman family, purchased land on Hindmarsh Island. In 1983 work began on a marina basin off the island. In 1989 cabinet approval in South Australia was given to the bridge and proposals of Binalong subject to a satisfactory EIS. In 1990 cabinet approved the development, confirmed by the Governor-in-Council, for the marina extensions, including the bridge and at that stage the government said it would assist with the funding of the bridge to a maximum of $3 million. In 1990 the Aboriginal heritage branch of the Department of Environment and Planning authorised the establishment of the marina `as no Aboriginal sites will be affected by the development'.

In 1991 as a result of financial difficulties with Binalong, the state government agreed to fund and construct the bridge. In 1993 expressions of concern from the Lower Murray Aboriginal Heritage Committee about the bridge proposal appeared and in December 1993 there was a change in the state government. Work on the bridge was suspended while Mr Justice Jacobs prepared a report he was asked to prepare by Minister Diana Laidlaw.

In December 1993, a delegation from the Lower Murray Aboriginal Heritage Committee met with Minister Tickner to discuss Aboriginal sites and burial grounds on Hindmarsh Island. There was no mention of the women's issues which were later to become seminal in this decision of the minister. In February 1994, Mr Jacobs's report was presented to the government, confirming its liability to build the bridge. In April 1994, work on the bridge was suspended again following a letter from the Aboriginal legal rights movement about further sites. On 12 May 1994, the minister announced a section 9 declaration which prevented the building of the bridge for 30 days, and on 10 June a further declaration under section 9 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act extended that delay for another 30 days.

On 20 June, the first reference of the women's issues I referred to a moment ago was received as a result of a meeting of 35 Ngarrindjeri women at the Graham's Castle and Conference Centre in Victor Harbour. On 7 July the minister prepared, as we understand it, a draft order and received Professor Saunders's report and the Fergie report. The Fergie report was a report by Dr Deane Fergie, who was employed as an anthropologist by the Aboriginal legal rights movement to assist in this inquiry. On 10 July, the minister announced his declaration of a 25-year ban. I think the order was made on 9 July.

After all of this time, after a number of reports, after an enormous number of dollars being spent, after having had two female ministers in the responsible positions in South Australia, after having the contracts signed by the state government and work allocated, and after having had a report by Mr Justice Jacobs saying that this work to build the Hindmarsh Island bridge should go ahead and that the South Australian government had no option, all of a sudden some new material—known as women's business, women's knowledge or women's issues—appeared. At no point in the past had that material arisen. Current legal and political options had been exhausted and, after millions of dollars of expenditure and a decision by the South Australian government—contrary to its views on the matter—the decision to build the bridge was made.

Then in June there was a threat by Mr Matt Rigney of ATSIC in Adelaide to withdraw a billion dollars in funds from its bankers, Westpac. It is interesting to note, although it may have no relevance, that Doreen Kartinyeri's mother—Doreen Kartinyeri is the one who brought forward this women's business—was a Rigney. On 23 December 1993, the Aboriginal legal rights movement wrote to the minister on behalf of the Lower Murray Aboriginal Heritage Committee claiming that the work will damage Aboriginal sites. Of course, we know what happened from then.

The essence of what I wish to raise today is probably contained in a speech made by the Hon. Justice Michael Kirby in 1980, when he was commenting on some work done by Professor Strehlow, the late world-renowned anthropologist who specialised in Aboriginal affairs. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Original indigenous traditions are irretrievably on the way out.
Whether we agree with that or not is another matter. He continued:
Few if any experts and spokesmen have a deep knowledge of Aboriginal customary laws anywhere.
However, the point he makes is this:
It is simply not feasible to present to parliament for blind adoption unstated secret rules, the very existence of which could not be recounted to the parliament.
That is really the essence of the first point I wish to make today. When the minister issued his declaration on 10 July, he said:

All the evidence available to me, including all written representations and the report and attached representations which I have received from Professor Cheryl Saunders under section 10(4) of the act, lead me to conclude that the area is of particular significance to the Ngarrindjeri people within the meaning of the act and is under threat of injury or desecration.

In particular, he made reference to the fact that the area was under particular threat to the cultural significance of those people within the knowledge of the Ngarrindjeri people, which he said concerns the life force itself.

PARA.TAB: I simply repeat that, until 12 May, when Doreen Kartinyeri—she has at times worked for the Adelaide museum and is a friend of Dr Deane Fergie, a female anthropologist, who was, as I said before, employed by the Aboriginal legal rights movement—wrote to the minister and said that this knowledge of hers was recent information, nobody that I know and can discern knew of this women's business. So we have a circumstance where, out of the blue and out of the past, if you like, came some information of which nobody could possibly have pre-knowledge. Doreen Kartinyeri said to the minister, `I have always known about the stories associated with the Ramindjeri, a clan nearby, and the Ngarrindjeri women's business, but until recently I did not know the exact place they referred to.' So that letter and information came forward to the minister, and presumably Cheryl Saunders, no earlier than early May this year.

Doreen Kartinyeri refers to an exact place. But, as the minister will know, when Professor Saunders made her recommendations to the minister, she did not talk about an exact place. She talked about an area of significance which encompasses such areas as the Murray mouth in general, Hindmarsh Island and the Mundoo islands, and the surrounding and separating waters in particular, as crucial for the reproduction of the Ngarrindjeri people and their continued existence. That area is hundreds of square kilometres.

All of a sudden we have Doreen Kartinyeri saying that she only became aware of the exact place in recent times. However, the exact place in Professor Cheryl Saunders's mind is an area which is variously described in her report. But, in any case, it is a minimum area of hundreds of square kilometres. That seems to me to be a problem. Those on the outside, such as we who are here today as the judge and jury, have no definitive, exact place to look at.

In other words, the place described by Doreen Kartinyeri, who is the principal supplier of the information about women's business, is an exact place; yet in the hands of the reporter, Cheryl Saunders, it is not an exact place. In fact, it is a place which comprises many hundreds of square kilometres.

Firstly, that is a problem which is nearly beyond understanding and which is quite unclear in the recommendations to the minister. The minister made a recommendation to ban the bridge site itself. That may have been the requirement that he had to finally come to under the act. But how anybody else can understand for the future what area will or may come under some future declaration when the information comes out of the Saunders report is very unclear.

The second point I would like to make is that nobody, with the exception of Doreen Kartinyeri, seemed to know of the secret knowledge. I doubt whether the significant camp sites which have been talked about before were important enough. How do I know that? Because on 13 April ATSIC advised the South Australian Aboriginal legal rights movement that, if it had some evidence of cultural matters, it would strengthen the minister's hands. In other words, it said: up to this point, we're not doing very well, so you'd better do better than that.

Within a few days, Doreen Kartinyeri emerges with new information of significance to Aboriginal women on Hindmarsh Island. For the outsider—we are the outsiders, but we are also the judge and jury today—that is a very inconclusive situation.
Finally, on the subject of secret knowledge and the significance of the area as a whole, I simply say that Professor Saunders was categorically wrong when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: The final aspect of significance of the area, identified also by Mr S. J. Jacobs in his report to the current government as potentially the most serious, involves the secret knowledge of women.

I read paragraph 25 of the report to Mr Justice Jacobs last Friday. His reply to me was that that was outrageous. He said it was outrageous because he had never heard of any women's business when he wrote his report. How could he when you think about it? The fact is that even Doreen Kartinyeri did not know about the significance of women's business when Mr Jacobs wrote the report. The minister did not have much time to read Cheryl Saunders's report. It came to him on the 7th, he made a declaration on the 9th and he announced it on the 10th. But there already is an absolute inaccuracy in that report.

PARA.TAB: I will get to the second matter. Why would the minister not allow Minister Laidlaw of the South Australian government to read the sealed envelopes? After all his adviser, Suzanne Kee, has apparently read them. She advised the minister that the confidential appendices contained nothing that might make him change his mind. Dr Deane Fergie obviously knew what was in those appendices, as she had put them together. Ann Mullins, helping Professor Saunders, knew what was in them. Suzanne Kee, working in the minister's office, knew what was in them.
But the South Australian minister does not know what is in them. When she wrote and asked the minister if she could know what was in them, he refused.

The minister has not confirmed anywhere to my knowledge that he has either seen or not seen the contents of those two attachments to the Fergie report, which are not to be seen by men. So that we know that the decision was made sight unseen and so that we know that the minister did not read all the evidence, I would like him to confirm that he has not seen either of those two reports or been told about the contents. After all of these reports and this publicity, it transpires that on 12 May Doreen Kartinyeri, who works for the Adelaide museum, comes up with the answer, after the minister was advised by ATSIC and other Aboriginal organisations that something had to be done.

Let me raise the last matter, which I think the minister needs to reply to. On 8 July he wrote to ATSIC asking to be compensated if he made this declaration and if it were to cost the minister or his department any money. How do I know that? Because in an open court judicial review hearing in Adelaide on this matter, Lois O'Donoghue wrote back to the minister and said that she was examining the matter of whether or not ATSIC could compensate him. In a letter dated 8 July this year, in reply to a letter that the minister wrote on 8 July, Lois O'Donoghue stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, you sought my assurance that ATSIC would be prepared to play a part in meeting costs if and when this occurred. I can assure you that this important financial question will be put to the board—
that is of ATSIC—
at its next meeting in August.

I put it to the minister that the only way he would have to compensate somebody in this matter would be if he had acquired land. He has already written to the Chapman solicitors saying that he did not have any idea that this was an acquisition of land. He had dismissed that idea, and I think one would have to agree with him.

PARA.TAB: The only other way that he could be compensated by ATSIC would be if he were contemplating doing something unlawful. There is no way that ATSIC could possibly compensate him. Apart from anything else—and it would be a good idea for him to get some information on this—he was asking ATSIC to do something unlawful. He was asking ATSIC to do things that were in no way in its charter within the ATSIC Act. I put it to the minister that all of this coercion and all of this organisation have gone too far, and he needs to explain that to this House. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the first point to make in this debate is that this motion, which is so very important to public policy debate in this country concerning matters of Aboriginal heritage, has not been moved by the shadow minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), but by the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan).
—I am the local member.

—I listened to the honourable member in silence. I suggest he do likewise. The fact of the matter is that in the moving of this motion we are seeing who really calls the shots in determining Aboriginal affairs policy within the coalition.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Every word spoken on this extremely serious and sensitive issue by the member for Barker, the local member, related to the issue. This minister does not know how to do that. Get on to the issue instead of playing stupid politics. It is very serious.
—There is no point of order.
—I am outraged.
—Just relax and take a couple of deep breaths. I know you may well be.
—The honourable member for Capricornia laughs.

—Order! I am giving the member for O'Connor the benefit of taking a few deep breaths. Keep doing it. The minister is responding to this motion. The chair has no role to play other than to suggest that the minister, as he rightly said when he commenced his response, should be given the opportunity to be heard in silence, as was the member for Barker. I give the minister the call with that proviso.
—The fact that the member for O'Connor rose and interjected shows yet again who calls the shots in relation to Aboriginal affairs policy within the coalition.
—If you want to be heard in silence, address the issues.
—You might not like this—

—Order! For the benefit of the member for O'Connor and others in this place, I point out that a disallowance motion has been moved. The relevance of the content of the speeches of the members who speak in this debate is a matter for me to determine. Generally speaking, the minister is in order in what he is saying. If the member for O'Connor wants to hear the rest of the speech and wants a chance to respond, I suggest he sit there in silence.

—In trying to get through the first sentence in this debate, to face incessant interjections from the opposition after I made not one interjection during the entire contribution I must say is a bit galling. I first approached this matter on the basis that this issue—it is on the public record—is currently being challenged in the courts. Therefore, some matters that I might otherwise say in the course of this debate I will, out of respect for that judicial process, refrain from saying. Nevertheless, there are other very important matters that I would seek to put on the public record in the course of this debate.

PARA.TAB: The first point I emphasise is what the law requires of me as the federal Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. The legal provisions are contained in section 10 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984. It sets out very precisely my obligations—not my options—as the federal minister under the law. One of the obligations I clearly have, when faced with an application for heritage protection of this nature, is to commission a report under section 4 of the act.

In commissioning that report, I sought to choose a person of such eminence and standing that that person would be beyond reproach. I would hope that in the course of this debate no-one would be making reflections on the integrity of Professor Cheryl Saunders AO, who is the head of the Centre for Comparative Constitutional Studies at the University of Melbourne and someone who is respected by both sides of politics in this House. What I did, following the receipt of that report and all the other advice and representations that were made to me, was issue a declaration to protect Aboriginal heritage. A number of aspects of Professor Saunders's report are quite unambiguous in what they told me. In her first conclusion she said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is . . . open to the Minister—
that is me—
to conclude that the area has particular significance for Aboriginal people within the meaning of the Act.
It would also be open to the minister to recognise that the area is under threat of injury or desecration from the construction of the proposed bridge.

PARA.TAB: She went on to highlight a number of other matters that I ought to consider when determining whether or not to make the declaration. The issues in Professor Saunders's report, and in the representations made to me, weighed very heavily on my conscience. I am deeply conscious of the responsibilities I have as the federal minister to protect Aboriginal heritage, but I also have to consider other interests that may be affected in relation to a possible declaration in this matter.
Mr Filing interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister might just wait for a moment. I am conscious of the fact that I should not interrupt him, but I have said in this place already today that I will not tolerate interjections. I remind the member for Moore of the provisions of standing order 55. I also remind the member for Moore that the provisions of standing order 304A apply to the whole proceedings of the House, not just question time. If he wants to stay here to contribute—I see he is on the speakers list—he will sit there and listen.
—The report of Professor Saunders, which is a publicly available document, on page 28 said:

SPEECH.PARA: In essence, the Ngarrindjeri women regard the Murray Mouth area in general and Hindmarsh and Mundoo Islands and the surrounding and separating waters in particular as crucial for the reproduction of the Ngarrindjeri people and their continued existence.

In other words, here is an existing continuing spiritual belief of indigenous people that they regard as of immense importance. That was, I have to tell honourable members, something that weighed very heavily on my mind when determining what course of action I should adopt. I was also conscious of the fact that on page 32 of the report Professor Saunders said:
The omission of women from consultative processes—
that is under the South Australian act—
is a problem to be rectified as a matter of urgency and this has been acknowledged by the Chief Executive Officer of the Department of State Aboriginal Affairs.
If honourable members read the report, they will find that the failure of the state process is something that the state government's own representative acknowledged to Professor Saunders.

PARA.TAB: A great many things have been said in the course of the debate in relation to the Hindmarsh bridge issue. A number of the journalists, public commentators and, I regret to say, politicians who have been involved in this debate—not all, but a great many—have disparaged the spiritual beliefs of Aboriginal people in a way that they would never do in respect of non-Aboriginal beliefs, whether they be Christian, Jewish, Islamic or some other religious belief. The attitudes that have been expressed by many people are unquestionably based on a dismissive view of Aboriginal spiritual beliefs. They are attitudes which are implicitly based on racial superiority. And might I say that they are completely out of step with the respect shown to the spiritual beliefs of Aboriginal people by virtually all the Christian churches in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said?
—I will refer to those matters in the course of the debate, if the member opposite will just allow me to continue.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I submit that the comments that have just been made by the minister may grossly reflect on members who may have contributed or plan to contribute to the debate. I think the minister is in dangerous waters in relation to standing orders.
—No—

—To conclude my point of order, I submit that, if the minister is going to continue with the line that people who are taking part in the debate on this matter in some way have a racial superiority in their line of debate, he ought to withdraw that remark before it becomes a matter of concern and debate.

—There is no point of order, the reason being that the minister has not referred specifically to anybody in this chamber. I was listening to the minister very carefully because I am aware of the sensitivities of this matter to members that are speaking in this debate. You can rest assured that, if any such sensitivities were breached, under the standing orders of this place appropriate action would be taken. The minister is entirely in order.

—What we have seen is yet another interjection without foundation by the Liberal Party in an attempt to try to stop the record being set straight. It is in complete contradiction to the respect that I showed the rights of other members in the course of this debate. The fact of the matter is that, on every single occasion an issue arises where there is a need to balance the rights of Aboriginal people and the question of development, the view of the Liberal Party in this country is to send in the bulldozers. That is why we see members of the Liberal Party so very sensitive in relation to this matter.

PARA.TAB: I said that, on the issue of respect for Aboriginal beliefs, I welcome the support shown by the Australian Christian churches, in addition to the views expressed by believers of many other faiths that are practised in this country. However, I regret to say that in the aftermath of my decision on Hindmarsh Island bridge there was some woeful distortion of the impact of my decision and the basis on which that decision was made.

Let me first of all give honourable members a categorical assurance that my decision was in no way based on the envelopes that were not available for inspection by me as a non-Aboriginal male person. The Adelaide Advertiser, which from day one has repeatedly trotted out this hoary old lie, is to be condemned for the way that it misrepresents the facts of the matter. I said from day one that I did not rely on those envelopes.

I note that the Premier of South Australia went on to ludicrously assert that, somehow or other, my decision affected hundreds of kilometres of the River Murray and was to threaten the water supplies of South Australia. Again, that assertion is utterly without foundation. It is part of the political campaign by the government of South Australia to misrepresent my decision. The assertions about the wide impact of my declaration are without foundation. The declaration is limited specifically and deliberately to the site of the bridge.

It is also important to look at the past stand of some of my opponents in relation to this particular issue. The first person that I would refer to is indeed the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) himself, who was reported in the South Australian country magazine as stating that, despite strong business support for the bridge in Goolwa, the bridge was `a bridge to nowhere'. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I'm sure it will be convenient to have the bridge, but at what price?
The Premier of South Australia, as recently as 9 October 1993, said that, if the Liberals won government in South Australia, `all contracts regarding the bridge would be examined'. He went on to say:
Surely developers don't expect the state government to act as the main risk-taker for private developers. That's the State Bank revisited.

That was said by the Premier of South Australia. Indeed, the member for Barker has admitted in the course of this debate his own longstanding opposition to the bridge. He made, again, further comments as recently as 12 October when he said:
I've said all the time and all along that in my view the building of the bridge to Hindmarsh Island was a waste of money.

He made that comment on radio station 5AN. I think we have to ask ourselves: where is the respect of the coalition—where is the respect of the member for Barker and the Premier of South Australia—for the sanctity of the processes, for the sanctity of the contracts in relation to this particular issue? You were on the record as a coalition, as was the Premier of South Australia, saying that if you could come to government and overturn the processes, if you could stop the bridge, if you could get out of the contracts, then you would—but you could not.

PARA.TAB: What I have done is cause great outrage on the part of the coalition. I will tell you why I am being attacked, and now we will get to the very essence of this debate: I did what you said you were going to do but did not do. The difference is that I have done it to protect the rights of Aboriginal people. That is what you cannot cop—that I have stood up for the human rights of Aboriginal people. The second reason why you are so outraged about my stand—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! The minister will address his remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I will address my remarks through the chair. (Extension of time granted) The reason the coalition members in this debate are so outraged is that not only have I stood up to protect the rights of Aboriginal people in the course of my actions as minister, in a proper way, observing all proper processes—which is so galling to the coalition—but also I have done something else: I have used something that the coalition finds totally unpalatable; that is, I have used a national power, a federal responsibility, the rights of the Commonwealth given to this parliament by the 1967 referendum.

PARA.TAB: Of course, it galls the coalition that somehow or other we should assert the power of the national government to protect the human rights of Aboriginal people. On every occasion when there is a choice that really counts about issues of human rights or environmental protection versus the question of states rights, we always know which way the coalition will fall.

The 1967 referendum gave to this parliament not only a power but also, I believe, a moral responsibility to protect the rights of Aboriginal people. That is, indeed, the power that I have exercised—wisely, prudently, cautiously and in accordance with proper processes—to grant the declaration. I end my contribution to this debate on a much more optimistic note. I have always believed—
Mr Tuckey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for O'Connor has been spoken to already. On the next occasion, I will resort to standing order 304.

—I end this debate on a more positive note. It has always been my view that if issues of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs generally, including the issue of heritage protection, can be elevated to a position of cross-party and inter-governmental support then that is the direction in which I think we should proceed. Indeed, in the One Nation statement, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) foreshadowed, at my request, an attempt on the part of the Commonwealth to try to get a cooperative arrangement between Commonwealth, state and territory governments with respect to Aboriginal heritage protection. I am pleased to report to the House that last week, at a meeting of Aboriginal affairs ministers in Sydney, there was unanimous adoption, at my suggestion, of a framework for review of both Commonwealth and state-territory heritage protection laws as a national priority to better protect Aboriginal sites.

PARA.TAB: The meeting took as its basic framework for that review a report of the reconciliation council called Exploring for common ground. The review will focus on clarity, consistency and efficiency in approval and appeal processes. It will examine joint agreed approval processes to minimise delay, the risk of Commonwealth intervention and a number of other key elements of that review. I stress to the House that the review will attempt to minimise delays and the risk of Commonwealth intervention. What the Commonwealth will not do is abdicate the power given to this parliament by the 1967 referendum. While I am the minister, that power will be exercised sparingly and in accordance with proper processes. But, as in this case, if necessary it will be used to protect the human rights and spiritual beliefs of the indigenous people of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of this disallowance motion. I am quite distressed by the way in which the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) goes about this type of debate. He does not come into this place seeking a bipartisan approach to issues. He does not come with that attitude at all. The emotional response which we saw today shows that fact.

PARA.TAB: I agree with the minister when he says that this is about due processes and following through on these types of issues. This motion is about due process. The information on which the minister has made his decision is a very important point for debate. It may not be the first, but it is certainly a very crucial and maybe fulcrum point in this debate. I believe we have an evidential exocet in the type of knowledge we accept into this parliament. I will go into that in detail in a few minutes.

First of all, I want to take up what the minister said in response to the shadow minister for environment and heritage, the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan). The minister was asked whether he saw the material or whether he was told about the contents of the material. The minister avoided those two questions. He said, `I did not rely on the secret envelopes.' He did not say that he did not see them, and he did not say that he was not told about the contents. He avoided answering that question. We would like to know whether the minister saw the material or whether he was told about the contents of the material. I ask the minister, as part of the due process, to come clean and directly answer with that information.

This motion is about openness by government. There has been a lack of openness by the minister on the processes in this federal parliament. I support the minister in his addressing of the law, as he is a minister responsible for particular acts in this parliament. Every minister has to consider those areas. In particular, he has to consider heritage protection in Aboriginal affairs. That is a responsibility which every minister responsible for that portfolio has to take on. I want to look at the information provided to the minister on which he made that decision. I refer to three particular quotes from a document by Professor Saunders. The first one states:

SPEECH.PARA: Protection of the area is sought by the applicants on another ground . . .
That is apart from the significance of permanent camps and a number of burial sites. Going on to the second key point of her argument:
Protection of the area is sought by the applicants on another ground as well, of great potential significance.
At this time, the professor could not actually say that these things were significant. They were only potentially significant. Professor Saunders continues:

Representations to me, authorised by a large representative group of Ngarrindjeri women, speak of the spiritual and cultural significance of Hindmarsh and Mundoo Islands, the waters of the Goolwa channel, Lake Alexandrina and the Murray Mouth within the sacred traditions of Ngarrindjeri women, crucial for the reproduction of the Ngarrindjeri people. One of the custodians of this knowledge described the area to me as "the most important place for the Aboriginal people of the Lower South". Viewed from this perspective, the bridge presents a threat to the area in the form of a permanent prominent and physical link above the water between two parts of the territory which would, in accordance with Ngarrindjeri tradition, render the cosmos, and human beings within it, "sterile" and unable to reproduce. The Ngarrindjeri women believe that construction of the bridge would not only injure and desecrate their traditions but destroy their culture.

This raises the issue of what the minister has referred to as Aboriginal spirituality and other terms like tradition and culture—and I want to add the concept of superstition because all cultures have superstition. I ask: did the minister critically examine this report and analyse it?

PARA.TAB: I can see the minister smiling and thinking, `We can go on the attack here and label people in the opposition with all sorts of terms.' Many in the coalition have a very high respect for Aboriginal culture and traditions, and I do for many cultures. I think much of Aboriginal music and painting, and many other aspects of their culture can and will become part of an Australian identity as time goes on.

But in all cultures there are also superstitions, and we in our own society also critically examine people—as does this report and the next one I will refer to—our visions and dreams to see whether there is another way of measuring knowledge. In this report we are saying to the parliament that experiential knowledge does not have to be weighed up against empirical knowledge or knowledge derived through the senses. What you are saying is that revealed knowledge to one individual person can be the basis on which this federal parliament should make decisions.

I refer in particular to Sarah Milera, who talks about having had this experiential vision. It is used as evidence as to why this area should be prevented from having a bridge built for, say, 25 years. The minister is using experiential knowledge from one person as a basis for this parliament to make a decision which we would say is for the common good of all people in this country. If we are going to use experiential knowledge of individual people from different religious and cultural backgrounds, are we going to do it for all religious and all cultural backgrounds? If somebody from the Buddhist community in Australia came to the government and said, `I have experiential knowledge from a dream which I had,' and asked the government to do certain things, would you give the same status to that cultural belief as you are giving to Aboriginal culture? All I am asking is that we put all this cultural understanding on the same level and use the same processes for everybody.

I ask the minister and the following speakers: does the government accept experiential knowledge from all cultures represented in Australia? Does it accept that as the basis of knowledge on which the federal parliament should act? The minister has used that view as part of the basis for making his decision.

Is the government going to allow all Australians to use knowledge which comes from visionary dreams? I am not denying that people have them; I think people do. But if we are going to accept this as truth and as knowledge on which the federal government should act in regard to the implementation of the laws of this country for the Aboriginal culture then let us make sure all Australians—the Muslims, the Christians and the Jews that the minister referred to—know they can also use the same form of knowledge.

Does the government believe that building the bridge renders the cosmos and the human beings sterile? Is that what the government believes? That is what the government, by this motion, says it believes. The government is saying it is accepting this information as knowledge on which a government should operate and base its decisions—the cabinet of the Commonwealth of Australia. The information given in this report by Professor Saunders is that the Ngarrindjeri women believe the building of this bridge would render the cosmos and the human beings sterile, unable to reproduce.

We now have a situation of the federal cabinet in this country being able to take evidence as truth and knowledge without any critical analysis. I think we should always have critical analysis of whatever comes into this parliament. We see here the government having what I refer to again as evidential exocets now put in place for any people who want to claim, particularly within certain cultures, that they have had a very clear vision of the importance of some aspect of our society or of this land of ours. It can come into tradition and culture tomorrow, even though it has never been heard of.

An exocet can be manufactured at any time. This government is showing that it is willing to accept information which comes from, as one person puts it, a dream or a vision. I think we can be tolerant of and respect individual people, but when it comes to public administration of a country we have to weigh up the experience of those individuals or of that individual with the overall common good and the other knowledge which we have in our community and our society.

I do not believe the government has acted with propriety in this at all. I do not believe the minister has exercised in any critical way due consideration of the information which was presented to him. There is always a balance and there is always a judgment to be made but, as a federal parliament, surely the government should critically analyse the information provided to it. I do not believe the knowledge and the information the government has used to make this decision is valid.

That is not to deny Aboriginal spirituality at all. If anybody suggests that, I will reject it, because it is not about that. Most people in this House will accept that view from me. The government has to be open about these processes and not just say that it was the information provided to it. The government has to examine the nature of that information. It has not done that in an open, honest and frank way to the Australian people on this issue. If it is going to do it in this way, as I say, it will develop an evidential exocet to be used in the parliament by anybody on whatever dream or vision they might have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate on the disallowance motion with about two hours worth of comments that I would like to make with only 15 minutes in which to make them. I do not know where to start in commenting on the contribution of the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles). It demonstrates to me, unfortunately, an incredible arrogance on his part. It disappoints me, because the honourable member for Braddon has always espoused, and I have a great respect for him for that espousal, very strong Christian principles. I have always believed that one of the tenets of Christianity he espoused was respect of other people and respect of other people's rights. Throughout his contribution he totally ignored that principle. He has demonstrated a supreme arrogance.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I totally object to that comment, and I ask him to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Braddon, in his contribution to this debate and challenge to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), sought to ask whether the minister had in fact involved himself in making any personal subjective judgments about the validity of the evidence that was presented and the report that was provided. The member for Braddon talked about due process and following the proper processes in making sure that this parliament and the government acted according to the proper processes in making these decisions. By suggesting that the minister should then engage in some personal analysis of the cultural beliefs of the people involved, he wants to totally throw out the due process that is actually in the act. The due process that is in the act is that an expert report should be done.

PARA.TAB: The minister is not in a position to make judgments about the validity or otherwise of certain cultural beliefs, dreamings or whatever. That is not his position. It is the responsibility of the minister to ensure that adequate advice is given and that a totally comprehensive report is provided, which is what Professor Cheryl Saunders's report is. It is not up to the minister to then decide, `I do not agree with this bit, I agree with that bit; I am not particularly sure about this dreaming line or whatever.' He has appointed a person of great integrity and credibility on this issue to engage in a detailed study of the claims. The report from Professor Cheryl Saunders strongly recommended the action the minister has taken. If you are therefore challenging the minister's decision, you are challenging the validity of this report and the credibility of the person who was engaged to do it.

You have not been honest enough to actually say that. You have skirted around the issue and made all these comments about dreaming and whether the minister has made any judgment about experiential knowledge of one person, et cetera. You are rejecting the Cheryl Saunders report and saying that it has no validity and that the minister should have in fact made personal judgments about the validity or otherwise of a group of people's cultural and spiritual beliefs. That, to me, is a demonstration of massive arrogance on your part and goes to the very essence of the opposition's position on this matter. It demonstrates to me a total ignorance of the minister's responsibility to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act.

The minister has acted completely within the terms of the act and has observed his responsibilities under the act, which the South Australian minister failed to do. The federal Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has taken this action because his state counterpart failed to carry out his responsibilities. The South Australian government—even though under its legislation it has broader powers than the federal government—failed to adequately protect this site of immense significance to the Ngarrindjeri people.

The federal minister became involved only because in the South Australian state government ministerial statement to the parliament on 3 May the South Australian Minister for Aboriginal Affairs announced the authorisation of this damage to Aboriginal sites pursuant to section 23 of the state act. It is interesting to note that Dr Armitage, the minister involved, conceded that his decision was one that left him in no doubt of the Aboriginal opposition to the construction of the bridge and that the community would be extremely disappointed.

What I find amazing in my analysis of the circumstances around this debate is the position the opposition has taken. We have on the public record comments from the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) and from the state Premier when he was Leader of the Opposition that they did not support the building of the bridge; that they did not believe it was a viable process; that they did not believe it should go ahead. They believed that it was a waste of money and that the money could have been spent somewhere else. But, as the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs said, when faced with the choice of respecting the human, cultural and spiritual rights of people or respecting the nebulous concept of states rights—that does not actually exist; it is a myth that the opposition has created—they always go towards protecting the rights of state governments.

That is what this debate is about—protecting the rights of a political structure rather than the rights of human beings. Every debate we have had in this chamber regarding Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs has come down to that analysis, and on every single occasion the opposition has failed to meet the challenge. It has constantly supported the rights of a political structure, a state government, rather than the rights of human beings, of people, in this country. That is the weakness in your case. You have demonstrated hypocrisy once more in this. You do not support the bridge; you think it is a waste of money. You do not believe that it should go ahead. But, regardless of that, you are prepared to trample on the rights of the Ngarrindjeri people because you believe the state government should have the right to build the bridge.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Moreton will address his remarks through the chair.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member for Barker had 20 minutes. For the first 15 minutes the essence of his speech was the conspiracy theory that this women's business, this women's belief, was magically produced only in the last couple of months; that it did not exist before; that when the community felt it was going to lose the debate, lose the argument, over the bridge they suddenly plucked out of the air this concept of women's business and introduced this new cultural and spiritual element into the debate. It amazes me that the member for Barker could suggest such a thing and therefore treat with total contempt the capacity of Professor Cheryl Saunders to analyse that.

PARA.TAB: The member for Barker said that Professor Cheryl Saunders has absolutely no credibility and integrity; that she has just accepted at face value this reproduced story about women's business that never existed before; that somehow the community has been able to pluck it out of the air and build up a case of thousands of years of history about this area, about women's business and about the spiritual and cultural significance of this area of land to women. He has said that they have been able to produce in a few months all of this history that did not exist before and that now Cheryl Saunders has fallen for it; that she is such a fool as a woman that she has fallen for the three-card trick the Aboriginal people in the local area have played. That was the essence of the argument of the honourable member for Barker. He said that there is no such thing as women's business; that this issue was produced by only one particular Aboriginal woman from that community at the point when the community realised it was going to lose the debate unless it came up with something new. The member for Barker alleged that the people have made up this issue; that they have created a new issue. That again demonstrates to me incredible cultural and spiritual arrogance on the part of the honourable member for Barker.

TALK.START.PARA: —And ignorance.

—It also demonstrates ignorance but, more, it is a total attack on the credibility of Professor Cheryl Saunders. You are saying that she did not have the ability to see through that process in her examination. You are also attacking—
—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the chair.

—Sorry. The honourable member for Barker is also attacking the credibility of anthropologist Dr Deane Fergie, who also has seen this evidence in great detail. Dr Fergie had separate meetings with the Ngarrindjeri women concerned and received an account of the traditions which was entirely consistent with the account provided to Professor Cheryl Saunders. All of that material is in the secret envelopes that were attached to Professor Cheryl Saunders's report.

PARA.TAB: I am amazed at the capacity of opposition members on every occasion to fail to meet the test about whether they are prepared to respect cultural and spiritual rights of Aboriginal people. Every time they get up in debates such as this, they say, `Oh, yes, we respect the cultural and spiritual rights of Aboriginal people, but on this occasion they do not really exist.' I have been in this parliament for only 4 1/2 years—the same period as the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) has been here—and I have participated in a number of debates on issues affecting Aboriginal people. On only one occasion have I heard coalition members demonstrate some understanding of what is needed for the future, and that was on the issue of Aboriginal reconciliation. They supported the formation of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and I am pleased they did. It was an honourable decision they made.

But at every step since that time coalition members have sought to destroy the principles of reconciliation with Aboriginal people. Since the passage of that bill and the formation of the council, on every single occasion that coalition members have been asked to address the issues and the principles of Aboriginal reconciliation—one of which is respect for the culture and spiritualty of Aboriginal people—they have failed. This is one more occasion on which they are doing it.

Even more amazing is that coalition members are doing it at a time when they do not even support the project that is involved. In the past they have said that mining at Coronation Hill should go ahead, that mining in Western Australia should go ahead and that uranium mining should go ahead. On this occasion, it is a project they do not even support. But even now—even when it is a project they do not support—they are still prepared to overturn the cultural and spiritual rights of people and say, `We should still allow the state government to have the bridge and to go ahead.'

It is an amazing situation they are allowing themselves to get into. They are totally defying everything about reconciliation. It demonstrates to me that, despite what I believe to be the honest and true commitment to reconciliation of the former shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), and despite the fact that the opposition's representative on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), is strongly committed to Aboriginal reconciliation, the coalition fails the test every time. This is a test about the opposition's credibility on Aboriginal reconciliation. This is what it is all about. The minister has not done anything wrong. He has acted completely consistently with the terms of the heritage act. He has followed the procedures. He has followed due process. He has done the correct job. He has done the job because the South Australian government failed to do the job. That is the most galling element for the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The South Australian Labor government.
—And subsequently the South Australian Liberal government. Both state governments have failed in their responsibilities. The federal government has acted according to its responsibilities.

PARA.TAB: As members opposite understand, this government is committed to reconciliation. This government is determined to protect the cultural and spiritual rights of Aboriginal people. Those rights have been clearly demonstrated in the report by Professor Cheryl Saunders. The minister has acted according to the act. I strongly oppose the disallowance motion and support the minister's decision in preventing this bridge from going ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —After being accused of being a racist, ignorant and not sticking to the debate or the subject, I find that all two of the government speakers thus far have resorted to very strong personal attacks on the opposition as part of their argument.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Nobody called anybody a racist in this debate.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! It is not a point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was implied by what the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) said in his address. Any honest person reading the debate afterwards could only infer that from what he had to say. I listened very carefully after making a point of order and could quite easily pick up the clear implication. But the implication was continued by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), who resorted to personal attack for about three quarters of his argument. Very seldom did he stick to the actual debating matter in hand.

PARA.TAB: I will make one observation about this matter. The honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) said that he does not particularly support the construction of the bridge. That is not the issue. As the honourable member for Moreton quite rightly pointed out at one stage, the issue is the role of the minister in this. The member for Moreton pointed out that the minister acted entirely within the law and that he was not obliged to make any personal determinations in relation to the reports or other information he received in relation to his declaration.

If the member had bothered to read the act—I am happy to provide him with a copy, or we can arrange for him to get one—he would have seen section 10, which says `where the minister receives an application and is satisfied'. In other words, there is a requirement for the minister to satisfy himself in relation to the question of a declaration.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's exactly what he did.

—But the member argued in his contribution that that was not an obligation of the minister. You made that debating point. I made clear notes. Clearly, you are either ignorant or you have skirted around the issue. Perhaps the debate has been less than honest, as you pointed out earlier in your contribution. One may ask: why is a member from Western Australia contributing to this debate? It is a good question. Let me answer it.
—Ha, ha!

—The minister laughs. Come in, spinner! Western Australia is contributing to this debate because I have a very good memory of what happened in relation to the old Swan Brewery. You made a great point in your contribution about how you were taking strong stances as minister and exercising those federal powers that were conferred on the federal government by the referendum in the 1960s. But ask yourself this question: why did you not act in the case of the old Swan Brewery? Why did you not—
—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the chair.

—I beg your pardon, Mr Deputy Speaker. Why did the minister not act in relation to the development of the old Swan Brewery site by the previous government, which was the Lawrence Labor government? Was his reticence to act in that case because the Labor Party in that state had received $692,000 worth of contributions from the developer, Mr Roberts of Multiplex? I ask the minister why he did not act under those circumstances.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I really do not believe what I am hearing from this Liberal Party member of parliament. Clearly, the member has said that I have been influenced in some way in the exercise of my responsibilities by party donations. I ask that that deeply offensive personal reflection be withdrawn.
—The honourable member asked for a response and he is in order.
—I merely asked the question because I am looking at the minister's line of behaviour in relation to that matter and this matter.
—Sit down. You are a disgrace to your party.
—You are a sanctimonious fool and you ought to sit down and keep quiet.
—Order! The honourable member for Moore will withdraw that remark.
—You are a hypocritical humbug.
—The honourable member for Moore will withdraw it immediately and without qualification.
—I withdraw the remark `hypocritical', but he is still a humbug.
—You will withdraw the total remark.

—I withdraw the total remark. I raised the question of the old Swan Brewery and asked questions because, in this particular instance involving the Hindmarsh Island bridge, the decision was made by the Labor government of South Australia in the first instance. That decision in relation to the bridge was determined—

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a very precise point of order. This is a debate about a disallowance motion in respect of a heritage declaration in South Australia. If this member of parliament wants to move a motion condemning me or dealing with other matters in the state of Western Australia—
—Order! That is not a point of order.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I press the point of order on the issue of relevance.
—I press my response: it is not a point of order. The minister will resume his seat.

—I raise the argument that this decision was given cabinet approval by the South Australian government in 1989. Where were the minister's predecessors and where was the minister subsequent to that? Certainly, those in the state Labor government were apparently nowhere to be seen. I ask a valid question about the old Swan Brewery because the debate lasted for some time and is still ensuing in some ways: where was the minister at the time of the old Swan Brewery development? It is a matter of great concern to many Aboriginals in the metropolitan area of Perth, as the minister would well know.

PARA.TAB: The question of the treatment of evidence is also a matter of concern. It required Aborigines who had a case to go and present evidence to a court in relation to the appeal that the then Lawrence Labor government made against the original determination by the Supreme Court involving a ban on the continuing development of the site. All I am doing is asking a fundamental question about the consistency between the treatment of the old Swan Brewery and the treatment of the Hindmarsh Island bridge. The minister may well become agitated and upset by that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you are appalling.

—The minister may well make that comment. I have found that the minister continually makes personal attacks on members of the opposition in debates, but when he receives some attacks in return he becomes very sensitive indeed. Of course, this is a matter of great sensitivity, but it is also a matter requiring the minister to make a very serious decision. In this case, the minister has extraordinary powers to make a declaration. In making a declaration, the minister is obliged to naturally consider reports that he receives and to satisfy himself as to the validity of those reports and the actual substance of the circumstances that would give rise to a declaration.

PARA.TAB: I want to deal with some aspects of the reports because there are some differences of opinion. The member for Moreton makes the assertion that somehow Professor Saunders's report is the absolute authority, that somehow Professor Saunders is unquestionable. That is intellectually dishonest. It is absolutely dishonest because in any case, in any report, in any opinion or in any thesis of someone doing a study of this sort there will naturally be areas where people have a difference of opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you do a better job?

—That is a ridiculous argument. The member opposite really ought to remain silent. A teacher of mine once said that when you keep silent people may think you are stupid, but when you open your mouth they know for sure. In the few moments left to me, due to continual points of order, I note that there are a number of contradictions to the Saunders report. There are some differences between what Professor Saunders has asserted in her report and some of the evidence of previous authorities on Aboriginal settlement in the area in South Australia. I refer to Catherine and Ronald Berndt and Norman Tindale, who are recognised as three of the best anthropological authorities on Aboriginal culture around the world.

PARA.TAB: Why is it that Berndt and Tindale, acknowledged as authorities on Aboriginal anthropology, do not refer in any detail to the claims by the Ngarrindjeri women? Norman Tindale died in 1993 at the age of 93. He had devoted his whole life to researching Aboriginal history in South Australia and left his findings in the form of two tonnes of diaries and research notes to the South Australian people. These are housed in the South Australian Museum and were catalogued by the head of the anthropology section, Philip Jones, in 1989. There are approximately six volumes that refer to the Goolwa area. There is no mention in any of the six volumes of the significance of that area as suggested by the Ngarrindjeri women.

The minister would have to concede that there is quite a substantial difference between the views of the women and the views of someone who was noted as a worldwide authority on Aboriginal anthropology. I am not an expert on Aboriginal anthropology and have never pretended to be. But, as someone who has had some basic training in assessing evidence, opinions and research, I would think that one would at least take note of the fact that there are differences of opinion.

The Berndts, in their book entitled The world that was, refer to the River Murray as being like a lifeline, an immense artery of a living body which included country to the east: the legs spread south-eastward along the Coorong and south-west along Encounter Bay. However, the Berndts later refer to the fact that, due to the dispersal of clan remnants, visits to the lakes area were infrequent and, according to Karloan, an elder from the Yaraldi clan, the western leg of the lakes system, a symbolic body, was the first to wither. Why is a section of water, including the Goolwa channel, any different from other stretches of water in the lower Murray?

In examining the research that was provided to the minister with this advice one has to look also at the scale of events. The member for Barker referred in his contribution to this debate to the sequence of events. I referred earlier to the fact that in 1989 cabinet approved the bridge and proposal subject to submissions. In 1990, the Aboriginal Heritage Branch of the Department of Environment and Planning authorised the establishment of the marina as no Aboriginal sites would be affected by the development.

It is of note that at that particular time there appeared to be absolutely no questioning of the advice that the state Labor government received from its Aboriginal affairs section in relation to the proposal. The $64,000 question is: why is it that this declaration has been made with such alacrity by the minister? The minister in his contribution made little or no substantial reflection on his actions other than to make what I believe were petty personal attacks on members of the opposition for having the gall to disagree with him. The substance of the debate thus far from members on the other side of the chamber is that we have the gall to disagree with them; therefore we are either fools or have less than a satisfactory grasp of the issue.

I am talking about some of the issues relating to the advice that the minister received. The minister said in his contribution that he did not rely on the sealed envelopes. I accept that and I have no reason to doubt that that is true. Bearing in mind that the sealed envelopes did have some special significance in relation to the report prepared by Professor Saunders, the minister basically said that he relied holus-bolus on Professor Saunders's report when making his decision to make a declaration.

The other question that has to be asked is: why has the minister imposed a ban for only 25 years? That is something I do not understand as yet. I think the minister ought to answer that question.Clearly, if the matter were of such importance he would have made a permanent ban. Does it mean that the mythology will have evaporated after 25 years, or does it mean that the few remaining Ngarrindjeri women will no longer be alive then to pursue the tradition? That is another question the minister ought to answer. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose this disallowance motion moved by the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan). I will leave it to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) to respond to it. I am not going to spend too much time in responding to the federal member for Moore (Mr Filing). All I want to say in general terms, before I get to the substantive issues, is that it is another sorry day in this House for the Liberal Party. Several more nails have been driven into its coffin and its electoral prospects as a result of its deplorable attempt to deal with these issues. It shows no respect for Aboriginal cultural traditions in this country.

PARA.TAB: I would like, in response to the federal member for Moore, to refer to the report on this issue by Dr Neale Draper, which was commissioned by the South Australian government. I quote from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a large Aboriginal township, incorporating residential areas, food processing areas, shell middens, traditional burial places, and the specific traditional camping places of the Ngarrindjeri and Ramindjeri families who have a very deep cultural association with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: the honourable member for Capricornia is referring to the Draper report. We have been properly denied access to the Draper report; therefore, I suggest it should not be quoted in this House.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is amazing that the members of the opposition do not want any substantive issues raised in this debate. The report goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the most important site of all . . . represents a crucial part of Ngarrindjeri cultural beliefs about the creation and constant renewal of life along the lower Murray lakes, the Murray mouth and the Coorong . . . The cultural traditions concerning this `site', and its relationship to the surrounding lakes and Coorong, are highly confidential.

This report supports Professor Saunders's report to the minister. The issue of how seriously we need to take Aboriginal culture has a fairly long and established judicial history in this country. I refer to Justice Brennan's comments on the Tasmanian dams case under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 in relation to the Kutikeena Cave issue. The phrase `particular significance' in section 8 cannot be precisely defined. This is what it says:

. . . the site must be of a significance which is neither minimal nor ephemeral, and that the significance of the site may be found by the Aboriginal people in their history, in their religion or their spiritual beliefs or in their culture. A group of whatever size who, having a common Aboriginal biological history, find the site to be of that significance are the relevant people of the Aboriginal race for whom the law is made.
I also refer to Justice Wootton's comments on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritiage Protection Act 1984 relating to the Junction Waterhole dam in Alice Springs. Justice Wootton states:

. . . the Act does not specify that any degree of antiquity must attach to the observances, customs and beliefs which may obviously change over time, although the word `tradition' in its ordinary meaning carries the notion of being handed down from generation to generation.

This motion concerns the oral tradition of the Ngarrindjeri people. It is very important to quote Dr Deane Fergie, who was referred to by the member for Barker. In her report to Professor Saunders, she says:
. . . this case demonstrates the resilience of tradition in Aboriginal society. It also demonstrates the specificity and persistence of women's tradition in Aboriginal society.
I want to further refer to Justice Wootton's comments on the Junction Waterhole Dam because I believe it is relevant to the matters in this issue:

. . . the issue should not be whether, judged by the norms and values of our secular culture or our religions, the sites are important, but whether they are important to Aboriginals in terms of the norms and values of their traditional culture and beliefs. In other words, the issue is not whether we can understand and share the Aboriginal beliefs but whether knowing they are genuinely held, we can therefore respect them.

It is that respect and that attempt to understand the spiritual significance of these issues that is at the core of the matter. One of the issues that we have to take into consideration—here I refer to the points raised by the member for Braddon (Mr Miles)—is that, in the dispossession that was suffered by Aboriginal people in this country, their spiritual beliefs have been put under immense pressure. It is fascinating that this is often forgotten. The report by Cheryl Saunders contains elements which are fairly pertinent to this issue. Page 17 of the report states:
Drawing on Taplin's observations, Jenkins describes the Ngarrindjeri at the time of European contact as "a highly cultivated people", noting their craftsmanship and "dedication to cultural pursuits".

European contact lead quickly to the spread of disease amongst Ngarrindjeri people. There is some evidence of contact by sealers and whalers as early as 1802. By the time Sturt arrived in 1830, these contacts were substantial. A smallpox epidemic ravaged the clans at about this time or even, possibly, before it. The first lease on Hindmarsh Island was taken out in the early 1840s and others followed soon after. The Ngarrindjeri people began to move away to Point McLeay (now Raukkan) where the Aboriginal Friends Association had opened a mission in 1859. Others were moved more forcibly. The Aborigines Act 1911 segregated the Aboriginal people into missions and reserves and gave the Protector unlimited powers over families. From 1923, the Protector had power to remove children from their parents and commit them to institutions. By 1913, the Ngarrindjeri effectively had been forcibly removed to Point McLeay. By the time this form of restrictive legislation was repealed, in 1962, several generations of the Ngarrindjeri people had grown up under this regime.

We should be amazed that the traditions and the spiritual meaning have been handed down from mother to daughter, as reported by Doreen Kartinyeri, about whom the member for Barker spoke. I could only perceive his comments to be in fairly disparaging terms. Who is Doreen Kartinyeri? Let me read once more from this report from Professor Cheryl Saunders, which is open and publicly available to everyone. She says that the substantive issues that are in the confidential documents, because they are women's business, do not change the information that she has been able to put in her report. Professor Saunders and Dr Fergie spent considerable time gaining the trust of Ngarrindjeri women, who came into this issue very late because they had not been consulted and did not know and because they were dispersed following the history that I have just mentioned. So the notion that they suddenly came into this matter late in the game to save the issue for the minister is an absolute nonsense; it is an absolute outrage to the women concerned. The report further states:

Doreen Kartinyeri is the key person in the Aboriginal Family History Unit of the South Australian Museum, which is nationally recognised for its work in enabling Aboriginal people to rediscover their families. She is a Ngarrindjeri elder, whose knowledge about "women's business" central to this report came from her grandmother and her Aunt Rosie, her mother's older sister. In turn, she passed on the knowledge to her daughters, in accordance with the traditions as she understood them, when they reached the appropriate age. The handing down of the knowledge within Doreen's family may have been assisted by the fact that her great-grandmother did not go into the mission, although Doreen herself did. Doreen Kartinyeri's work was recognised when she was named as the South Australian Aboriginal of the Year on 1st July 1994.

These are the people who are being referred to in what I can only conclude are fairly disparaging terms by my colleagues opposite. What we have here is a very paltry attempt, once again, to raise a spectre of states rights over human rights in this country.

PARA.TAB: We should be pleased and proud that, in the face of these considerable difficulties, the Ngarrindjeri women have been prepared to speak about very secret and ancient traditions to Professor Cheryl Saunders. This was done because they were faced with the fact that, were they not to do this, once again the rights, dignity and religious beliefs of Aboriginal people would be trodden on by people who had no respect for their ancient traditions. If reconciliation is to mean anything, it must take into account an increasing and growing understanding and respect for those traditions. We are not talking about ephemeral issues in the terms used by the member for Braddon; we are talking about an ancient religious tradition that is central to the welfare, wellbeing and future of Aboriginal people in this country.

I will further quote from the report the concern about the release of secret information to people who traditionally, in terms of their culture, have no rights. Justice Wootton refers to this and states:

SPEECH.PARA: Aborigines know that they must maintain secrecy, unless the release of that knowledge is perceived ultimately to be the only way to protect an area.
The report goes on to quote Dr Fergie, who describes the compound problem as follows:

Knowledge of the full significance of the sites and areas appears to have been confined to a small group of senior women who were all living in different and distant parts of South Australia and who for some time were unaware of the proposal to build a bridge to Hindmarsh Island. The dispersal of these few knowledgeable Ngarrindjeri was compounded by the fact that, until very recent months, it has been men rather than women who have been the central players in consultative and planning processes involving Aboriginal interests in this region. Men have dominated organisations such as the Ngarrindjeri Tendi, the Lower Murray Heritage Committee and the Ngarrindjeri Lands and Progress Association.
It took some time for the women to be brought together, and then they were not prepared to talk to people who were not able to be sensitive and concerned about women's issues.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, you will know, serving as I do on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, that there have been many situations in other areas of the country where our committee has respected that, with some issues where men's business is to be discussed, it is not appropriate not to respect that cultural tradition; I certainly have been absent from those particular meetings. On the other hand, where women's business has been at issue, my male colleagues on that committee have been prepared to respect those traditions, and that has allowed me to participate in discussions with Aboriginal women.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as I am sure you would be aware from your own personal contact with Aboriginal people, I think it is certainly true that Aboriginal people—and we should not be surprised at this, given the history of genocide and oppression in this country—are not prepared to open their hearts without first gaining some trust in the individuals with whom they are prepared to communicate sacred and important information. I commend Professor Saunders for the way in which she went about her consultations with the elders of the Ngarrindjeri women's group. I believe that it is to the credit of the minister and this government that they have been prepared to take full cognisance of, and ensure that, the issues relating to women, who have been responsible for maintaining the traditions and the commitment of a dispossessed people, have been taken fully into account.

It is to the eternal shame of the member for Barker that he has been prepared to be so dismissive and to use as his only argument these envelopes and these women. It is an outrage, it is appalling and it brings no credit to this House. I oppose, wholeheartedly, this disallowance motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In beginning my summing up, I ask the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) whether she will table the Draper report that she was referring to.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Is it a confidential document?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a confidential document at this point, and I will seek further advice.

—You should because it is so confidential that you should not have it. No doubt you will find that out later. On the subject of the veracity of Doreen Kartinyeri, I am not doubting that she believes what she says. Nobody seems to doubt that in any way at all. But, before the member leaves the chamber, I will read some words from Doreen Kartinyeri's own genealogy, which she wrote when given a grant via the Adelaide museum. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1979 Lewis O'Brien came to see me at my home and asked me if I could record Point McLeay and Point Pearce family genealogies and if I could would I be interested in doing a project to submit for the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies in Canberra. Next I could ask for a grant to record family genealogies, and he and Paul Hughes thought it should be recorded now. They both felt that the Aboriginal identity, culture, customs and language were fast dying out, and if it was not recorded now then it would be lost to our people forever. I told Lewis I didn't know much about the culture, customs and language but I said I do know the identities of the Point Pearce and Point McLeay people.
