It is no wonder that the member for Capricornia is leaving the chamber; this is a quote from the lady who is the custodian of all of this women's knowledge.

PARA.TAB: Let us make sure that we are examining this on a reasonable and rational basis. Members opposite raised a number of times the fact that members on our side of the House, including the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) and me, and Mr Dean Brown, the Premier of South Australia, had at various times said that we were not in favour of building the bridge. That is absolutely true. I have said any number of times that, in my view, it was a waste of government money. I did not mind if the Chapmans built the bridge, and when they ran out of money or were unable to do it that did not worry me one hoot. But, when the government was asked to put money into it, I felt there were better places to expend it—one of which was to build another bridge on the same river, further up at the town of Berri where the annual traffic every year is exactly double, and much more of it is commercial.

Let us put at rest the view that we are changing our view. Quite frankly, that is irrelevant compared with the enormity of this decision, which is that all of a sudden all of the previous systems can be overthrown by something that nobody can possibly comprehend. Nobody can possibly anticipate some issue that could turn up out of the air that overthrows all of the best laid plans of those people, costing them hundreds of thousands or millions of dollars after years of effort on their part.

Not only that, but when it does turn up the minister will say, `We are not going to compensate you.' However, he managed to write to ATSIC saying, `If we are out of pocket, you can compensate me.' He made an unlawful suggestion, or a suggestion that ATSIC act unlawfully by compensating him. How on earth it could do that nobody could possibly contemplate. But you apparently contemplated that. My guess is that—and this is supposition—cabinet said to the minister, `You go ahead and do this as long as you are not out of pocket.' Do not forget that, in relation to the Swan Brewery, you said, `I have to ask cabinet.' You said, `It is 8 July. I have to make this declaration tomorrow. I will write a quick letter to Lois O'Donoghue today and ask her to compensate me,' which you did.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I suggest to the honourable member for Barker that I did nothing of the kind.

—Which the minister did. She wrote back to the minister saying, `Yes, we will consider that at our next August meeting of ATSIC.' So you made a suggestion to her, as I said, which was unlawful. Not once did the minister address any of the debating points. I can only describe what he did as as he poured out this sanctimonious soup yet again by general or generic aspersions that anybody who disagrees with his point of view is virtually a racist—and the minister goes awfully close to saying that every time he gets up here at the box. You did it in the land acquisition fund debate many times. When anybody even says something remotely approaching that to this minister he jumps up and down here in a furious rage and takes points of order. You never debate the issue and you are always making generic references based on some form of sanctimony.

PARA.TAB: I raised a number of issues which I will come to in a minute, none of which were referred to by the minister. He did not refer to the fact that the information about women's business seemed to come very late and that it was not all agreed to by all of the Aborigines. But let me raise one or two others that have been alluded to. Professor Saunders, who has been much praised by the government here today, never went near the Adelaide museum. I had that told to me by Mr Chris Anderson who runs that museum. He said, `Professor Saunders never came near us.' The Adelaide museum is a repository of all sorts of anthropological and other Aboriginal information and has been known to be for a long time.

Professor Saunders failed, as has been mentioned, to take notice of any of the reference material written by Norman Tindale. As the minister knows, Norman Tindale worked with these people all over this country for many years. He retired to America. His work has been catalogued in part by Australians in Palo Alto in the USA. I think either earlier this year or late last year some large numbers of boxes of his personal and private notes were returned to the Adelaide museum, and some of the work that he did exactly countenanced this area. It was never referred to by the expert. She may be an expert, but in this particular matter that does not mean she is infallible, and that is the point I wish to make. Cheryl Saunders did not refer to Norman Tindale's Adelaide museum store of information.

Then again, Ronald and Catherine Berndt did excellent work on the area, and have written a book which is very thick. Catherine Berndt, being a woman, you might have thought in all of that time might have heard of these women's issues or women's oral tradition, as it has been otherwise referred to, somewhere along the line in that area. She did not know of it. Her husband would not have known it, but she did not even know it or know of it.

The Campbell family is one of the two families who were residents of Hindmarsh Island, which is the island we are talking about. The other family was the Pula family, the Pulami family. King Pulami was the king of the whole area. But Peter Campbell, four or five generations ago, was regarded as the man who ran Hindmarsh Island. Some members of the Campbell family disagree with the conclusions that the 35 women's group had come to.

One Dorothy Wilson went to this meeting and walked out of the meeting—this was not reported by Cheryl Saunders—and she came to the conclusion, very disappointedly and sadly, that it was fabricated. A member of the Campbell family, a male, said to me that he had checked with his mother and an elder Ngarrindjeri called Nanna Laura, and none of the older women who were not at this meeting—his mother has since died—knew of it. He said that they, some of these women, made sure that the locals could not get there. I do not know whether that is true or false.

`Everyone except our family managed to get there,' he said. `I could respect this matter if we were living in tribal tradition ways, but we are not. We've got to make sure that these things are fair dinkum. If we lie once then we have to lie and lie again,' he said to me on the phone only two days ago. Finally, he said, `Nothing what we've been told so far fits the shoe.' I agree: nothing we have been told so far fits the shoe. In regard to one of the people who was a descendant of King Pulami, Sarah Milera, he said, `Poor sister girl Sarah Milera believes it's true, but that doesn't make it true.' Again, he referred to the Berndt book and he said that this women's business is not even in the book written by the Berndts called The way it was. Some would have thought that all of this would have been in the Campbell's family history at the Adelaide museum. It will be interesting to see in fact whether it is.

I want to come back to the matters I raised with the minister in the first instance, and they were fourfold. One matter is whether or not this parliament should be asked to make a judgment when the evidence that is proffered is not all able to be seen by the parliament. Until such time as we are able to do that, then I suggest that we should reject this declaration. That is why I have moved in this way. I repeat what Justice Michael Kirby said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is simply not feasible to present to the parliament, for blind adoption, unstated secret rules, the very existence of which could not be recounted to the parliament.

That is the essence of my problem. The essence of my problem is that I am here to vote and I am not allowed to see the evidence—not that I want to see the evidence particularly if it is women's business, but neither is Minister Laidlaw and Minister Barbara Weise, because, presumably, nobody knew of its existence at that time. Yet Doreen Kartinyeri is an educated, intelligent woman. She knew this matter was going on for years in the press. She could have come forward with that information much earlier than 12 May.

PARA.TAB: Another matter is that I categorically asked the minister whether or not he had acted unlawfully. The minister absolutely refused to answer that question in regard to ATSIC. He did not even comment on the subject. I said to you that you could not suggest to ATSIC that it repay you if you made a mistake, because the only way that you could be successfully sued is if you had acted unlawfully; and there is nothing in the ATSIC Act which enables them to repay you if you acted either lawfully or unlawfully. So you will have to produce that letter, which we understand you have up until now refused to produce, no doubt in some other place. Nevertheless, on the public record in open court is Lois O'Donoghue's reply to you saying that you had demanded some compensation.

In conclusion, the minister categorically refused to answer the question as to whether he had seen or been told of the contents of the sealed attachments to Dr Fergie's report. There is a good reason perhaps why you refused to do that: you know that if you had, in Aboriginal terms, that would have been a profanity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first occasion that I have had the opportunity to speak in this parliament on family law matters. Today we are debating very sensible and well thought out amendments to the Family Law Act. I take this opportunity to put on record my view that the Family Law Act when it was introduced was, and remains, one of the best examples of far-sighted reform coming from this parliament.

PARA.TAB: Last sitting week, the House passed legislation which will stop police poking and peeping into citizens' bedrooms in Tasmania. Senator Lionel Murphy's Family Law Act did the same in 1975 with regard to private detectives peeping into bedrooms with cameras prior to the introduction of non-fault divorce. Lionel Murphy was a great Australian. The Family Law Act is only one of the lasting monuments to Lionel Murphy. Lionel Keith Murphy's legacy will remain while many of the so-called leaders of the coalition who not so long ago tried to vilify him are long forgotten.

The conclusion of the Family Law Council is that the language of family law has been drawn from criminal and property law. Unfortunately, these concepts remain in the minds of the users of family law. In my experience as a legal practitioner, try as I might, I could never convince the majority of my clients that the issue of custody of their children was separate from the issue of maintenance. Now this legislation removes the concepts of custody and access and introduces the concepts of parental responsibility, parenting plans and parenting agreements.

Apparently, these changes have been criticised by Mr Justice Joske in a submission to the joint committee dealing with family law matters. His Honour argued that confusion would arise because, under the Hague Convention on Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction, the terms `custody' and `access' are used. He argued that confusion about custody and guardianship arise in the community as a result of what terms are perceived to mean in fact rather than the result of legal labels. I would agree to some extent that there is certainly confusion in the community over the differences between the concepts of custody and guardianship, but I would say that the confusion is both in terms of law and often in terms of fact.

In particular, the concept of joint guardianship is not well understood in the community. Quite often, when matters of family law come before the courts, one party is given custody and joint guardianship goes with that. It is not something that is emphasised by courts yet, as I say, when people walk away from the Family Court or the Magistrate's Court that has given them some sort of custody, all that remains in their minds is that they have custody of the child. Unfortunately, some people see their children as being possessions; therefore, the concept of joint guardianship is alien to them. They cannot contemplate sharing their possession with an estranged spouse or partner. But because there is little or no understanding of the law—and in some cases not even an acceptance of the law—this reform is necessary. It is much better to address, as this bill does, parenting agreements which reflect the reality of society's conception rather than enforce some ill-defined joint guardianship.

The concept of guardianship itself is a little out of date. It is mainly used in state legislation relating to ex-nuptial children. Thankfully, most of this legislation has now been replaced. In my view, the word `guardianship' should be disregarded from our family law language. I looked up the word `custody' in the dictionary and found the word `keeping', which certainly implies possession. Yet, when the Family Court, or perhaps the Magistrate's Court, awards custody, it does not intend now to give something to one party to the exclusion of the other.

Confusion and resentment almost certainly follow when access is awarded to the other party. That is also not understood. Mr Justice Joske also took the view that parents are normally possessive about their children and that attitudes will not be changed by terminology. I agree with that, but I would go further and say that no law in any form will change everybody's attitude. These changes provide a framework for the carrying out of those principles that society at this point sees as most appropriate. The law can never be expected to be a substitute for compassion and commonsense in all cases.

As a legal practitioner, I remember vividly spending several hours with an estranged couple who refused to agree on what half of Christmas Day each party would have access to the children. This dispute took hours. They could not agree who would get the morning and who the afternoon. The law can never totally solve a relationship of that level—especially one involving children—where the parties cannot even come to a basic agreement like that. No lawyer, court or legal terminology could ever solve such a basic and fundamental breakdown in communication and tolerance between two parties.
Counselling can be a great help in these situations. This legislation greatly enhances the capacity of the Family Court and other courts that administer the family law to involve counselling.

In my view, the structure of parenting agreements following counselling is the best model for reflecting the principles of tolerance and understanding together with the very important principle that the best interests of the child are paramount. This language reflects the language of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. That is why the bill refers to parental responsibility. It is very significant that in this legislation there is no reference to the rights of parents, because a reference to their rights would imply some sort of property rights over the children. But the concept of parental responsibility is important in relation to the financial maintenance of children.

Proposed new section 61C(2) provides that each of the parents will continue to have parental responsibility for the child, despite any change in the nature of their relationship, including whether they become separated, married or remarried. Under proposed new section 63B, parents are encouraged to agree about matters concerning their children rather than seek an order from the court. A parenting plan may deal with a person or persons with whom the child is to live, contact between the child and other persons, the maintenance of the child and any other aspects of parental responsibility of the child.

It is very important that this legislation makes that link between maintenance of the child and other parental responsibilities, because that has always been the reality. As I said earlier, the law quite often has made that separate, and for very sensible reasons. But the reality is that they are connected in people's minds and we cannot ignore that. That is why this legislation, by adopting a parenting plan, adopts the proper balance between these responsibilities.

Who a child lives with is an important issue. Quite often, disputes are not about where a child is to live but whether a present third party is perhaps seen as a bad influence on the child. They are the sorts of things that can be determined in parenting plans. Every other aspect of the parental responsibility of a child is very important, because parents may want to make agreements about issues such as the education and religion of the child. Under this bill, the court can only set aside the parenting plan if it is obtained by fraud, duress or undue influence with the consent of the parties or, very importantly, if the court concludes that it is in the best interests of the child to not set aside the plan.

The bill also gives power to make orders where appropriate to include step-parents in the parenting plan. This does not diminish the parental responsibility of natural parents, but in relation to maintenance it does allow the court to give step-parents some financial responsibility for children who are in their care and control. This is very significant because again it reflects reality. I emphasise that it does not diminish the responsibility of the natural parent.

Obviously, since the Family Law Act was drafted and introduced in the 1970s, we have had most significant reforms in the area of child support. Although there have been very obvious administrative problems with child support, the concept that natural parents should be financially responsible for their children and that, if necessary, there should be state intervention to ensure that that is the case is very important and it will obviously be very complementary to this legislation.

I congratulate the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) and the Joint Select Committee on Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act on this bill. The Family Law Council also reported on guardianship, custody and access and made comparisons with the British legislation. What came out of that was that this legislation is leading the world in this area. We in Australia can be very proud that sometimes we pick the best out of overseas legislation. That is certainly what happened in Australia with the Family Law Act. When Lionel Murphy first drafted that act, similar provisions had just been enacted in the United

SPEECH.PARA: Kingdom. We came out with better legislation, and this has happened here again.

PARA.TAB: It is acknowledged that this is not the end of the reform process. I understand that the joint select committee has put up other matters that it obviously wants to press with the government. The values of society change quite often, and these values must be reflected in the family law. The family law will not be static. These matters will be covered in the course of further scrutiny by the joint select committee and other committees of this House.

It is very significant that, when people are surveyed in opinion polls these days, they quite often do not refer so much to matters of unemployment or matters of an economic base as being important in their lives. Quite often they refer to personal relationships. Quite often they say that that is what they see as affecting their lives and they look to governments for assistance. That also comes through in Hugh Mackay's connotative research. People feel that a change in society is somewhat threatening and they often look to the government for assistance.

It is obvious that this legislation is part of the government's response to that. It is a very appropriate response because it reflects the fact that society now believes that children are not possessions. There should be an obligation on both parents to come up with an appropriate plan for the care and control of the children. There could not be a topic that has had more public input and parliamentary input than this one. Therefore, I am putting to the House that there is no reason whatsoever to send this legislation to another Senate committee.

We cannot underestimate the importance of this legislation. It will take away a bit of the heat that people face during the difficult time when their marriages or relationships break up. I do not want to overemphasise that point because there is obviously heat in those situations and nothing the law will do will change the situation.

This legislation strengthens the principle of looking out for the best interests of children, so why on earth does the coalition want to delay it any further? Why on earth do those opposite want to send this legislation off to a parliamentary committee in another place? I suspect that it is another example of the grubby political opportunism that we see from the coalition. Once again it is another example of how an opposition works under the leadership of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer).

I do not see any reason for another committee report into these matters. I do not want to exaggerate the point, but people are suffering. These changes are very sensible. Why deprive the people of Australia the opportunity of working with a new and better Family Law Act? That will be the effect of any coalition delay with the legislation. I wholeheartedly support the Family Law Reform Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite clearly the previous speaker, the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd), misunderstands why the opposition wants to examine further some aspects of the Family Law Reform Bill [No. 2]. I do not dispute that there was a quite long, involved and very worthwhile inquiry. My only regret—and the name of the inquiry reflects this point—is that the inquiry looked at certain aspects of the Family Law Act. It seems to me that there is still time for a complete overhaul of the Family Law Act. The whole ethos and basis of existence of the Family Law Act has been brought into question in a number of important respects since it was first introduced in 1975. In practice it simply does not work very well.

PARA.TAB: I do not think anyone in this place could seriously advocate going back to pre-1975 and the spectre of being required to prove fault. There is an imbalance here. We have somehow lost the plot and effectively made divorce easier. There needs to be a balance, and I am not advocating that we go too far to one side or the other. By law we have made divorce easier. The enormous hike in the number of divorces that have occurred post-1975 indicates that we have facilitated divorce.

You, over there, will argue that that is a good thing. In my view it is not necessarily a good thing. The other thing that you on the other side of the House have done is, in an economic sense, facilitate the break-up of marriage. When speaking in the debate about the Social Security (Parenting Allowance and Other Measures) Amendment Bill yesterday I mentioned your headlong rush to create a welfare state in this country. Once again you have made it possible for people to separate.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—The honourable member for McPherson might note that the chair has not made it possible for people to separate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has made it possible for people to leave relationships easily. Once again, that is the purpose of the government's policy. I think there may be some sort of balance there, but the government cannot argue that that has not occurred.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Leichhardt mentioned the amount of interest there is in this subject. This interest is reflected in the number of members on the speakers list. This interest is also reflected in the number of complaints that we get through our offices. In my experience, the complaints come equally from men and women who feel that they are somehow disadvantaged by the operation of the law, whether it be the operation of the Family Law Act or the operation of the Child Support Agency. These things give rise to an enormous number of complaints from men and women. In terms of complaints, one side does not outnumber the other.

This is an area of great concern. My view, which is well known in this place, is that we ought to be doing everything we can to support families, to keep families together. Yet, from my understanding, this particular legislation and indeed many of the government's economic policies have had exactly the opposite effect.

I am speaking in this debate as a non-lawyer, although I understand that the former speaker is a lawyer. Plenty of lawyers will contribute to this debate. However, my colleague on the other side of the chamber the member for Chifley (Mr Price) is not a lawyer. So a number of non-lawyers will also be contributing but it will be a fertile debate for lawyers. They will argue from a legal point of view about some technical aspects of the law as it is proposed. It is quite legitimate that that sort of debate should occur as we are concerned that we get this right.
This process has been going on for some time. The government has actually contributed to the delay. A bill was introduced into this House some time back, but it was subsequently withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let's get on with it, then.

—We are facilitating it up to a point, but you have contributed to the delays. You made the point that we are delaying the legislation, but it so happens that there are aspects of this bill that we are not satisfied with—despite the good work of the committee, chaired by the honourable member for Chifley. So often we see this government rushing into this place when it wants to make a political statement or do another political stunt, which is what a lot of legislation actually ends up being. The government then comes back the next week, the next month or the next year to fix up the problems it created and the unintended consequences. So let us get this right. What is happening to families and relationships is too important to us as a nation for us not to do this properly. It is also some time since the report was brought down—I think it was in the previous parliament—and things can change. So there is every reason for proper investigation to be going on.

PARA.TAB: It is unfortunate that we have to legislate ways of raising children when marriages break down. Children are ultimately the innocent victims of marriage breakdown. All of our experience would tell us that they are the ones most affected. Kids do not easily get over divorces. I saw some statistics recently that showed that even five years after their parents had divorced a significant number of children were still suffering the psychological effects. In other words, some were suffering severe depression and other related disorders as a result.

Divorce is not like the flu or a cold, something kids just get over. They do not get over divorce. Many of them carry the scars of their parents' divorce throughout their lives and it colours their own relationships and their own marriages to some extent down the track. It is a fact of life and, therefore, the law has to address the issues involved.

Marriage breakdown, and the family breakdown which is directly related to it, is a big problem in Australia. It would be much better if we as legislators could implement ways of addressing the problems that actually cause family breakdown. As I have suggested, I believe there are a lot of ways of doing that. Unfortunately, most of the things the Whitlam government did and this government has done have had exactly the opposite effect—to facilitate family breakdown instead of actually looking for ways to address the core problems.

We often hear people talking about the rate of divorce in our country having escalated, depending on how it is measured. I was reading recently that the good news is that most marriages appear to survive. In 1992, 7.7 million Australians were living in registered marriages, and 90 per cent of those people were in their first marriages. On that basis, only 10 per cent of those first marriages had broken up. Often divorce rates appear to be overstated as they are a comparison of the number of marriages and the number of divorces in any one year. The large number of divorces which occur from second and third marriages breaking up tends to be reflected in and distort those figures if they are looked at just on an annual basis.

Another point worth making is that the traditional family is alive and well. We often hear all sorts of talk that there is no such thing any more as a traditional or nuclear family. In fact, 86 per cent of all families in existence in Australia at the moment are couple families; they may or may not have children, but a traditional family relationship exists.

It is widely recognised that one of the key causes of marriage breakdown is financial pressure. A recent study found that one in eight traditional families is now living below the poverty line. It is quite clear that the tax system has discriminated against those families—I assume intentionally, because it is evident in the figures—in the last 10 years. Those families are living below the poverty line despite the fact that, in most cases, at least one parent is working. The same study also found that the nuclear family was one of the groups hardest hit by Labor's decade of economic mismanagement.

This bill is testament to the fact that marriage breakdown is a major problem in Australian society. There is no doubt that the current Family Law Act as a whole, particularly the Child Support Agency which flows from it, has plenty of room for improvement. I am sure that every member of this House is regularly approached by people who feel the system has let them down badly. Some of those people are extremely angry and frustrated by the extent to which the law as it exists has let them down. We see evidence of that every day. When we look at their problems as they are presented to us in our offices, there is no doubt that it would take more than the wisdom of Solomon to come up with a solution that would be acceptable to both parties in situations where goodwill has often completely broken down and there is no normal communication between the two parties. Like most members, my Family Court and Child Support Agency files are amongst the largest files I have got in my office. They detail a lot of very sad cases.

I recently conducted a school essay competition in my electorate. One of the essayists, 16-year-old Darren Bridges, who goes to Somerset College in my electorate, summed the situation up very well. The topic for the essay was related to the International Year of the Family and the sorts of things governments should be doing for families. Darren wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The statistic that divorce has trebled since 1970 is an alarming one. However if, in some cases, divorce is the only option then the government should encourage couples to move away from lengthy and expensive legal battles over custody and set up an easily accessed system of mediation—a more suitable way of sorting out human relationships than the current confrontational approach.

I think there would be general agreement to that suggestion from members on both sides of the House. This legislation goes down that track. The coalition recognises that the government is attempting to prompt an attitudinal change with this legislation. It is not easy to achieve such a change through the law; it needs to be achieved in other ways, such as through the education system. But still, to the extent that the law is attempting to do that, we support it. The government is attempting to move away from a confrontationist system and to give both parties to a broken relationship more control and responsibility for the parenting of their children.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt in my mind that parental responsibility is a vital ingredient in the successful raising of children. I have never had any doubt about the fact that children need both parents. Yet some of the commentary on the existing situation regarding families and single parents says that it does not matter; kids can be raised in any sort of relationship. It does not matter if children are raised by single parents; two parents of the same sex is almost an option on the agenda these days. All of the evidence I have ever seen—it has never been refuted—is that children fare best when they are brought up in a stable, intact two-parent family, with one of the parents being a man and the other a woman; quite obviously, that is what I am saying in that particular context.

All of the evidence points to the desirability of intact families for the sake of children. Anything else we talk about here today has to be seen as a second best solution to a problem which inevitably will arise to some extent in our society today. But, as I say, in my view it does not necessarily have to arise to the extent to which it is arising if other government policies are in place and the education system is such that marriage as an institution is put back on the pedestal where it used to be. The fact that it has fallen down is one of the underlying problems we have in our society.

The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child is now being touted as part of the reason for some of these changes. All family members have rights and responsibilities. The problem with the trendy nature of our rushing headlong into United Nations conventions is that they are all big on rights. The UN Convention on the Rights of the Child talks a lot about rights but does not really canvass responsibilities, which are the other side of the coin. If families are to work properly, there has to be within the education system a basis for understanding marriage as an institution where every family member has rights and responsibilities. In the end I do not know whether you can legislate parental responsibility; in this particular bill, we are attempting to facilitate it in some way.

In many ways, a parenting plan sounds to me like a bureaucratic solution to the problem. We will have to see how it works. I am sure the member who will be speaking after me will tell us that it is working well in the UK and that is the model for it. We will see how it works here. It is difficult to produce attitudinal behavioural changes in a hostile family environment, and that ultimately is my concern.

The opposition shares the concerns of the Law Council that this legislation ends up involving the court to a greater extent in that, while it does not scrutinise consent orders and parenting plans, they are given the full weight of a court order. That is one of the reasons, incidentally, why we would like the bill referred for consideration to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

It is easy to see, as the Law Council suggests, that both parties will need to receive independent legal advice before allowing these parenting plans to be registered with the court. It is also easy to see that these new arrangements will really only work where there is some degree of goodwill between both parties. Without that, it is difficult to see how these particular arrangements will work. Clearly, where a relationship has deteriorated to a large extent this new terminology and these new arrangements will not improve the situation at all. There will still be lengthy court disputes, and so on.

We support broadly the principles and aims of the bill, although I do so rather reluctantly. From my point of view, as I said earlier, it is really up to the government to address the root causes of marriage breakdown. More attention to some of those causes would solve a lot of the problems.

As I said during a debate yesterday, the government has created a welfare state in this country. I referred in that debate to figures which point absolutely conclusively to that: in 1971 the primary source of income of 10 per cent of the population was government welfare; now it is almost 30 per cent. We now have 4.4 million Australians relying completely on the government for their income. That is a deplorable situation and not at all desirable.

More and more people have been trapped in the welfare net and are no longer able or encouraged to take responsibility for their own lives. Responsibility surely is one of the keys to social cohesion. Yet it seems to me that this government—I am not sure whether it comes from its socialist philosophy—is all about taking individual responsibility away from people. While it continues to do that, we will continue to have the problems we are addressing today.

I strongly believe that counselling is a very desirable way of enabling people to solve problems and that premarital counselling should be more widely available. I know my colleague at the table on our side, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews), has spoken a lot about the need to improve access to counselling, particularly premarital counselling. It is very surprising—I think the committee probably had evidence of this put before it—how little premarital counselling is taken advantage of by couples intending to marry. It should be encouraged or even made mandatory, although I do not know in practice how that would work for those who are intending to marry.

Unfortunately, in many respects the existing mediation procedures have provided exactly the wrong sort of counselling. I think it is generally recognised that, by the time people enter formal mediation, the whole intention seems to be to help them further the cause of breaking up their relationship rather than attempting to counsel them on ways of getting it back together. Therefore, in my view, that has the wrong foundation completely. It may be that the extension of counselling facilities will be worth while. While there is something basically wrong with the institution of marriage, while it is no longer sacred and it no longer confers special privileges and responsibilities upon those who enter into it, it may well end up being a lost cause.

There was a letter in my local paper yesterday which I think sums up people's attitudes to what is happening in our society. A lady writes that, after looking back over 65 years of life, she can see a constant crumbling of our society and its institutions—and amongst them is marriage. Marriage used to be important and sacred to people. It used to be, as I said earlier, on a pedestal. When it ceases to be that, that is one of the fundamental reasons for the problems in our society. Families are the foundation of our society. Strong families make a nation strong. When our foundations crumble, what becomes of our society? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am thankful for the opportunity to speak in support of the Family Law Reform Bill [No. 2]. I want to start off with an apology. Firstly, I place on record the encouragement and support that members on both sides of this House have given to my committee in its child support inquiry. It is a matter of regret that we have not yet tabled that report. Whilst we have missed some deadlines, I think it reasonable to expect if all goes well that we will table the report at the end of the month or the first week in December. Those members who have so strongly encouraged and supported the committee's work will not be disappointed by the work of the committee. I acknowledge their contribution as well as that of the honourable member for Menzies (Mr Andrews).

PARA.TAB: I suppose I should get out of the way my disappointment that the opposition is referring this bill to a Senate committee. I think the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) made a fair point when he suggested that the primary task of the family law committee ought to be to complete the child support inquiry. We also have a second reference into the funding and administration of the Family Court. I will refer to that later.

The honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) made a few points to which I must strongly respond. I am not sure whether he was aware of the implications of what he said. Firstly, he said that we should make it more difficult for people in marriages to split up. I do not share that view. Basically, the statistics show that it is now women who are walking out of relationships. I do not believe the government is facilitating that in any way, but I do not think it helpful to make it harder for those women to walk out of the relationships. Either the relationship is sound and can be maintained or it has disintegrated.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not that extreme.

—I acknowledge that maybe he did not intend to say that, but I do not think it fair to single out women as the cause of marriage breakdowns. I am very disappointed that all our government money goes into the collateral end of marriages and breakdowns. None is there to assist to overcome the ups and downs. But, even if we had a very active program, we would still find a high rate of marriage breakdown. I certainly acknowledge that as a major shortcoming. Frankly, in the International Year of the Family, it is something that needs to be addressed.

PARA.TAB: I think every member on this side of the House strongly supports the view that families should be supported and that marriages and relationships should continue for as long as possible, if not infinitely. But the reality is that people do dissolve these relationships and we ought to accept it. We need to satisfy ourselves as parliamentarians that, without creating artificial barriers, we have done everything by way of providing counselling and assistance.

I certainly reject the view that it is somehow government action or policy to want to put financial pressure on marriages and/or relationships and therefore the government is responsible. I think it is a function of our society. In a very male dominated chamber, I venture the view that some of these male attitudes about marriages and relationships really need to be changed radically if we are going to see longevity in marriages and relationships.

Whilst I support the bill, I do not feel that it goes far enough in the family law area. I acknowledge the good work of the previous committee. I acknowledge that the government is picking up that committee's recommendations and I congratulate it. But I do not think it is going far enough. Why would I say that? Let me give you a few examples. I was staggered to learn that the increased funding for the Family Court over a 10-year period has been dramatic. I think most members of this House would be aware of the chief justice from time to time saying on television that he desperately needs more money for more initiatives.

The funding for the Family Court from 1981-82 to 1991-92 increased by not 50 per cent, not 100 per cent, not 200 per cent, not 300 per cent, not 400 per cent, but by 572 per cent. That is a staggering increase in funding for any institution, whether it be the Family Court or a government department. The thing that would disturb most members of parliament is that we cannot see that there is a 572 per cent better outcome in terms of access and quality of decision making. I think the Family Court has a real problem.

I know the Attorney-General's Department, for example, is responsible for the Family Court's buildings. I say to the Attorney-General's Department that I do not believe there is any correlation between the grandeur of the building in which it houses the Family Court and the quality of people's access and justice to that court. I was privileged to go to New Zealand as a guest of the New Zealand government. I dropped in to see the chief justice of the family court. To my surprise I found New Zealand did not have a separate family court. It was all part of the general division.

When I walked into the court, I found that it was a very modest court, very small, very intimate. Some judges did not even sit on a bench; they sat with the parties. I think we ought to see more of that. They were ordinary judges with a federal warrant. That raises the question—and I think this is one of the challenges for my committee: do we need a special Family Court or should it be part of the Federal Court with a special family law warrant? I think that is an issue that needs to be addressed. It has the immediate benefit that the judges themselves are not constantly dealing with Family Court issues.

The other thing that I want to say, very passionately I hope, is that we failed in the child support inquiry on the issue of custody and access. This is one of the big unsolved problem areas in family law. I do not think you are going to get much joy from the committee's report on child support. I am certainly keen to undertake the matter in the funding and the administration of the Family Court inquiry. The biggest problem, with great respect to some of my lawyer friends, is that it is all right for the Attorney or for the lawyers to say that the citizens of Australia have legal rights. Indeed they do. I have been absolutely shocked at the amount of money that people spend on their legal advice in family law matters.

I say to the Attorney-General's Department: it is about time you or the Family Court started gathering some statistics about this matter so that people can see the dimension of the problem that we are picking up anecdotally. The problem is that, by the time they have gone through their property settlement and their custody and access issues, there is no more money. It is all very well to say that if access has broken down people can go back to the court, but they have not got the money to go back to the court.

TALK.START.PARA: —And there is no legal aid available.

—The honourable member for McPherson points out the situation of legal aid. We are running out of legal aid. What is the quality of justice in this country if some people get legal aid but we say to others, `Sorry, the budget is not good. You cannot get legal aid'? Does someone not have to say that we need another process?

PARA.TAB: I do not want to take people's legal rights away from them, but I say that we are in a hypocritical position where we talk about people's rights to justice and rights to the Family Court but they cannot exercise them. Something has to give. Something has to change. No changes in this bill are going to go towards solving that problem. I know the bill talks about alternative dispute resolution problems.

I draw the attention of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and his departmental officials to the situation in New Zealand where counselling and mediation are organised by the court. You go to the court, but no court officer provides the counselling. It is all provided by outside organisations, thus overcoming part of the problem of the independence of the judiciary that the honourable member for Tangney referred to.

More interestingly, that mediation and counselling is not solely focused on collapsed relationships. A significant proportion of the focus is on people who are in difficulties, who recognise that they are in difficulties and who want some assistance to work it through. It is shameful in Australia that the Family Court is unable to provide that and that there is no equivalent service.

I have a difficulty in understanding why we do not say that judges, when dealing with children, are best placed to decide the health regime to fix a child's illness, and that judges are best placed to decide an education program to develop a child's talents—big decisions in a child's life but we do say, magically, that it is the judiciary that can decide which parent should accept what responsibility. What is it about judges that gives them this insight? I know that they are good with property and with commercial law, and I understand their role, but I do not understand their primary role in human relationships. I have suggested that we ought to look at—I hope the funding and administration inquiry will consider this—whether or not we can develop a no-frills tribunal as an alternative to the Family Court.

In other words, people will have the option of going there. They will not go to any of the grand buildings that are taxpayer funded to the extent of millions of dollars. It could be a round table discussion. It could be at 10 o'clock or 11 o'clock at night. It could even operate on Saturdays and Sundays so people could actually get there. Its process could be one of attempted conciliation. Maybe 60 per cent of the decision making could be conciliated and the rest arbitrated. We need to look at this sort of micro reform in the Family Court area to try to provide a degree of equity and access to justice. If we are going to talk about a reform program, this is the sort of thing we need to devote some attention to.

The Attorney-General's Department sought its third extension before putting a submission into the inquiry. I must say, I am looking forward to that submission. I hope and trust that it will be more substantial than the contribution it made to the child support inquiry.

Some people feel that putting television cameras into courtrooms, or even taking wigs off, is substantial law reform. Whilst I would not deprecate those moves, they go nowhere near giving men and women in Australia access to justice. People can test what we mean by access and equity. If they can get into a court with legal representation, it passes the test; if they cannot, it fails the test.

There will always be a certain number of cases that will be highly contentious and will need to be fought out in a legal area. There are also a lot of ordinary Australians who wish on an equal basis to have their disputes resolved by a non-adversarial method. Some proposals in this bill go some way to that. I also suggest that it is worth while looking at that so-called no-frills family tribunal.

I make one final observation. I have said publicly that fixing the child support area is only fixing an end point in the separation trail. With all its twists and turns, we have a long way to go. I hope this bill will make a significant contribution. I certainly hope the reference that both houses have been pleased to give my committee on the funding and administration of the Family Court will equally make a contribution.

TALK.START.PARA: —A tough job.

—It is a tough job. But there is a third area we really need to look at, and I believe it is the community area. The fact is that this government is no longer funding any new legal centres. There are dispersed community based advice services for families dealing with such things as financial counselling—and I have to say that I much prefer to see mediation out there in the community sector. But we need to have a good look at the community sector, at what it is currently doing and what it possibly could do in the future in this difficult area. We do not have a reference that covers this. I hope that, after we table the report into the child support inquiry, both houses of parliament will see fit to give us that third reference, which I think would deal with all those difficult areas in family law.

PARA.TAB: So I do not want people to be in any doubt. I certainly do support this bill and the changes it makes. It was unfortunate that the previous committee did not look at the United Kingdom children's act. I must congratulate the Attorney-General on taking the initiative to have the act reviewed and on bringing down many of the changes that are represented in this bill. I place on record my thanks to the Attorney-General for picking up the recommendations of the previous committee and implementing them in the main. I hope it will not be too long before I am able, on the committee's behalf, to table the report on the child support scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) for the sentiments that he expressed during his speech to the parliament. I agree with virtually everything he said. The Family Law Reform Bill [No. 2] is about heartbreak and agony. It is about people. It is about the dissolution of families. It needs an enormous amount of consideration by this parliament. It is the first of two separate bills to come before the House relating to family law. This one relates to mediation and other forms of alternative dispute resolution and to children. The second bill, which is due to be introduced this session—the government had better get a move on, I would suggest; the session is nearly over—will deal with matrimonial property.

PARA.TAB: I am particularly concerned with the provision of alternative dispute resolution. The bill will amend part II, marriage counselling organisations; part III, counselling and reconciliation; and part IIIA, mediation and arbitration, of the Family Law Act. It will seek to facilitate greater use of mediation, counselling and arbitration and the resolution of family law disputes, both in the court and in approved organisations in the community, and provide for approval mechanisms, community based counselling and mediation organisations to become approved mediation and/or counselling organisations under the act, and so on.

While the thrust of the bill is exemplary, without the money to back it up it is a waste of time. As member for Cowper, I have been seeking for quite some time to get additional funding for the Family Court so that counselling services can be established on the mid-north coast of New South Wales, specifically in Coffs Harbour, where in May a branch of the Family Court opened. I have been in correspondence with the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan). In his most recent letter to me he said that he shared my concern that it was important that regional centres have access to the same services as are provided in major metropolitan areas. I do not quibble with that; of course he does. The letter stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The government is responding to the need for counselling services in the Coffs Harbour region. As part of its family services program, the government is providing funding to the Family Life Movement of Australia to undertake marriage counselling through its family life centres, including its centre in Coffs Harbour.

That is correct, it is true and it is highly commendable. The family life unit in Coffs Harbour received $173,702 in the last financial year to provide marriage and family counselling and family mediation plus a very small amount of marriage education in the area including Port Macquarie—that is, the Hastings Valley—Kempsey and the Macleay Valley, the Nambucca Valley, the Bellingen Valley, Coffs Harbour, the Clarence Valley and Grafton, and the northern tablelands of New South Wales, including Armidale, Glen Innes and Tenterfield. To do all of that they have three full-time staff, only one of whom is a full-time counsellor, three part-time staff and seven sessional counsellors. In 1993-94 they conducted 2,200 interviews—mainly in Coffs Harbour, a small number in Grafton, none in the tablelands, none in the Hastings or the Manning or the Nambucca, and none in Bellingen or Dorrigo. Incidentally, there are no counselling services in Taree or the Great Lakes area either. There is a crying need for such services.

PARA.TAB: I must make it clear that my main concern with Coffs Harbour generally is that there are not enough Family Court counsellors. The Family Life Movement is doing a great job, particularly in Coffs Harbour under the management of Betty Judd. I commend her and all of the people associated with her, but they do not have the funding to go virtually anywhere outside Coffs Harbour. The same thing applies to the Family Court. As I said, my main concern is that there are not enough Family Court counsellors. The registrar in charge of the Family Court at Coffs Harbour has advised that there are presently 79 matters waiting for trial dates in Coffs Harbour and that at the next circuit 114 fresh matters are to be dealt with by the court. The court has circuits every six weeks, so every six weeks there are approximately 100 new matters coming on line. The enormous volume of litigation in this area cannot be managed adequately without skilled counsellors to deal with the more difficult matters.

Certainly, the initial funding to Family Life will assist, but the problem in this area is that we are dealing with poverty-stricken families, where the abuse of children is more prevalent than in some other areas. In fact, the chief justice has highlighted this area as one of the major priorities for additional funding. But, unless the government can see its way fit to provide the funding, all the rhetoric in the world is going to achieve nothing. To reinforce that, the response I had from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General—which stated that Family Life will be given additional funding—does not address the basic problem that we have in Coffs Harbour, namely, that highly dysfunctional families are litigating and we do not have adequate counselling facilities to assist them and the children through the litigation process.

I emphasise the importance of the children in this. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) have often heard me say that the `p' in `politics' stands for people and that the `p' in `parliament' stands for people but, above all, in this matter it stands for children and, as I said earlier, the heartbreak, agony and corrosiveness experienced by human beings because of this family breakdown. It is important that additional funding be supplied. I would like to quote from a speech the Chief Justice of the Family Court, Sir Alistair Nicholson, gave when opening the sixth national family law conference on 17 October. Whilst speaking on alternative dispute resolution, the chief justice said:

SPEECH.PARA: As a major plank of its legislative program, the Government has announced that the whole thrust of the Act will be altered in the direction of alternative dispute resolution.
What a good thing. That is why we are here today. He continues:
This approach is to be welcomed and is in accordance with the views of the Court.

However, there is a danger that what has occurred to date will become lost in the rhetoric. In a sense, the announced change of approach does not do justice to what has been achieved by the Government and its predecessors, or by the Court.
That is the nub of it. We are talking about justice—not just doing justice to what has been achieved, but providing justice for our fellow Australians. The chief justice continued:

It is too easily forgotten that the Court Counselling Service has been operating as an integral part of the Court since its inception, that the Court's Registrars have similarly been involved from the inception of the Court in the conciliation of property matters and that less than 5% of cases ever require a final judicial determination.
It also should be remembered—
and I do give praise where praise is due, as does the chief justice—
that this approach is far in advance of that adopted by any Court in Europe and that only a few States of the USA have the facility of an in-house counselling service.

The mediation model adopted by the Court is a very particular type of mediation, its main distinguishing features being the fact that it is entirely voluntary, entirely non-directive and the mediators are a combination of professionally trained lawyers and social scientists, working together.
That is quite important. But, without the funding to do it, it is not going to happen. There is insufficient funding for the counsellors, whom we need.

PARA.TAB: The chief justice, when talking about court funding, also said in his address to the annual judges meeting on 13 October 1994:

SPEECH.PARA: The Court finished the financial year with a slight overspend . . . Measures are, I believe, in hand to correct the situation, which has largely been caused by high staff levels. The reduction in these levels will involve some pain so far as Court services are concerned . . .
I repeat: so far as court services are concerned; that is, the services being provided to the families of Australia who need them. It continues:
. . . this being an inevitable concomitant of the so called efficiency dividend, which is in reality a compulsory and recurring cut in Court funding of approximately $.4M each year.

I believe that it was $450,000 in the present year. Year after year, the court is having to cut back by $400,000 or $450,000. Every time that happens, it has to lose nine staff. Over the next five years, because of this so-called efficiency dividend, the family law court must lose 45 staff members. The workload is building up enormously. I cannot see the logic or sense of it. The chief justice also said:

This is a recurring problem, as the efficiency dividend really means that we have to shed the equivalent of nine staff each year at a time when our workload is steadily increasing . . . Our administrative expenses are close to budget so that the real problem is in staff numbers, but the dilemma is how to reduce staff numbers without a corresponding reduction in services. If we transfer monies from administration to salaries, as we have done in the past, we suffer a loss of 20% of the amount transferred.

So, if the court takes it out of administration to try to keep some people at the coalface, so to speak, working with dysfunctional families, it loses 20 per cent of it because that is part of the efficiency dividend. What craziness! The chief justice went on to say:

. . . no real progress will be made in the long term while the Government adheres to its efficiency dividend policy, (now abandoned by the NSW Government). This currently erodes the Court's funding base and taken to its logical conclusion, will eventually mean that the Court will have to shut down registries or curtail services such as counselling and circuits to keep within budget.

This is not on. Everyone in this place is aware of the enormous growth of problems in families and divorce and the need for litigation, counselling and mediation. We are placing our Family Court in a situation where, sooner or later, if this keeps on going, it will disappear up its own exhaust pipe. That is not satisfactory. When we talk about curtailing services, we are talking about the impact on people. We are talking about people in crisis and people who are involved in frightful family dissolution. As I said, it has a very bad impact on men, women and children.

PARA.TAB: I refer again to the caseload for the Family Court in Coffs Harbour. There are presently 79 matters waiting for trial dates. At the next circuit, there are 114 fresh matters to be dealt with by the court. So, with a court circuit every six weeks, approximately 100 new matters are coming on line every six weeks. These are people in crisis and in great shock who need mediation, help and counselling.
I return to what the chief justice said when he opened the sixth national family law conference. When talking about a pilot program for mediation, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The pilot program has been very successful, but it would be naive to suggest that it can ever be a substitute for the Court's Counselling Service or the service offered by the Court's Registrars.

The court's counselling service and the court's registrars lose nine people every year because of the efficiency dividend. Eventually, carried to the logical, but not very sensible, conclusion, it will disappear. The chief justice went on to say:

It does however, constitute another very useful additional technique in the settlement of family disputes and I am hopeful that it can soon be offered at all of the Court's Registries. The service has operated in the Melbourne Registry since January 1992 and in the Sydney Registry since November 1993. The court expects to open a service in Brisbane in 1995-6.

In May 1994, the court opened a new counselling service to the Gold Coast in Queensland, which is one of the fastest growing population areas in Australia, as is the north coast of New South Wales. The north coast of New South Wales has unemployment levels which are virtually double those in the rest of Australia. That places a significant strain on the system because areas with high unemployment are high stress areas. This is where you find a dreadful increase in domestic violence, marital breakdown and all of these things. The chief justice went on to say:
There are many other areas of Australia where permanent counsellors should be stationed such as Alice Springs, Coffs Harbour, the Sunshine Coast of Queensland, Gosford, Geelong and many others.

The Family Court can see it; the chief justice can see it. I am sure the Attorney-General can see it too. I am sure the Attorney-General and his parliamentary secretary are aware of the problem. I am absolutely certain that they will do everything in their power to try to address that problem and expand on it. But it comes back to money. Therefore, it comes back to the cabinet and the government as a whole, which will have to support what the Attorney-General and his parliamentary secretary are trying to do with more funding. This is not in the interests of the Family Court itself; this is in the interests of Australians who are in enormous trouble. The chief justice continued:

I am also anxious to develop outreach counselling whereby the Court's counsellors will co-operate with other agencies, particularly in the outer suburbs of the large cities and will be posted to such locations, either on a permanent or visiting basis.
He went on to say:

Other initiatives which I believe should be pursued in the area of alternative dispute resolution and which I have conveyed to Government are the amendment of the Act to enable Registrars to conciliate property disputes prior to the filing of proceedings in the Court and the setting up of a small claims jurisdiction within the Court.

I certainly commend to the government the recommendations of the chief justice. The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd), who spoke a little earlier on the bill and the coalition's attitude to it, was rather scathing of the coalition's proposition that the question of court supervision, consent orders and registered parenting plans, together with other more technical concerns, should be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for consideration. He said, `There's no need to send the legislation to the Senate committee. Why on earth would the coalition want to delay this?' I say to the member for Leichhardt and others who share his views that we do not want to delay it.

PARA.TAB: This report came before the parliament in 1992. The first version of the bill came here in June, which was a good year and a half later. Because it was not a very satisfactory bill—I will be polite about it—the government, of its own volition, withdrew it. Here it is back again in a much better form. We want the legislation to go to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs so that we get it right. Again, if it does mean a delay of another couple of months, that is okay; just let us please get it right. Let us get it right for the families and for the kids of Australia.

I conclude by noting the very desperate and urgent need for Family Court counsellors in Coffs Harbour to service the north coast of New South Wales and the northern tablelands. At present, the government and the parliamentary secretary have said, `It's up to the Family Court to allocate its funds accordingly. We're not telling the chief justice where he's got to put his counsellors; that's his decision.' But he cannot make any decision and he cannot put anybody in another area unless he has the funding to do it. Do not forget the disappearing up the exhaust pipe act where the efficiency dividends, for heaven's sake, are taking nine staff members away each year. I fail to understand that.

We need to make sure that enough funding is given to the Family Court. I also make a plea for additional funding for the Family Life Movement. I briefly revert to what I said about the Coffs Harbour operation. The counsellors are supposed to look after Hastings, Maclean, Nambucca, Bellingen, Coffs Harbour, Clarence and the whole of the northern tablelands. They cannot get out of Coffs Harbour, except for looking after a few people in Grafton.

Perhaps the member for Charlton will stand up in a minute and say, `I don't know about the member for Cowper; he is always asking for more money.' I am always asking for more money for the Pacific Highway, as he knows. This time I make no apology whatsoever for asking for more money so that the Family Court can function efficiently and so that the Family Life Movement can function to its capacity and help the families, and in particular the children, of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to participate in this debate on the Family Law Reform Bill [No. 2] 1994. I note that it is not a debate in the normal sense where we expect contention between the government and the opposition. The opposition has quite correctly indicated that it is supporting at least the general thrust of the bill and, as the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) has just indicated, it will be moving an amendment in the Senate at least in order to have a closer look at the question of whether or not the Family Court can or should exercise continuing surveillance over consent orders.

PARA.TAB: One of the difficulties in connection with family law generally is the fact that, with whatever goodwill and whatever good intentions governments bring to this question, there is no way that any government or any parliament can enact legislation which is designed to overcome, and be effective in doing so, basic human frailties, sensitivities and inadequacies. We can establish procedures, we can establish frameworks, we can establish processes and we can give leads, but we can never overcome, and we can never adequately compensate for, all of the difficulties that arise in human relationships.

The contribution made by the honourable member for Cowper was very valuable to the debate, as was the contribution made by the member who led for the opposition, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams). It was a very thoughtful and careful presentation of the opposition's attitude towards this legislation.

The bill seeks to amend the Family Law Act 1975. Consideration was given to the matter before the legislation was enacted in 1975, so it covers a period of about 20 years. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) drew attention in his second reading speech to what he regards as one of the great social initiatives of the Whitlam government. Yes, it was.

Credit is due to the late Lionel Murphy. To a very large extent Lionel Murphy was the architect of and had responsibility for the carriage of that legislation. He had the responsibility, as most members will recall, of attempting to encourage general community acceptance of the legislation. There were a lot of people who wanted the fault element of family breakdowns, separations and divorces retained. They wanted the guilt element retained, despite the fact that marriages fall apart when they irretrievably break down for whatever reason. One of the great achievements was to remove the concept of guilt from family breakdowns, separations and divorce and, at the same time, to start on a 20-year program of concentrating our attention on the interests of children, which is where it should be concentrated.

This legislation is very comprehensive. It is comprehensive in terms of the consultative processes to which it gives attention. It is also comprehensive in terms of the consultation which has taken place for it to get to this stage. The draft bill was introduced, as other members have observed, on 30 June and it has received fairly wide consideration since then.

The bill is also comprehensive in terms of its content. There are two particular elements to which I will be making reference. The first major element concerns part VII of the act, which deals with children, and the second major element, as far as I am concerned and as far as my contribution is concerned, is how we can extend the range of dispute resolution mechanisms which are available. These points are extremely and fundamentally important. I will not be saying much about the consideration which has been given to domestic violence in this particular legislation. That is something which I might have an opportunity to pursue on other occasions.

In addition, there are two further steps to which reference has been made in developing this general approach and this general issue. There will be a further bill introduced this sitting that will deal with matrimonial property, prenuptial financial agreements and a number of other issues. Hopefully that will be introduced during this present session. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) will make a justice statement early next year. In the context of that, he will be addressing the level and priority of family law funding. This bill is really part of a package of approaches which the government has undertaken to more adequately address the types of issues which are involved and the matters which are of concern.
I referred to the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General. There is one particular statement that he made in that context to which I want to refer:
The Family Law Act 1975 was one of the great social and legislative reforms of the Whitlam government . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I have made reference to that, and I repeat it because it is of fundamental importance that we recognise the origin of it. Again, let me record credit to the late Lionel Murphy for his enlightened vision, his understanding and his humanity, which he brought to bear on that and other legislation.

PARA.TAB: I will firstly deal with the general area of dispute resolution. The parliamentary secretary said:

SPEECH.PARA: Once amended by this bill the act will emphasise the importance the government places on methods of dispute resolution other than litigation by categorising counselling and mediation as primary dispute resolution.

That is important. It provides an important conceptual approach. In chapter 4 of the joint select committee report, the committee defined counselling and mediation. The committee accepted the definition of the Attorney-General's Department of `counselling':
. . . a process where a neutral third party assists parties to deal with the stresses they encounter as they move into, live within or move out of the family unit.
In relation to mediation, the committee accepted the Family Court and the Family Law Council definition:
. . . a process by which participants, with the assistance of a third person or persons, consider alternatives and reach a consensual settlement that will accommodate their needs.
It goes on to say:
Mediation emphasises the participant's own responsibilities for making decisions that affect their lives.

They are important definitions because they are fundamental to the whole of the government's approach to counselling and mediation in dispute resolution. This legislation provides for an approval process for community based counselling and mediation so that organisations and individuals can apply for and receive approval status and therefore be involved in that area.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether there are any matters that have come to my attention in my electoral office and from my constituency with which there is a greater level of human feeling involved than family law matters. I never cease to be amazed at the venom, the hatred, the despair, the anguish, the disillusionment and the frustration which people bring into my office in relation to their former partners. I tell them quite bluntly that there is no way in the world that I, or anyone else with whom I am associated in government or anywhere else, can enact legislation which will compensate for those attitudes. How is it possible for a man to have sired a child and for a woman to have borne that child and then feel about each other the way they do and express sentiments of venom and hatred, often verging on violence—certainly oral violence?

I am stunned and appalled, and I despair at some of the things I hear and the way in which those things are said. This is reflected in the recent attacks that we have had on Family Court judges, on the families of Family Court judges, on the property of court judges and on the property of the courts themselves. For example, just a few days ago—and this was apparently related to a case in which a wife was seeking custody of the children—a newspaper report said:

SPEECH.PARA: A three-hour siege ended peacefully yesterday—
fortunately; they do not always end that way—
in Melbourne after a man who rammed his car through the front of a city Family Court building surrendered to police marksmen. Police charged—
I will not mention his name—
with conduct endangering life and criminal damage. He was remanded in custody to appear in Melbourne Magistrates Court on December 2.

Cases are compounded one after another. We will do our best, but our best will not be good enough. It will not be good enough until we are able to prevail on the basic humanity, goodwill, sensitivity and conscience of people to more effectively examine their circumstances, examine their human relationships, think more deeply about the welfare of their children and, hopefully, attempt to do something about it.

PARA.TAB: There is another area that I want to refer to briefly. As well as the matters of counselling and mediation there is the appalling question of costs. If I get a chance, I will refer to some of the things that Lionel Murphy said in 1973 and 1974 when he referred to the question of costs. He introduced the legislation in the hope of reducing costs.
Let me refer to a couple of things from the select committee report. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: A witness in Albury, in response to a comment that `as the law is at the present, the solicitors, barristers and QCs are the ones making big, big money and leaving the two families poor for the rest of their lives', stated:
In this case the legal costs are well over $400,000 for all the parties and that is a lot of dough.
My word, it is a lot of dough! Submission 287 said, in part:
I wanted legal advice, as I was working, my partner works casual—total income did not exceed $400 per week—I wasn't entitled to legal aid. On visiting four solicitors the following became evident.
Sol. 1 wanted $800 up front before he would look at the case. If he accepted the case I would have to pay an extra $2,000 plus barrister fees for the court + other costs.
Sol. 2 $1,500 up front + $3,000 per day in court costs.
Sol. 3 $1,250 up front + $1,500 per day plus barrister costs.
Sol. 4 $300 to look at case $700 if case taken $80 per hour at court $72 per page of declarations etc. plus min of $500 for court costs.
Mr Deputy Speaker, submission 354 said, in part:
It is costing the Government millions in Legal Aid, and the money parents are spending would be so much more beneficial going towards the children's upbringing.

Of course it would be.
