If there is any means by which we can provide structures and arrangements to ensure that families are not going to burden themselves with debt and destroy themselves financially for the rest of their lives, then we should be giving consideration to them and, of course, that is precisely what we are doing.

PARA.TAB: We have a Family Court in Newcastle. It was not established until 1980. I must give credit to all of my colleagues who campaigned for its establishment. Then there was the support that we have had from the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee), who has recently joined us. We keep an eye on the operation of the court and we are generally pleased with the operation of that court.

The court has 34 staff, including a director of court counselling, seven counsellors, one child-care worker and two administrative staff within the court counselling service. It has two judges. The registry has an estimated population catchment of 1.1 million, and the figures indicate that the registry is a productive and an efficient operation. Locally approved marriage counselling organisations include Unifam, Centacare, Marriage Guidance, Family Life and the Community Justice Centre. All around Australia, of course, we have similar types of operations related to this legislation.

Seventy to 75 per cent of people reach satisfactory agreements through alternative dispute resolution; that is, they do not have to have the orders imposed on them in the process of litigation within the court and with all of the legal representation. Approximately five per cent of cases proceed to trial. It is in a sense a sorry reflection on our social circumstances that, according to some figures, 30 per cent of marriages fail and, according to other figures, 40 per cent. If we split the difference, about 35 per cent of all marriages in Australia fail. Very often, of course, they fail at a time when there are still dependent children within the marriage. Those children and their interests have to be addressed.

The second major area of the amendments concerns the attitude towards and the treatment of children. The emphasis has been shifted, fortunately, from parental rights to parental responsibilities. There is an understanding that, when a family into which children have been born breaks up because of the alienation of the parents, the best interests of the children are of paramount importance. That issue is fundamental. To emphasise this, the concepts which tend to treat children as property have been avoided. References to custody and access have been taken out of the legislation. You do not have custody of children as a lump of property; you have a responsibility in relation to children. The mechanisms of custody and access orders have been replaced by residence orders and contact orders. I know you do not necessarily change meanings by changing titles, but there are important modifications built into that. In addition to those orders, there is also provision for child maintenance orders and what are referred to as special purpose orders. I know that that question was addressed by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) to good effect in his response on behalf of the opposition.

The orders can be determined by the court or, in the case of consent orders, endorsed by the court. I acknowledge the problem that the opposition has drawn attention to and that is inherent in this process. It is possible for consent orders to be registered and enforceable by the court and to be expressed with provisions, requirements and arrangements which the court itself would not impose. So there is a problem there. Of course we want people to come to understandings and agreements, and we want them to come to consent arrangements; but there is a problem there, and it is something that we will need to keep under review. The question of general court surveillance and related matters has been raised by a number of members. The unfortunate thing is that children are so often used as weapons in the parents' armoury, as part of their conflict equipment. The parents use their own children.

The question of parental rights is a very contentious one, I recognise, and it is one which is often misunderstood. Parents often say, `Well, what about parents' rights?' But I want to emphasise the important common law principle identified in a United Kingdom case. Reference is made to this in the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General. It was adopted by a majority of the High Court of Australia in what is identified as Marion's case:

SPEECH.PARA: The principle of law is that parental rights are derived from parental duty and exist only so long as they are needed for the protection of the person and property of the child.

That principle is fundamental to the whole approach of this legislation. It recognises the fact that, as I said, children are not property and no-one, not even their parents, has any property rights over them. As far as possible, we must seek to free children from trauma associated with the breakdown in their parents' relationship. The essential purpose of these parts of the bill is to assist parents to reach agreement about arrangements for their children rather than having solutions imposed on them.

PARA.TAB: Division 4 of part VII of the bill makes provision for parenting plans and encourages their use. Those plans can be registered and enforced. There is also an important variation from the present law under which the custodial parent exercises daily care and control of the child. Underlying this legislation is the principle that parents have a dual responsibility, a common responsibility, for their children. Certain provisions to that effect are built into the legislation. It is important legislation. It comes at the end of a 20-year period of development. It is not the end of the story, but we will, as we must, keep it under continuing surveillance and review and, perhaps, subject it to necessary and continuing reform. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it had followed the recommendations of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, the Family Law Reform Bill [No. 2] could have been one of the most important pieces of legislation brought before this parliament in the past 20 years. Regrettably, the government's response to those recommendations is inadequate. One can only hope that there will be further legislation from, and further change in attitude by, the government to what happens in what the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has quite properly described as a very traumatic situation.

PARA.TAB: Such situations are probably the most difficult ones for members of parliament to deal with. No doubt, every member of this House has talked to both the husband and wife in these sorts of cases and has experienced the trauma, the anger, the violence and the irrational behaviour which arise as a result of this particular problem.

The report by the joint select committee ran to 450 pages. The committee received 943 submissions. It held public hearings over two years throughout Australia, in capital cities and in many country areas. It took evidence and received submissions from a number of constituents from my electorate and, no doubt, from those in the electorate of Charlton.
The basic philosophy for family law was spelt out in the Senate on 13 December 1973 by the then Attorney-General, Senator Lionel Murphy. In the second reading speech on the Family Law Bill, he said:

It is hoped that in appropriate cases a person who has filed an application for divorce, particularly a person who has filed such an application before the end of the 12 months separation period, will use the services of expert marriage counsellors, who I expect to be attached at least to the Superior Court. I considered whether there should be provision for compulsory reconciliation conferences between the spouses, as there are in other countries, but rejected the notion as being unacceptable to the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: I doubt that the late Lionel Murphy would have the same view if he were here with us today. A large number of people gave evidence to the joint select committee on the Family Law Act which bears testimony to the fact that the system is deficient. It is deficient because the philosophy adopted by the government is to attend to the damage after the event rather than to look at reconciliation and counselling processes before the matter reaches the courts.

PARA.TAB: I know that that is easy to say in this House, but the Australian community could well look at whether there needs to be provision for compulsory reconciliation conferences before the event and whether it can devise a system to meet the requirements of the people before the processes move to the Family Court itself. The honourable member for Charlton has already referred to the anxiety, the trauma, the violence and the irrational behaviour that have occurred in this context. He gave just one example of a spouse who was obviously going through tremendous trauma in not being able to have access to his children and who then behaved so irrationally as to drive a car through the glass doors of the Family Court in Bourke Street in Melbourne.

There are many cases of similar pressures and tensions suffered by people who become involved in the court and the processes of property settlement and the rights of the children. I guess the No. 1 consideration in all of this is the absolute rights and best interests of the children of any broken marriage. That is where we need to direct our attention.

When I read through the three speeches that the late Senator Lionel Murphy made on the Family Law Bill when he introduced it and see that he rejected the idea of compulsory reconciliation conferences between the spouses, it occurs to me that somewhere along the line the government has missed the point that it is better to try to bring the parties together for a reconciliation process. Even if only some of the marriages could be saved, it would be in the best interests of the children, in the best interests of the two spouses and in the best interests of the Australian community.

In that 1973 speech by Lionel Murphy he went on to say that the bill recognised the desirability of reconciliation being kept in mind at all stages until the marriage is dissolved. When he said he expected that the marriage counsellors would be attached at least to the superior court, even then that was looking at the aftermath, after the spouses have got to the courts; it was not looking forward and looking at providing reconciliation counselling before the processes moved into the court.

Having read that and seen the basic philosophy and thread, I noticed that it was reflected even in the terms of reference of the committee of inquiry. The first term of reference was the role, funding, effectiveness and availability of the services of the Family Court Counselling Service. I did not see any mention of this in the report until the conclusions on counselling services on page 52. Paragraph 3.82 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee would prefer to see increased funding for marriage education, and the introduction of measures to increase community awareness of the benefits of seeking professional help at an early stage in marital difficulties.

I could not agree more. That has not been adopted by the government, because all the talk in this bill and in the government's rhetoric is that the funding and the counselling will be available after the processes at the Family Court. Yet we see in this report that the committee made a particular point in that recommendation and the conclusions that the effort needs to be made before that stage, and that we must provide increased funding for marriage education and the introduction of measures to increase community awareness of the benefits of seeking professional help at an early stage in any marital difficulties.

PARA.TAB: I do not think any member in this House could argue with that, but it is contrary to the philosophy spelt out by the late Senator Lionel Murphy in his second reading speech when he introduced his bill. That part of it is very important. The Chief Justice of the Family Court in fact gave evidence to the committee and, in that evidence—referred to on page 306, at paragraph 13.24 of the report—he referred to the level of satisfaction of litigants after the settlement of a dispute. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I have been a practising barrister for many years before I was a judge and I do not think I recall anyone who was ever satisfied with a settlement of a dispute, other than those who managed to get a result that was wildly beyond what they expected. But that did not happen very often.
His next words are very telling:
I think in family law matters there is never a winner.

By making that statement, the Chief Justice of the Family Court has really reinforced something that members of parliament dealing with these problems see day after day. There are no winners; in fact, there are many losers. That is why I am stressing the need for the government to see what can be done in the area of reconciliation processes of counselling and marriage guidance. Have another look at this report. See if it is necessary to bring back legislation. If it does not require legislation, then the government should at least adopt a change of thinking that will direct attention to those areas where the funding could be applied, to foster an awareness in the community that people should seek help before things reach the courts.

PARA.TAB: The transfer of children has been an issue that has arisen recently. I have had discussions with members of Victoria Police on this matter. It was addressed on page xix at paragraph 42 of the committee's report. I want to refer to that because it is a particularly important issue. Victoria Police told me that they have not been advised about orders that were made by the courts for the transfer of children to one or other of the spouses outside a police station.

The committee obviously looked at this, because it made recommendations to the government that, unless certain criteria had been met, the changeover should not occur outside a police station. It said that the changeover of the children from one spouse to the other should not occur `unless it has been positively ascertained that the police station is suitably staffed to facilitate such a change-over', unless `the officer in charge of that police station agrees to the police station being used as a custody exchange point' and unless `a copy of the order has been made available to the officer in charge of the police station at least 48 hours prior to any custody/access change-over'.

The Victoria Police advised me that they were quite often finding out after the event that it had been designated that a changeover should occur outside a police station. The partners would turn up and events would lead to an emotional outburst which, quite often, would end up in physical violence. The police would first know about it when they had to come out and try to mediate in the dispute. One can imagine the trauma that the spouses and the children go through in a process like that. That is a very important issue which should be addressed by the government. I have looked through the bill and I do not see any reference to it. It may be tucked away in the fine print somewhere, but I certainly do not see anything.

I now turn to another matter, which is the report of the ombudsman. On page 362 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, the ombudsman made some very telling comments about the Child Support Agency. I know that, whilst it may not be exactly expressed in this bill, it certainly is related to it. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: The CSA may well have been the greatest single source of difficulty for my office during the year. It was not just the complaint numbers. Its administrative system seems complex, its staff appear at times not to have grasped how the law operates; and it is not as responsive to complaints, whether from me or from the public, as ought to be expected . . . But the number of complaints remains a prime source of concern because the client group is so much smaller than that of the other agencies with high complaint levels.

I also note that 204,000 people had been involved in complaints to the Child Support Agency, as at September 1991. I know that that figure is still increasing. You have to ask yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker, whether the government has, in fact, got it right with the legislation that is before the House. I do not believe that it has. I think its response to the committee's report has been inadequate, and the government needs to have another look at it.

PARA.TAB: I also believe that the government's response to the Child Support Agency issues is inadequate. One has to ask oneself whether it is the Child Support Agency administration, the process or the law that is deficient. It is likely to be a combination of all three. I believe that it is imperative that the government revisit the Family Law Act and the committee of inquiry's recommendations on this.

There are many other issues which the government needs to address. I have endeavoured to spell some of them out this morning in my address to the House, but I believe that there are many things which go back to the fundamental process, right from its beginning on 13 December 1973. The government needs to return to that and to discuss the philosophy behind that. It needs to look at the history of the family law legislation in the past 20 years to find out whether the original philosophy, as expressed by then Attorney-General Lionel Murphy, was adequate and whether it meets the requirements of the people who become involved in divorce proceedings. It also needs to look at the fundamental issue of whether the rights and interests of the children involved are properly addressed. I do not believe they are. I think that it is appropriate for the government to go back and to look at that. Otherwise, we are going to see a continuation of the trauma, the violence and the irrational behaviour that feature in so many of these cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise to support the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 [No. 2] and I acknowledge the thoughtful contribution by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid). The private experiences and personal pain of people are indeed a very difficult area for government to legislate on. Family life, as we have all experienced, is very varied. Nothing works quite so well as family life when it is working well and, at the same time, nothing is more difficult and more traumatic than family life when it fails to meet nurturing and caring needs, as happens when families break down.

PARA.TAB: The bill introduced by Lionel Murphy in 1973 was a watershed in our history that moved us away from the bad old days of having to find cause and marital misconduct. An unintended consequence of that revolution and reform was that we failed to understand the human difficulties and the need of people to find someone to blame when they suffer hurt and dislocation in their personal lives. It would seem to me, from my professional experience in counselling families, that this need to blame, and to project that blame onto another person, has found its way into custody disputes in the Family Court process.

This issue of blame was obviously one of many looked at by the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. I commend the work of that committee. Some of its members are on the joint standing committee that is currently looking at the child support scheme. I pay tribute to that very hardworking committee. I also pay tribute to the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), who has been very prompt in his response, and to the reform agenda that this government has to make the law more accessible and to provide for real social justice for Australians. The reforms currently being debated will go a considerable way to meeting the many difficulties in this area of law, difficulties that are well known, I believe, to every local member because we get many calls and requests for assistance.

There are two main areas in the amendments to the Family Law Reform Bill. The first is the extension of the availability of dispute resolution procedures involving mediation and counselling. The bill makes it clear that it is talking about primary dispute resolution, giving a signal to potential litigants that these forms of dispute resolution should be engaged in prior to seeking resolution of any dispute through a court imposed decision. But this does not take away the right of applicants to proceed to law. As other speakers have indicated, two of the major problems for people in seeking to have their concerns addressed are the huge costs and time delays involved in presenting a case to the Family Court.

The second main focus is in part VII of the act. It has been redrafted entirely and replaces the current concepts of custody, access and guardianship with a new statutory concept called `parental responsibility'. In addition to the notion of parental responsibility, parents have a duty to provide the child with a residence and contact in accordance with agreed parenting plans or court orders. I will refer later in more detail to that change.

I think the move to expanding the counselling and mediation opportunities is very pertinent and to the point. It has been my experience that, when marriages break down, the breakdown has often been of a long gestation. Very often, the seeds of the failure of the relationship have their origin in the histories of those two individuals and, particularly, their experiences in their own families of origin. So, when one comes to provide counselling for people at this very traumatic time, one is often faced with traumas that go back to their own families, their relationships with their parents and the sorts of gender roles that were defined in their families. I have very often had the experience of realising that those difficulties had their origins in the grandparents' experiences. So, as far as one can trace back with an individual or a couple, one is often dealing with several generations of difficulty and dysfunction.

One is also dealing with the fact that we often base our concept of family life on the interesting concept of romantic love. We translate this into the most important social and economic unit in our society, wherein we choose to nurture and raise the next generation. In fact, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl—as I am sure you would recognise—romantic love, lust or a combination of both is not what keeps relationships together over a long period of time. What I have discovered personally, and in my counselling, is that the qualities you need for the long haul are respect, caring, consideration, friendship, tolerance and forbearance—all those things that members of this House display on a day-to-day basis as we debate issues across the floor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mateship.

—I thank my colleague. When people make choices in the glow of love, lust or a combination of both, we should not be surprised that, in the afterglow, they find that they have not spent time developing those other qualities which would develop a long-term relationship.

PARA.TAB: It is often put to me that if we had lots more counsellors and so on we would not have all these marriage breakdowns. Certainly, counselling can make a huge difference, but we cannot change the course of history. We are in a period of rapid economic and social change, with new expectations and new opportunities for both men and women to develop and pursue independence in their work and family responsibilities. I believe the fact of marriage breakdown is going to stay with us. I think it would be unrealistic to suggest that if we provide lots and lots of counselling we are going to stop that from happening.

However, what we can do right through the process—and I think this is important for the family agencies and Family Court counsellors, at that end of the spectrum—is provide a range of marriage education and support counselling opportunities. It is in the nature of human beings that they do not think they have got a problem until it hits them between the eyes. Very often, it is not until one or other party walks out of a relationship that the partner who is left finally faces the fact that there have been problems. At that point in time, it is absolutely crucial that people have access to mediation and counselling services, of which this bill is going to allow a much wider distribution.

This is particularly the case in regional and rural areas of the country. It is certainly true in my own electorate. The experience I had in mining towns was that the availability of Family Court counsellors was limited to two counsellors in Rockhampton, which meant that people had to take time off work and travel for two or three hours, or more, for an appointment. They often had to miss work and so on to avail themselves of those opportunities. In fact, it was through my own program of providing family counselling on site, in a program that was supported by unions and management, that the coalmining communities that I worked in had, for the first time, a professional counselling service available—at a crisis level and in the longer term—to work on these issues. Under this new legislation, the sorts of services that I was providing would be recognised.

One of the issues that can be dealt with in counselling at this point is assisting both parties to obtain information about their rights under the act but also encouraging them to begin to solve the problem rather than taking it through the legal system. As the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and others have said, not only does the court system impose huge costs and stresses and mark the beginning of a long descent into acrimony and threat and counterthreat which ultimately affects the children in a very destructive way; it also militates against the possibility that the parents will begin to see that the important issue, as they deal with their own pain at the break-up of the relationship and the loss of many dreams they had about what their future would provide for them, is that they must be aware of what this experience is doing to their children.

I am sure all members of the House, whether they are parents or otherwise, are aware of the destructive consequences to children of lack of resolution of marital disputes which then spill over into parenting disputes. It is my view that the only way we will achieve a satisfactory solution is, as soon as possible, to provide the potential litigants with the opportunity to work through the trauma, the anger and the grief and begin to take responsibility not only for their part in the break-up of the relationship but for their need to see that they have a continuing responsibility to their children and that they must be able to set aside their conflicts with their ex-spouse or ex-partner to achieve an effective parenting role with their children.

Where this is not possible, there is the difficulty of one party being discouraged from having access or of access orders not working under the old scheme. That is the great challenge of the new plan, which provides for both parenting plans and orders and which, as the bill makes clear, is founded on these principles: the children have the right to know and be cared for by both parents; children have the right of contact on a regular basis with both parents and any other person significant to the care, welfare and development of the child; parents share duties and responsibilities concerning the care, welfare and development of the child; and parents should agree about the future parenting of the child.

These principles come out of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, which Australia ratified on 17 December 1990, and they are indeed very sound principles on which the new parenting plans and orders are premised. However, that is the challenge, because what we have to overcome, as I said, are the hostilities. It is altogether understandable that children faced with the fractioning of their family life wish fervently for a situation where they can reunite their parents, and they often have fantasies about their power to make this happen. One of the things in counselling children is to help them accept the fact that they do not have that sort of power; that it is a psychological process that they go through, believing that, if only they would be better or stronger, that could effect the reunification of the family. That often leads to huge difficulties.

Another aspect of the reforms that I am particularly pleased about is the extension of counselling services and representation of children. While it has always been held that the Family Law Act was intended to maintain the welfare of the children, it is very easy for counsellors and others to assume that they know best, and the children are not in a position to make a judgment or a decision. Given that children can be caught between their commitments to both parents, it is my experience that if children are offered the opportunity to work through these conflicts they can express a view about their degree of contentment, but it is important to emphasise their need to somehow effect the resolution on their terms.

There are many parents who have felt a great deal of anger and frustration when the court or court counsellors, with the best intentions in the world, have made decisions, based on their assessment or interview with both parents, that have not been for the children's perceived welfare. In spite of decisions made by the court, situations then arise where children run away from home or suffer further difficulties in their relationships with the parent with whom they are residing.

We have a great challenge in front of us to now effect these changes. Allocation of considerable resources into the counselling and mediation area will be needed so that particularly in regional and rural areas of the country—I see you, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, nodding in agreement because we both represent regional areas of the country—people can have access to mediation and counselling assistance.

Problems arise, for instance, with a teleconference. One party can be sitting in the office of the Family Court counsellor, say, in Brisbane while the other party may be in Rockhampton or further west, which is an unequal situation. The alternative is a great deal of expense for the parent who is wanting to attend the conference in person.

So we have a great deal to do in this area. However, I believe that the reforms in the bill will clearly signal major changes, particularly to the notion of children being `property' of parents and the need to make sure that the views and concerns of all parties—the children and the two spouses—are involved.

It would be my contention that the sooner we allow for the possibility of access to counselling and advice at the time of the separation of the parties the sooner parents will be encouraged not only to deal with their own trauma in the failure of a relationship but to focus on their responsibilities to their children, who never wanted the break-up to happen in the first place in most instances.

This bill's very important reforms will make a major contribution and will go some way towards making sure that there is real access to justice and that the cost of that justice allows people to feel that they have been able to pursue their requirements. At the other end, we need to strive to make sure that right through the development of families there is access to education information that will assist them to solve problems before the point of marriage breakdown. So I commend the bill to the House and I commend the Attorney-General and the reform agenda that he has in place with the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) on major areas that impact daily on the lives of families in this country. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My views on the Family Law Reform Bill [No. 2] are based, as they are for us all, on a mixture of inputs into my life. As a member of parliament, like so many other members, I am well aware that the present system of family law in this country is unsatisfactory. That has been made clear to me by the number of people who have come through my office door with problems. In particular, the Child Support Agency is probably the most incompetent organisation ever invented by any bureaucracy anywhere in the world. I do not think I would get much argument from any member in this place on that.

PARA.TAB: However, there are broader issues in this bill than just the Child Support Agency. Before becoming a member of parliament, I was involved at one time with counselling services in this area. Within the last two years I have also had personal experience, through my own divorce, of the Family Court, custody and access matters, and the use of the counselling service, so I also speak as a user of the system. It is very hard to divorce my emotional experiences in that regard and be totally objective on some of these matters, but it does give me a unique perspective. Going through the Family Court is a very painful and difficult process. It could be made a lot easier with better basic administration, apart from any changes to structures. I will say more about that later.

The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams) said in his opening speech that the coalition will not oppose the legislation, but we will refer some questions of concern to a committee. Overall, I am uncomfortable with many elements of this bill. Fundamentally, it is about dispute resolution and counselling. The legislation is based on evidence from the United Kingdom which I do not believe is actually substantiated. I will return to that point later as well.

The fundamental problem with this bill is that it seeks to defy human nature. It is a matter of hope triumphing over reality. Essentially, the mechanisms that are being put in place, with counselling and arbitration before resorting to the legal system, substantially favour those who have the money to hold out for a long time. They favour those who have a strong personality or are smooth talkers and who can prolong the process on an ongoing basis until they get their own way. The right outcome does not necessarily evolve from that process. If people cannot agree within a marriage, they have even less chance of agreeing under stress when they are getting divorced or are separated, particularly if they are trying to build new lives.

The following points are not in any priority order, but they are the concerns that I have about this bill. Firstly, if counselling or arbitration is to be effective, the quality of the people providing that service has to be looked at. From my experience, that is a major concern. This legislation sets up a mechanism whereby counselling services can effectively be contracted out. Other speakers in this debate have said it is desirable that it be contracted out so that the court is not involved. Counselling or arbitration has to be seen to be independent, particularly if later on the matter becomes a case before the Family Court.

However, I worry that many of the organisations likely to be approved will be voluntary organisations, made up of those desirous of being involved, who will not necessarily be trained or experienced. I note that in the reporting and accounting mechanisms there is provision for the minister to exempt organisations from any accountability in terms of how the money is spent and in terms of the work that they undertake. That is a real concern. We are going to see a number of amateurs involved who could do more damage than good. For example, I am aware of a minister of religion who at the moment does not provide maintenance for his own children—he is the non-custodial parent—but who offers counselling services. I will be very interested to see whether that particular gentleman is approved. Obviously, I hope he will not be.

One of the problems with what is proposed in this legislation is the time factor for going through the process. If there are not enough people and resources, as has been mentioned by a number of speakers, by the time a couple gets an appointment, has a counselling session and perhaps a follow-up session—and quite often the counsellors, as the honourable member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) so rightly said, think they know best and want the people to come back—it can be quite a lengthy process. The couple may then have to go through the arbitration process, and eventually to court if they cannot agree.

In a time of major upset, trial and turbulence in the life of the children of the marriage, that ongoing, drawn-out process is most destabilising for them. Children need stability; they need to know where they stand. It is highly desirable that these matters be dealt with expeditiously. What this legislation is proposing will, in fact, make the present situation even worse.

In terms of the change of terms to residence orders and contact orders, instead of having custody and access orders, and there are variations of course, that is stated to be a change because people want to get away from the idea of ownership of human beings. I understand the sentiment but it seems to me that whatever terms we use, no matter what label we pin on something, ultimately we are going to have the same effect.

If people want to achieve a particular outcome, whatever label they apply to the name of the process, if they do not get what they want in the end, then they are going to be just as disaffected. We are going to have the same bitterness and problems, potential violence and so on. I do not see name changes as particularly relevant and I think that that is a bit of window-dressing.

The primary dispute resolution proposal obviously is not appropriate in all cases. But as I read the legislation—and I would love to be corrected—all cases are going to be forced through that process. It seems to me that at a time of difficulty and stress for the parties, and for the children in particular, we are going to add extra layers of suffering and difficulties to those parties.

Clearly, where there is an imbalance of power between the separating or divorcing parties, or a change of status or whatever, an arbitration or conciliation system is unworkable. The trouble is that that imbalance of power is often only known to the parties at the beginning of the process. It is the person who is at the lower end of that imbalance of power who is going to suffer the worst, and that is not going to be apparent. Therefore, to force everybody through that process is unacceptable.

Of course, much has been made about the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and the fact that signing that convention means we have to reflect many of the standards in that convention in this legislation. In principle I do not have any problem with that but I do have a problem with some of the current thinking that seems to be gaining credence in our society where children have rights at an increasingly early age. I do not believe—and remember they are children—that they always have the maturity to handle some of those alleged rights at that young age.

Particularly in this field, we often see the situation where one child plays off one parent against the other, or where children will make decisions on limited knowledge and information thinking that they might, as the previous speaker indicated, get their parents back together or something of that sort. It seems to me that children are ill-equipped to make decisions in this area. I am concerned that it seems to have become a convention in the Family Court that 12-year-olds can express a view as to where they wish to live. It seems to me that 12-year-olds are not mature enough, emotionally or in many other ways, to make those sorts of decisions.

And then we come to the question of the parenting plan, a written document between the parents. I wish to ask the question, and I would like to be enlightened by the minister in the fullness of time, about enforcement. It seems to me that a general document can be written but I do not understand how to make sure it is implemented with good intention on a day-to-day basis. There are all sorts of ways of getting around those arrangements and if the document is to be enforceable then it seems to me that it clearly has to be something that is enforced by the courts because there is no other mechanism that I am aware of.

I also have a concern about the provision for constant revision of this parenting plan. Section 62D of the Family Law Act says that a request for counselling can be made at any time about a matter relating to a child. If that really means that—that it can be made at any time before, during or after the process and throughout the child's life—then it seems to me that that is going to make life unworkable and disruptive for the parent who has responsibility for looking after the child, and for the child itself. Frankly, one could spend one's life going back to counselling and arbitration and so on. There has to come a time when a decision is taken in the interests of all.

As I read the legislation, there is to be no testing of the accuracy or truthfulness of what is said in counselling and arbitration, because of the secrecy provisions, of course. Although a subsequent report may go to a court, it cannot subsequently be challenged, because what is said cannot be disclosed. It is interesting to note that Judge Joske from the Family Court was not, as I understand it, supportive in his evidence of some of the changes being proposed—particularly with the access and custody matter I referred to earlier. He used the word `window-dressing' and said that it would have no impact. My experience is that Judge Joske is one of the better judges and shows a great deal of commonsense in the courts. He certainly has a good record. I am concerned that there are perhaps others around who are more concerned with social engineering.

It worries me that there is no certainty about what is likely to happen in this field. If someone goes to a solicitor, he will actually tell you quite openly, `I cannot give you any guidance. I cannot tell you what the norms are; it will depend on which judge we draw on the day, and on how that judge feels when he gets out bed in the morning.' That is the state of family law in this country. Therefore there are matters of standards which the Chief Justice of the Family Court ought to be paying attention to, rather than necessarily restructuring the whole process.

We have flagged some problems over resources. My belief is that if we are to implement legislation of this nature—with extensive counselling, arbitration and all the other resources—it will in fact require considerable resources and training of the people involved. Of course, we need to make those services readily available. It may cut down on some of the legal costs, and there is no doubt that the legal costs involved at the moment are quite shameful. In that sense, it may well advantage people; but the government has to recognise that there will be a cost to the taxpayer. We have also flagged concerns over court registration of parenting plans, and we want that referred to a committee, as was mentioned earlier by my colleague the honourable member for Tangney.

But I would also like to make a couple of other points. Section 64B(7) provides a definition of `made in favour'; in other words, a residence order is made in favour of a person with whom the child is supposed to live. So, whether one is talking about custody and access and all those other words which we are told are now not acceptable because of their hidden connotations, it seems to me that if one makes an order `in favour' it is exactly the same process. The interpretation is that one either wins or loses.

In terms of maintenance, the legislation—as far as I can see—does not address the situation where a parent arranges his or her finances so as to avoid maintenance. As many of us in this place will know, with child support cases, this often applies to self-employed people, where they cannot be got at when they fail in their responsibilities to make appropriate payments. But it also applies where people arrange their income to get a lot of it paid in kind—because, of course, it is net salaries that tend to be taken into account. We see avoidance of responsibilities quite often but, under this system, there is still an entitlement to exercise parental rights via the parenting plan. There should be no rights to parenting plan input and so on without some acceptance of financial responsibility. There ought to be a linkage.

In division 10 of the legislation, the term `child's best interests' is spelt out. I reiterate the point I made earlier that the wishes expressed by the child are a major concern. If one looks at the forces acting on individual children, at the age of 12 of 13 they naturally want to see their parents back together, even if that is totally unrealistic. They are swayed by the loneliness of one parent or the apparent upset of one parent as compared with the other, and they are not in a position, it seems to me, to make what is going to be a judgment in their interests. The judgment ought to be in their interests, yet many children will express a view based on what they believe are the interests of their parents. The report to the court by the family and child counsellor could well be skewed in favour of the dominant parent, because the articulate and powerful tend to know the phrases to use and will get their way.

On the question of separate representation for the child, I think there are a number of failures in the present system. I am aware of a case, for example, where a separate representative was appointed, took weeks and weeks to see the appropriate child, had a 10-minute chat and then came along and delivered a `considered' judgment. That sort of superficial activity which goes on at the present time just does not help the situation and I think has to be changed.

Schedule 2, clause 3, talks about interim arrangements. As I read the legislation, it says that cases now lodged but not heard are to be dealt with `as if this Act is in force', even though the act has not been commenced, and that seems to me to be entirely inappropriate.
I want to refer very briefly to the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) in which he says:

SPEECH.PARA: A significant departure in this bill from the approach recommended by the joint select committee is in the relationship between children and their parents. The committee recommended that the existing terminology of guardianship, custody and access should be retained. That terminology suffers from connotations of proprietorial rights in children, delivering them as the spoils of victory to the parent gaining custody. The government was not convinced of the select committee's view that a change in terminology and approach was unnecessary and sought from the Family Law Council a report on the operation of the Children Act 1989 in the UK. This act has moved away from the existing approach in Australia. I thank the council for its prompt and incisive report which was tabled in this House on 3 May.

But if one actually reads the report—and time will in fact preclude me from going through too many extracts—what it says very clearly is that there is no firm evidence that what has been done has actually improved the situation. People think it is better, there are some warmer feelings there, but there is actually no evidence at all. Yet, based on that, we are proposing to make changes that will affect people's lives for many years to come. That is something that I am not particularly comfortable about.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that the solution for the Chief Justice of the Family Court ought to be not more legislation but administering the present process a lot better, to get cases into court on time. I know a case where in June the judge said that he wanted the arrangements with children sorted out by Christmas ready for the new school year, and yet the court is not even going to have the pre-trial hearing until just before Christmas. The actual hearing will not be until March, in other words, part way through the year, which means the child will almost certainly stay where it is at the moment. That sort of rank administrative inefficiency seems to me to be a major problem, and I do not see that this legislation is going to change that situation.

I think one needs that certainty of advice, as I mentioned before. We need to deal with this use of structuring of income because people need certainty, they need reasonable speed and they need simplicity, and they are going to get the reverse in this particular legislation. In fact, I think it will make the situation worse. I do not see where there are many user views represented in this. It seems to be an awful lot of legal views. Obviously there are men—it is predominantly, but not exclusively, men who tend to be the non-custodial parents—who suffer, and I do not see that this is going to fix their problem. This will create more suffering for women. Children have a rough time and it will make it worse for them. In the second reading speech, the parliamentary secretary said:

SPEECH.PARA: By implementing those recommendations—
of the joint select committee—
which the government accepts, the parliament should go a long way in providing a simpler, fairer and speedier family law justice system for all Australians.

We all know that the present system needs improving but I am not so sure that this will do it. Based on that UK legislation, there is a real question mark: why ignore some of the key recommendations of the joint select committee? Why not deal with the legal concerns over registering of parenting plans? We have taken the view not to oppose, subject to some amendments, and I accept that. However, I believe that the bill is bureaucratic and costly and will cause unnecessary time delays. It will cause further uncertainty for children and place further unfair pressure on the child. The strong, not the right or the just, will prevail, and I think this will do a lot of damage to future generations of Australians. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Deahm Ms M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to speak on the Family Law Reform Bill [No. 2] because it is an extremely important piece of groundbreaking and timely legislation. Having listened to the comments of the member for Aston (Mr Nugent), I feel sorry that he is so pessimistic about it. I happen to think the reverse about most of the things he said. In fact, one or two of the matters he mentioned are wrong, and I will deal with those when I get to the particular part. I have always thought of him as a progressive person, so I am sorry that he is being pessimistic this time. I hope he will find that things turn out differently in reality.
—I hope you are right.

—So do I, although I know I am. The bill is important because it improves the lot of families and, in particular, children. Anybody reading the legislation and seeing what it will bring about cannot fail to appreciate that families, and in particular the children, will be better off.

PARA.TAB: The bill eases access to the law, and that is well in line with the government's present access to justice policy. At this stage I would like to commend the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General, the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan), for the excellent work that they have done in making the law much more accessible to average Australians. Of course, fundamental to that is keeping down the cost of litigation.

This bill is a further step in the 1975 Family Law Act, which was brought in by the then Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Murphy. That was a major change at the time, because the act took the emphasis away from the concept of guilty parties. Those of us who lived through those times saw people sometimes having to set up a situation where they could be proved guilty in order that both parties could get out of a marriage that was unsatisfactory. Taking the emphasis off the concept of guilt and guilty parties was very important. We are learning from that, and this is why we are bringing in this legislation.
I would like to read from the second reading speech of the then Attorney-General, Lionel Murphy, on the Family Law Bill in which he said it was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the most important social reform. It will affect the lives of many people. By introducing a sane, balanced law to deal with family disputes, it is hoped that where marriages do break down—as they undoubtedly will continue to do so under the stresses and strains of modern life—persons will be encouraged to adjust their transition from married life with the minimum of bitterness and animosity. At least under this legislation, persons will not become financially as well as emotionally bankrupt as a result of divorce proceedings.
Quite clearly, that has not worked to the extent that Lionel Murphy would have liked, but it was, as I said, the first step and we are now moving on to the next step.

PARA.TAB: This bill also breaks new ground on the attitudes, rights and responsibilities of parents. I take issue with the member for Aston when he talked about children not being old enough to know what their rights are. The rights of children, as I see it, are well spelt out in the United Nations declaration: the right to food, the right to be clothed, the right to habitation, the right to education and all of those fundamental things. It is not a question of children standing up and saying, `I have got a right to this; I'm going to have it.' They have those fundamental basic rights as dependent people. It is time those roles changed, and this bill goes a long way towards that.

The member for Chifley (Mr Price) talked about our sometimes reacting at the wrong ends of things. This is something that I have long thought about. You reach a certain age, you go to so many weddings and you see so many divorces. I have long thought that our attitudes are wrong: we rejoice when people get married and think it is absolutely wonderful, even though a lot of the times we know that it is a totally unsuitable match. Once that marriage breaks up, it is suddenly everybody's business: the state moves in, particularly when there are children involved, and the law gets involved in the division of property and so on. As the member for Chifley said, we need to do more prior to that eventuality.

Marriage counselling has long been established in this country, as it has in other countries, but generally it is only called into play when there is a problem. I think marriage counselling ought to be part of the preparation for marriage. I know that some people do go through that preparation—perhaps not always with people who are quite wise to human relationships. The member for Aston talked about a clergyman who counselled people when they were contemplating divorce, yet he was not maintaining his own children. Sometimes people in those sorts of roles take on the position of counsellor when they are perhaps not qualified for it. I would like to quote from George Bernard Shaw, a very wise playwright, who says:

SPEECH.PARA: When two people are under the influence of the most violent, most insane, most delusive, and most transient of passions, they are required to swear that they will remain in that excited, abnormal and exhausting condition continuously until death do them part.

That is a very moot point; people are in love when they marry and they very often do not think about their actual compatibility, which is something that goes much deeper than that initial passion of love. So counselling is needed before marriage.

PARA.TAB: A lot has been said about divorce. I hear people from the pulpit, the podium and various places saying, `It is bad; it is absolutely shocking that we have so much divorce.' Obviously, we would all like people to live happily; we would all like children to live in happy families. But to absolutely condemn divorce because it happens is not a good thing. As a child, I felt very strongly at times that I would much rather have been in a single-parent family that was happy than in a two-parent family that was in a constant state of war. But that was not quite as easy in those days. The member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) said that people should stay in marriages—he mentioned that phrase which sent chills up my spine because it is one I heard so much as a child—`for the sake of the children'. A lot of other adults and perhaps children would say, as I have said, that staying together for the sake of the children often has a more harmful effect on children than does splitting up.

Having said that, I do not diminish in any way the feelings that children have when marriages break up. As many of the speakers on this bill have already said, children suffer guilt feelings. They feel they are responsible, they develop resentment to one parent or the other and at times they become the pawns of parents. I do not for one minute say that children from broken marriages suffer no trauma. But we also have to acknowledge that there is a lot of trauma when children are growing up in families which are bitterly unhappy and constantly at war. We need to perhaps take a bit more of a rational attitude. We should not at all rejoice when people get divorced, but we should realise that in some circumstances it is the best thing.

We cannot legislate to make people love each other; we cannot legislate to make people happy; we cannot legislate to make them respect each other. What we can do is legislate for facilities that will enable people to sit down and calmly work through their problems. One of the main thrusts of this bill is a mediation, dispute resolution and counselling facility, where people can sit down and do that.

The member for Aston said that everybody filing for divorce will have to make use of such facilities. That is totally wrong. It is not going to be compulsory at all. It is acknowledged that these kinds of facilities will not suit everybody, particularly in situations where there was a strong imbalance of power and where violence in the family has been prevalent. But for many other cases these facilities will be useful. In fact, they have already been useful. I would like to quote from the government's response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. The government talks about a pilot program of mediation. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: While the evaluation of the pilot program is not completed, results so far are very encouraging. Mediation resolved one of the major issues brought to the table by the partners in 80 per cent of cases and completely resolved all issues in more than 60 per cent of cases. More importantly, 90 per cent of participants using mediation have not started litigation despite the fact that most involved difficult child and property disputes.

I think that speaks very well for the benefits of this kind of facility. I take on board what was said earlier by the member for Aston and a number of other speakers about the need for high quality, well-trained people conducting these mediation and dispute resolution and counselling sessions. It is difficult if you are trying to do it with someone who has a particular bias one way or the other. I have certainly had people come to my office who have felt that a person in mediation in the Family Court has been particularly biased.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of benefits to mediation. It will take the litigation aspect out of many divorces. The parliamentary secretary gave me a copy of a speech he made last night to a group in Adelaide. One of the things he said in that speech was that, as soon as people decide they are going to get a divorce, somebody says to them, `Get a lawyer.' That is the first thing they are told. Mostly, they are given the name of a lawyer who has been recommended by someone else who has been through the same process. So what we want to get away from is those people having the immediate reaction: I must go to the law. I hope that this bill will encourage them to go to mediation facilities instead.

A lot has been said about the cost of the law and the cost of the Family Court. The Family Court budget is approximately $88.5 million—that is the court costs. Then we have the costs to the individuals who go into litigation. I think everybody who has spoken today has said—undoubtedly, the rest of the speakers will all say the same—that they as local members all have a great number of people coming to them about Family Court cases and, of course, child support, which is closely related. Sometimes I find myself acting as an unofficial counsellor without trying to give advice, because I am certainly not qualified to. But people want to come and talk to somebody. Just unburdening themselves of their problem, getting whatever it is off their chest—perhaps it is about a spouse, the Family Court or the Child Support Agency—is a great help.

Mediation will cut costs for people going to court. Of course, a lot of people do not only just go to court and get their judgment on the divorce, the property settlement and the child custody but also very often they have to go back to court because the other partner does not keep his or her side of the deal. Very often this happens with access, which is one of the difficult situations that I have come across. I have seen people in desperate states over access. I say to them, `Your only resolve is to go back to the court,' and they say, `I can't afford to go back to the court.' So, if there is a mechanism whereby those things can be sorted out without involving lawyers, I think it is to be applauded.

It must be taken into account that mediation, counselling or whatever may save some marriages. I know that some people file for divorce and during the process do reach a conciliation situation. So, if these people are being dealt with by trained counsellors, maybe that can help as well.

A lawyer who works in the Family Court has said to me, `Look, we do not want more mediation; everyone who wants to get into that situation does now, and it is only the people who actually hate each other's guts and don't want to speak to each other who go to court.' But I think there is room for more people to go into mediation, even though they may be reluctant to do so to start with and even though the process may be looked on as one of dispute resolution—as some parts of it will be. It should be said to those people, `Look, it is going to be cheaper than you going up there and getting a judge.' As the member for Aston said, different judges give different judgments, so it is the luck of the draw on occasions. It is extremely important that people know they are going to sit down with a qualified person who will make sure that they are not intimidated by the other person to sort out even those very basic things, like who gets the cat, without having to go to law and without it costing a lot of money.

The other thrust of the bill is about children and removes those words `custody' and `access'. Again, the member for Aston said that is a cosmetic change; we are just changing the words. We are changing a lot more than the words. Those words have a firm connotation. Custody does imply ownership—this person is mine. I think that goes back to the old patriarchal times when in fact the wife and the children were the possessions, the property, of the man.

About 60 per cent of divorce suits filed in Australia include children. I think you will agree that their welfare is absolutely paramount. This bill sets out to look at the welfare of the child. I have already talked about the effect that divorce has on children. Of course, it is a very traumatic time for them, as it is for their parents. It is a time when everybody is feeling very raw and vulnerable. We should try to get away from having them sitting in a place that is rather scary, a place they do not go to as a matter of course, to see a judge—particularly, with due respect to the clerks, wearing a wig and a gown—as someone in authority, someone who is totally detached from them, as I think that can be very frightening for children. To be able to take them out of that scenario is very important.

As I have mentioned, I have had a lot of people in my electorate come to me with their problems. Gaining access to the children is one of the hardest problems. I always think of one particular man in this context. When his marriage broke up, his children chose to live with him until the court decided where custody would lie. The mother came and took two of the children. The court finally decided that she would have custody but he would have access. He has been consistently denied access to those children. He cannot get near the house. If he sees them in the school, within five minutes the mother is there creating a fuss and she takes the children away. The children are now absolutely petrified of any contact with their father, even though they love him and want to be with him, because of the reaction of the mother.

The last time he came to see me, I hardly recognised him because his health had deteriorated so much. He was a changed man. He looked at least 10 years older. Parents need to be able to sit down and work through with the other parent a parenting plan to accept joint responsibility. This will not work the same way with every family. This is why I think it is so important that the children be looked on as individuals, rather than property.

The Child Support Agency has been mentioned quite a lot by other speakers. Even though they are separate issues, there is a strong nexus between access to children and child support. I am sure all of us as members have had fathers come to us asking, `Why should I pay child support when I can't get access to my children?' I hope other members explain, as I try to do, that one aspect is not related to the other; that children have a right to be clothed, fed and looked after and that the father is as responsible as the mother for paying for those things. Access is a different issue. But I can well understand how that feeling arises. Those are the people who generally say to me, `I wish that there were still a guilty party in divorce.'

In many cases, the woman has left and obtained custody of the children, and the father has to pay child support. He asks, `Why am I the guilty person?' That is not helped by the tone of some of the letters from the Child Support Agency, which certainly makes the non-custodial parent often feel like a guilty party. We should get rid of all of those things. Again, it will not be easy. I think everyone here has talked about this bill and the whole family law issue being about people. People are different. No two couples will be alike. For some, it will be easy. For some, the war will continue to the grave. The bitterness, and sometimes violence, will still be there. But we are making headway, and I think this bill makes an enormous amount of headway. This bill is also part of the changing and the evolving of the family structure.

I made a speech in this place earlier this year on the family. I talked about a report on the family by Shere Hite. She did research covering thousands of people in various countries. She concluded that those of us who have grown up in patriarchal families have been much damaged and that the family is now evolving. The family is more democratic and a place where there is more equality. This has come about also because more women are working now. Women are not seen as the home slave and role model for the daughters as a wife and mother. The result of that, I think, is that more women assert themselves and more women become more independent within the family. There is inevitably friction because sometimes people have married on the assumption that their roles will be different from what they turn out to be. That is certainly true over the period of the 1960s and 1970s, when there was a great change in the role of women.

I think this bill is a forward step towards making happier families, even though it is looking at families when they are probably at their most unhappy. I hope that it will continue to be reviewed, as the original act has been, and that we keep up with the times. I commend the bill to the House and hope it will receive universal support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forrest Mr J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to speak on the Family Law Reform Bill [No. 2] as someone whose family has been through the trauma of divorce and separation and as someone who has also been involved in the counselling of friends, church colleagues and the like. It is a bit extraordinary that it has taken 20 years since the principal act was first introduced for the amendments that we are debating today to come about. When people talk about family law, they normally automatically think of the Family Law Act. The title `Family Law Act' is really quite misleading. It would be better described as the divorce act because it has little relevance to my personal concept of what family should be.

PARA.TAB: The original bill was supposed to be based on a series of principles, the first of which was that good family law should support, rather than undermine, the stability of marriage. I believe now it is a great tragedy that the central importance of family has been substantially undermined. The Family Law Act is supposed to provide that the court must have regard to a number of basic principles in its determinations, the first of which is the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman, to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life. I have some concerns which I would like to express later about the impacts the Family Law Act has had on the shape, structure and the fabric of our society.

The second principle is to reinforce the need to give the widest possible protection and assistance to the family, recognising it as a valuable unit of society, particularly while it is responsible for the care and education of children. The third principle is the means available for assisting marriage partners whose marriage has deteriorated—it is important to recognise that this does occur—to consider reconciliation or the improvement of their relationship to each other with the interests of the children at heart.

A substantial platform of the Family Law Act is reflected in the replacement of the grounds for divorce based on matrimonial fault with a single ground: the breakdown of marriage—irreconcilable differences—evidenced by over 12 months separation of the parties. Here we are, two decades after the introduction of the Family Law Act, and this platform—the divorce of the parties—remains the only operational basis for the legislation; it has brought the need for the reforms we are debating here today.

The way it has operated in the past can hardly be described as being about families. It seems that nowadays the easy fix divorce provides for a far too easy process for parents to absolve themselves of the responsibility they have to their children. Sadly, much of the emphasis is adult centred. More thought needs to be given to the rights and needs of the children. I am pleased to see that the proposals today go some way towards meeting that need.

The neglect of the support for marriage and family is fairly obvious. Many speakers here today have made reference to that. If government funding is any guide, expenditure on the Family Court alone is four times the expenditure on marriage education and reconciliation counselling. If the cost of welfare benefits for sole parents is added to this, the cost to the community would be $3 billion a year. It is not centred on preventive maintenance or preserving marriage; it is centred on addressing the damage associated when marriages disintegrate.

The neglect of support for marriage and family reflects a failure on the part of the Family Court and governments over the past 20 years. The bias that I have observed against reconciliation is seen in the inadequate funding of counselling services. It is generally accepted that counselling services fulfil an important role in family law matters. The Australian Institute of Family Studies evaluated the effectiveness of marriage counselling in 1986. Its study found a reasonably high satisfaction rate amongst those who had used marriage counselling to improve their relationship and prevent its breakdown.

The study also found that there were many couples who were provided through that counselling process with a basis upon which to separate amicably and so did not need to use lawyers or enter into a litigation process. It has led them into a more responsible way, in the interests of the children, to dissolve their marriage. The study by the Institute of Family Studies concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . public funding of approved marriage counselling organisations is a "very inexpensive way of reducing later costs in litigation, social security benefits and personal and social consequences" . . . funding of marriage counselling results in annual cost-saving to government of around $47.5m in terms of funding for Family Law Courts, Legal Aid and Supporting Parents Benefits.

Despite that finding, lack of resources for counselling has been a problem. Long waiting lists have existed. These have contributed to diminishing the effectiveness of any counselling offered because by the time the counselling is provided the relationship has long since deteriorated.

PARA.TAB: Many organisations not in receipt of any government funding have been carrying out marriage guidance counselling as part of their services. The criterion in the Family Law Act for the funding of marriage counselling is that marriage counselling be carried out as a specific function. A number of social counselling organisations have not qualified for that level of support. At least these reforms recognise the role they play.

The failure to use the provisions of the act to promote reconciliation has been explained by some as a lack of agreement on what a family actually is. I do not think this applies because the Family Court is dealing with parties who are part of an existing marriage. My concerns lie with the emphasis, and I do not accept the principle that people are going to divorce anyway. Effort should be made to preserve marriage as a valuable social and economic unit. It is an emphasis issue, from my perspective.

It is pleasing to see some of these major issues being addressed in the parliament. The bill incorporates provisions designed to strengthen and facilitate the role that counselling, mediation and arbitration can play in family law disputes. That is a good thing. The bill will make voluntary organisations eligible for funding if they provide family and child counselling services, even though their major purpose is not necessarily family and child counselling. This change will enable organisations to engage in non family law counselling without jeopardising approval under the Family Law Act. Consequently, it should also improve the availability of counselling services.

The role of mediation is expanded by the bill and, through it, approved mediation organisations are given access to valuable government funding. I would hope that would be cost effective. The benefits of mediation are obvious in that it provides quick, inexpensive, confidential and non-confrontational advice. Like a lot of alternative dispute resolution procedures, mediation should produce a better outcome which is likely to be more acceptable to all the parties and, therefore, likely to attract greater compliance and a resultant decline in litigation and huge cost to government.

Because the only mechanism in the act as it currently stands to achieve any kind of effective result is support for education and reconciliation services, and because these have been neglected, there has been little practical support for marriage. I hope that this approach is now recognised as being very wrong and naive. Laws made in this place are supposed to mirror social change. It is true, as speakers from both sides have said today, that our society is changing, but I worry about whether the Family Law Act actually represents the changes in law which are engineering this change or whether it follows them or runs parallel with them. It is a very confusing picture.

In this sense, I believe the Family Law Act has increased the momentum with which some very dangerous cultural shifts have occurred which we might all live to regret. Another factor that has operated in the same time frame which has contributed to this cultural shift is the introduction of the supporting parent benefit, which came in at about the same time as the Family Law Act.

The face of the Australian family has changed dramatically since 1975. At that stage, sole parent families comprised about nine per cent of all Australian families whereas today they represent about 13 per cent. Since that time, the actual number of sole parents has risen from 183,000 to 620,000. The overwhelming majority of these families, about 84 per cent, are lone mother families. Each year, about 50,000 children experience the separation of their parents. The number of children born out of wedlock is also increasing.

Whilst these changes demand reflection and discussion of the kind we are having here today, we should be careful not to adopt a jaundiced view on this. It is important to remember the fact that 85 per cent of all families in Australia remain couple families and that the vast majority of children are still growing up in intact two-parent families. Albeit the fabric of that family might be changing, they are still couple families. In other words, although it is said that one in three marriages fails, the majority of particularly married couples—two-thirds or 66 per cent—continue to choose the traditional family as the preferred option for the raising of children.

Nonetheless, the effects of these changes and this culture shift have been considerable. Like many Australians, I have grave misgivings about the long-term impacts on the quality of society that this is creating. Of course I am concerned about the ever increasing number of single parents, who I believe are doing a remarkable job in raising children. It is tough enough for mum and dad to raise teenagers today but people who do it on their own deserve my wholehearted support and deserve enormous credit, and they have it.

However, as a community, we need to ask some serious questions about the potential downsides to our society. It is clear that separation and divorce have contributed to the progression of poverty in Australia.
