Although estimated poverty rates for sole parents have been reduced over the past years by the actions of government through increased family payments, rent assistance and child support payments, sole parents still remain one of the poorest groups in the community. I judge that by representations I receive in my electorate.

The economic cost to Australia in investing in marriage, in investing in sound family, is considerable. Supporting parents benefits rose from $160 million per annum in 1973-74 to $2.9 billion in 1991-92. Therefore, family breakdown costs Australian taxpayers some $3 billion a year, which is equivalent to roughly $600 per household. This is an economic question and, indeed, there is an economic imperative here for government to invest in sound marriage.

Apart from the economic cost to society, there is also the question of longer term psychological harm, particularly to children. In its report Our homeless children, the inquiry into youth homelessness identified family breakdown as a major cause of thousands of street kids leaving home. A number of studies have shown that many children of separated families feel intense rejection. They feel anger and loneliness at the time of divorce and, whilst many overcome these problems over time, other children who seem to be adjusting well initially often develop severe emotional reactions to the divorce as long as a decade later, leading to a range of behaviour problems. Thankfully there are signs of some reassessment of what I would describe as this crisis in our society. It is pleasing to see the parliament responding here today in part.

A major area of dissatisfaction with the principal act has related to the treatment of children. Last year there were 15,485 custody guardianship applications before the Family Court and 14,971 access applications. Whilst property matters formed the largest single category of orders sought from the Family Court last year, matters relating to custody/guardianship, access and child support constituted 43.8 per cent of all the orders sought through the court. These figures are frightening.

The legislation before us addresses the language employed in the Family Law Act. The old language has encouraged adversarial proceedings and promoted the idea that children are the spoils in divorce proceedings. This needs to change. Children are not property; they are individuals. They need far greater consideration than has been received in family law settlements. They are, after all, the Australians of the future, whose wellbeing is an investment in our own future. Thankfully the bill addresses these questions.

The other aspect of the bill that I am encouraged by is the introduction of the concept of `parental responsibility', `parenting plans' and `parenting agreements'. To me this reinforces the concept of responsibility. In a society like we have today, where the emphasis is inordinately placed on rights, it is high time we were all reminded of responsibilities. The bill introduces the concept of parental responsibility and particular rights for the child based on UN conventions. These changes, in addition to other changes in terminology, are designed to promote the idea that the interests of the child are paramount. I am a little concerned that we rely on a United Nations convention to tell us that. We are, after all, a responsible society. We ought to have been able to draw that conclusion ourselves.

I was pleased to see the parliament establish a joint select committee of the House of Representatives and the Senate to inquiry into certain aspects of family law, and in particular in relation to the child support scheme, after a plethora of complaints. The committee received some 7,000 submissions and there were 150,000 attempts by Australians to contact the inquiry on a special telephone hook-up. This ought to indicate the magnitude of the problems that existed.

The idea of the family as a valuable bridge between the individual and society is not new; it is an age-old philosophy. If children are loved by their parents and family members, they too will develop the capacity for love and respect for others and in this way feel good about themselves, respect others, respect authority, and provide a basis for future good citizenship.

I believe that the whole of society rests on the foundation of stability, understanding and social order that family can provide. There ought to be a greater emphasis on preserving that role of the family. It is a trauma to witness what happens to individuals when families have to deal with broken marriages—not just the immediate couple themselves but their siblings, mothers-in-law, fathers-in-law and a whole range of extended family. I have had to watch that happen in my own family. It is high time this legislation was brought to the House. I am thankful for it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Family Law Reform Bill 1994 [No. 2], has four major sections under consideration: counselling organisations and mediation; primary dispute resolution; matters relating to children, including issues of terminology; and domestic violence matters. In response to the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, the government will progressively shift the focus of family law from litigation to a non-adversarial system. Participating partners will be encouraged to develop agreed upon solutions rather than need a judge imposed decision.

PARA.TAB: Divorce is very often an extremely traumatic event in the life of a couple, their children and their families. It is very likely that every member of this House has had some experience of divorce—at least second-hand, through close friends, brothers or sisters. We all know the dreadful pain involved and the high cost of that pain in terms of property, work and children. The imposition of a court settlement, often without choice as the divorcing partners refuse to compromise, is never an excellent development. Mediation to attempt to settle the stress of divorce sufficiently to allow some clear thinking and decision making is always a preferred option. Fortunately, this bill will help make mediation more the norm, and this is to be welcomed.

When the Family Law Act was introduced in 1975, the then Attorney-General, the late Lionel Murphy, said that the system would not inquire into the cause of marital breakdown and that it would be an inexpensive system with simple procedures. Sadly, this vision has not been realised. Today, the system is unarguably overly complex, rigid and narrowly focused on traditional litigation. Because of this situation and the vast unhappiness that follows, the government is making a clear commitment to mediation and will progressively extend the availability of mediation services as rapidly as budgetary priorities allow.

Of course, the success of mediation depends upon its being voluntary and a desire by the parties to actually find a mediated settlement. Mediation would probably not work in some cases where there is family violence or a serious imbalance of power in the relationship. There has been a pilot program involving mediation and, so far, the results are somewhat encouraging. Mediation resolved one of the major issues brought to the table by partners in 80 per cent of cases, and completely resolved all issues in more than 60 per cent of cases. More importantly, 90 per cent of participants using mediation have not started litigation, despite the fact that most of these cases involve difficult child and property disputes. Further evaluation of community mediation services is presently under way.

In the 1994 budget, the Family Court system was given an extra $700,000 to extend its mediation trials. Another $1.4 million was provided for mediation services offered by community organisations, such as the marriage guidance councils, which have recently been renamed Relationships Australia. I recently attended a board meeting of Relationships Australia in New South Wales and I was very impressed by the dedication of this organisation.

Not one of us here doubts the dreadful impact that an unhappy divorce creates. The economic effect is as profound as the social effect. In recognising this, the government will be looking at ways to raise employer awareness of the cost benefits of making counselling services available to employees. It will also consider education programs to raise community awareness of alternative dispute resolution and counselling services. Funding will be considered in the budget, along with other community education proposals on issues such as anger management, effective parenting, communications and dispute resolution skills, and the rights and duties of marriage and parenthood.

I would like to make a special plea to this House to emphasise the duties of marriage. In an age when everyone is aware of his or her real or imagined rights, the reality of duties is often overlooked. We will not be doing anyone any favours by downplaying the duty aspect of marriage. I call on everyone involved in marriage counselling to stress properly—especially before the event—the truth that marriage, family and parenthood require a long list of duties to be fulfilled.

I am sure that many divorces are based on the refusal to face duties. These duties are integral to marriage and cannot be shirked if the marriage is to survive. Young couples should be aware of them from the beginning.

Some 59 per cent of divorces involve children. We are all aware that far too often children are the silent victims of divorce, particularly when they are perceived as the spoils of victory in an adversarial court system.The select committee found that failure to comply with Family Court orders, particularly over custody and access to children, is the major cause of dissatisfaction with the current system.

To overcome this very serious problem, the government is looking at the terms of the United Kingdom's 1989 Children Act. This legislation emphasises the concept of parental responsibilities for the care and development of a child, which responsibilities decline as the child becomes more mature. Parents do not get `custody' and `access'. These are terms which reinforce the idea of ownership and see children as a prize to be won in the divorce struggle.

These approaches are to be removed and parenting plans made available—hopefully, through voluntary mediation. These parenting plans will detail each parent's specific responsibilities. The Australian government has accepted this recommended approach in principle and requests that the Family Law Council examine this and other children's issues, including replacing in the act terminology such as `guardianship' and `custody' which help perpetuate the false notion of the ownership of children.

Child welfare must always be the primary consideration of all court decisions. Children are utterly helpless in a situation of marital breakdown and have not of themselves been a cause of the breakdown. They are entirely innocent parties and they must never be victimised. Due to the problem over many years of divorced persons ignoring Family Court orders, the new legislation strengthens a clearer and stronger awareness of the compliance aspects of the Family Court system.

The government believes that information about enforcement procedures should be annexed to court orders and that the Family Court will also investigate alternatives for the provision of information on enforcement.

The government endorses the Family Court's current simplification project to make it easier for unrepresented people to prepare and present cases. Further to the compliance field, the government will look at amending the Family Law Act to empower the police to take temporary custody of a child at the same time as a warrant is issued for the arrest of a parent unlawfully trying to remove a child from a state or territory. Tougher compliance regulations have been necessary because of a number of attempts at abduction and perjury.

Unfortunately, these tougher compliance measures on their own can never adequately deal with the highly emotional situations where parents cannot or will not agree on the welfare of the child. Inevitably, the child becomes the real victim. That is why dispute resolution and counselling will be a high priority.

One of the saddest reasons for family breakdown is the appalling situation of domestic violence. For a very long time, women, the principal victims of domestic violence, have been unable to receive prompt protection from this horror. The bill before us will give state and territory magistrates and local courts the power to vary Family Court access orders in circumstances of domestic violence. This will enable the victims of domestic violence to obtain unambiguous protection from the courts with one clear, simple and quick application.

The extent of violence in the home—tragically, a major source of marital breakdown—is not always as widely recognised as it should be. Obviously, many other factors contribute to marriage breakdown, but family violence is specifically one of them. I take this opportunity to mention some of the details which have led to so many marriage breakdowns as a result of this violence.

Until there is some serious cultural and psychological change in Australia, I am afraid that violence against women will continue and that Australian marriages will continue to break up. This ongoing social and economic disaster will then continue to require further changes to family law. It is a vicious cycle that just keeps going lower and lower.

What is exactly meant by violence against women? The National Committee on Violence Against Women defined it as behaviour adopted by the man to control his victim which results in physical, sexual and/or psychological damage, forced social isolation or economic deprivation or any behaviour that leaves a woman living in fear. Aside from the more culturally recognised physical and emotional abuse, such behaviours include the destruction of property, threats, harassment and ridicule. The key element in these circumstances is the desire on the part of the man to have control and power.

We will probably never know the actual number of women who are the target of a partner's violent behaviour. The shame and isolation that continue to be an intricate aspect of domestic violence in our culture act to maintain the secrecy for many of the victims.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—The Minister for Industrial Relations and the Minister for Transport will be absent from question time today on government business. The Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations and the Special Minister of State, Mr Johns, is available to answer questions today on behalf of Mr Brereton. Mr Brereton will be available to answer questions tomorrow.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does the minister agree with the first assistant secretary to the department, Mr Fisher, that Australian business representatives are `appalling, incompetently briefed, a pushover for the Germans and Japanese to deal with and sometimes not even rational'. If not, are you or Senator Evans going to apologise to the business community at large and in particular to those individuals slandered by Mr Fisher's memo? What steps is the government going to take to ensure that your department does give business an unbiased hearing?

—The way in which the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade assists business and businessmen attempting to do business overseas is now a matter of record. In the days in which the present Leader of the Opposition and I used to work for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the idea that diplomats should assist businessmen in their dealings overseas was regarded as rather grubby and beneath the dignity of the people on the cocktail circuit—
—What Fisher had to say was pretty grubby. Are you going to apologise or not?
—Order! The member for Flinders has asked his question. He might do the minister the courtesy of listening to the answer.

—That has changed enormously. In that time the performance of our diplomats overseas in assisting businesses has been extremely effective. One can see that in the way in which our businessmen overseas have been successful in pursuing contracts and business—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—And women.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since you mention the question of businesswomen—
—I raise a point of order on relevance, Mr Speaker. The business community has effectively been slandered by a memo from his department.
—There is no point of order. You are debating the issue now.
—I ask whether there is an apology. It is as simple as that.

—There is no point of order. The honourable member for Flinders knows that a point of order has to be raised under the standing orders and not be debated. With respect to the issue that he did come to the microphone and raise, the minister is being relevant and has the call. His cause would be helped if people did not interject and if he did not respond to them.
—I will respond to the interjection which came from a number of quarters across the way about businesswomen. Recently, a major seminar was organised in Singapore which—

—The Leader of the Opposition will remain quiet. The minister has the call.

—It does seem to me that perhaps the opposition frontbench is trying to draw attention away from its own inadequacies by this barrage of interjections. The fact is that nowadays the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, as a department, is extremely solicitous and assiduous in pursuing the interests of businessmen overseas. One sees that in the way in which our export figures have been improving, particularly in South-East Asia and in the areas of elaborately transformed manufactures. If we compare that with the days in which these gentlemen were in office, we see that our export performance then was appalling, that the way in which the—

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145. The question asked by the honourable member for Flinders directly related to a particular letter which contained specific slanders against the generality of Australian businessmen and businesswomen. The minister is rabbiting on about seminars and ancient history, and you ought to bring him back to the subject.

—There is no point of order. The member for Bennelong has rightly pointed out that the minister was asked a question about the attitudes of businessmen and a specific case; I accept that. The minister is answering the question with regard to businessmen and under the—
—No he is not. Not by any stretch of the imagination.

—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition might be careful and listen to what I am saying before he says things like that which I might take some offence at. I suggest that if you read House of Representatives Practice relating to the specific matter of answers of ministers—which I have remarked on before—you will have a better understanding. —I do not have all that much else to add. On the specific matter of some leaked memo from an official of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, I am stating the government's policy. What officials may state in private memoranda is not something that I care to comment on. Finally, let me say that the level of testosterone on the opposition front bench seems to be in inverse relation to its standing in the opinion polls.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the hardship being experienced by many rural Australians, including those within my electorate of Capricornia, because of the terrible drought. Can the minister advise the House of progress in implementing drought relief payment measures to assist farm families suffering because of the drought?

—I thank the honourable member for her question and note the very considerable concern she has shown for farmers affected by the drought, particularly those within her electorate. I inform the House that last week I visited a number of severely drought affected areas in New South Wales and Queensland to see how we were going by way of implementation of the drought relief payment. I look forward this Friday to visiting the honourable member's electorate to see how things are going in that neck of the woods.

PARA.TAB: The drought relief payment was part of the overall package of drought relief measures that was announced by the government on 21 September. My department has the responsibility of implementing the drought relief payment. It is being paid at the jobsearch rate with the associated family payments that go with that. So, typically, a couple with two children between the ages of 13 and 15 should be entitled to a maximum of $380 a week.

The other key features of the payment, as well as its being paid at the jobsearch allowance rate, are the exclusion of farm assets such as farm machinery, livestock, et cetera; the fact that there is no activity test and that, by contrast with some other payments to drought affected farmers, it is not repayable. The payment is back payable to 1 October. Farmers who wish to apply need to get in contact with their rural adjustment scheme authority and get a certificate stating that they are in exceptional circumstances due to drought.

As of today, around 10,000 such certificates have been issued in the relevant areas of New South Wales and Queensland. The Department of Social Security has appointed drought contact officers throughout the affected areas in order to assist farmers to go through the mechanics of completing the forms. We have given considerable thought to appropriate methodologies for estimating income for the application of the incomes test that applies. At this point significantly fewer claims than certificates have been received, but the numbers of applications for the payment are rising rapidly. Again, as of today, there have been 4,216 claims received and they are continuing to come in at a rate of about 200 a day.

There is a bit of concern in my department that some accountants may be slow in lodging. There is obviously a concern that if we get a rush of them before Christmas there could be some processing delays. I would like to take this opportunity to urge people who think they are eligible for this payment to get their applications in. The last thing we need is a last-minute rush before Christmas. In getting their applications in, they ought to make sure that they do not take too much notice of the misleading National Party rhetoric about this payment. I would urge all farmers who are in the exceptional circumstances area and who think they might be eligible to get their applications in.

As of today, nearly 2,000 farm families are receiving the payment, and the number receiving the payment is increasing by around 200 a day. Some 91 per cent of those who have applied for the payment have done so successfully, and are receiving it. On the whole—considering this is a new payment dealing with a client group that many social security officers may not have had a lot of contact with, including some farmers whose financial affairs might be quite complex—all departments involved, the Department of Social Security and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy as well as the other authorities, have done a very good job of getting this due payment in place, on balance, pretty quickly.

I look forward to visiting the honourable member's electorate on Friday this week. It is most important, with a program like this, that we see how it is being implemented on the ground and that we address the problems and concerns that are emerging. I have taken careful note of those that have emerged thus far. These visits have been a very valuable exercise.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade, and is supplemental to the question asked by the honourable member for Flinders. Do you concur, if you do not apologise, with the views expressed in the minute written not by some official but by a person who is ranked among the third most senior officials within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr W.N. Fisher, to the department secretary, Mr Michael Costello, that Mount Isa Mines Ltd salesmen are `incompetently briefed and that they must be pushovers for the Germans and Japanese to deal with'? Do you also concur that some of the interventions by former and current presidents of the National Farmers Federation—Messrs Graham Blight and Donald McGauchie—and the Managing Director of MIM, Mr Norman Fussell, `were pretty appalling'? Are these comments really just akin to those by the former Australian Ambassador to Cambodia, Mr J.S. Holloway, when he criticised the integrity and character of senior members of the Cambodian government, and just another example of the arrogance, self-righteousness and, dare I say it, the level of testosterone of a Labor government increasingly remote from the deep social and economic concerns of the average Australian, particularly in the drought stressed hinterland?

—I am not sure how much time I am going to have to answer this rather lengthy question. The article referred to came out of a meeting of the Trade Policy Advisory Council, at which I was not present. I was present at the subsequent meeting. Those meetings reflect a very considerable degree of consultation between the business community, the Australian government and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I am advised by the Minister for Trade that he expressed a concern about developments in the climate change debate and access to Europe for Australian coal, which were the catalyst for a very fruitful subsequent meeting between officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and representatives of the Australian coal industry.

PARA.TAB: At the last meeting of the Trade Policy Advisory Council, at which the business figures mentioned by the right honourable member were present, this issue was not pursued. Indeed, I found the atmosphere extremely constructive and extremely useful. The National Farmers Federation, in particular, was happily approbatory of the actions that the government was taking. That included Graham Blight, who certainly complimented the government on the contributions it had made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you agree with the memo or not?
—I warn the member for Flinders.

—During the very important Uruguay Round, our consultations with business were similarly helpful and fruitful. We on the government side take this process of consultations very seriously. I remember being a servant of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in the days when the right honourable member was a minister in the government which shamefully neglected our trading interests in Europe. That was always the case. Indeed, the present Leader of the Opposition was an officer in Brussels. That government's contribution to this was to arrive too late for meetings and make no input of a relevant kind but to throw up its hands and say that Australia was going to lose out every time. It is a very different atmosphere nowadays. The proof of that pudding is in the eating; it is in the export performance of Australia.
—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Why is the government planning to introduce racial hatred legislation?

—Obviously Australia has a very good record on human rights, and we have a very proud record of racial harmony and social tolerance in this community. However, I do not think anyone in this House or in the broader community would pretend that Australians from a variety of backgrounds have not suffered from time to time, and do not continue to suffer, discrimination in our community and have not been the victims of extreme racist behaviour. This was recognised as early as 20 years ago when this parliament enacted the Racial Discrimination Act. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission shortly followed the enactment of that legislation. Over the years we have had other pieces of human rights legislation.

PARA.TAB: In recent years there have been three major federal inquiries which have focused on the existence of racial violence and racial vilification in this community: the Law Reform Commission's report into multiculturalism and the law; the royal commission into black deaths in custody; and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's report into racist violence. All three of those reports identified a deficiency in Australia's human rights regime and recommended that the Racial Discrimination Act should be amended so that complaints of racist behaviour could be made and conciliated and subjected to the processes of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The inquiry into racist violence also recommended that there be some behaviour which should be subjected to the provisions of the criminal law.

These conclusions have been shared by a number of state governments in this country, notably, the government of Nick Greiner in New South Wales in 1989 and the governments of Western Australia, Queensland and the Australian Capital Territory. All these parliaments have passed legislation which, to some extent, either through their criminal laws or through their civil provisions of their human rights bodies, have established regimes which allow racist violence and incitement of racial hatred to be covered by the law.

In recent times—fortunately, these are not common occurrences but, unfortunately, they are not unknown—we have seen in Western Australia, in South Australia and I think most recently in Melbourne occasions of racially based violence in our society. It is to address that problem that the government is proposing to this parliament that there should be specific legislation to deal with the issue of incitement of racially based violence and the threats which flow from that. It has also been recommended to the parliament that the Racial Discrimination Act be amended to allow civil procedures in relation to this type of behaviour.

These are difficult issues. People can obviously come to different conclusions as to how this problem should be best addressed. However, I do believe that, while confronting racism, arguing about it and education on it are very much part of the proper response—indeed, that is fundamentally the role of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and the Race Discrimination Commissioner—there is some conduct that is so damaging in its effect that there needs to be specific legislation and, in some instances, criminal law legislation to deal with it. It will be my intention to introduce this legislation into the House on Thursday. I look forward to there being a sensitive and sensible debate in this chamber and in the Senate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations. Does the minister agree with his colleague the member for Eden-Monaro that, as Australia is already a very tolerant society, the planned racial vilification bill is unnecessary, or does he dissociate himself from his own statement in June that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the country is carved up into various subgroups—migrants, blacks, women, gays—but the majority don't associate with any of these groups and there is a point at which the vast majority say "I have had enough, society is reasonably fair, now we can get back to basics".
I ask the minister whether he believes that Australia is at that point when the vast majority have had enough; and will he remain faithful to his feelings and oppose the bill?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have stated publicly, I will support the bill.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We will see whether you do. I have engaged debate within the caucus and made my views known. The caucus has voted, I accept its vote, and I will vote according to that in this House.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. The government has made the point that the racial hatred legislation has been on the statute books, both in some Australian states and other common law countries for a number of years. Could the Attorney-General inform the House of the experience of racial hatred legislation in those jurisdictions and, in particular, whether those laws have unduly limited free speech?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 144, in particular part (c) that refers to questions that should not ask a minister for legal opinion. At least part of that question to the Attorney-General sought from him a legal opinion as to the effect and the way in which laws in states work. That question is quite clearly asking for a legal opinion and I ask for it to be ruled out of order.

—I think the question was sufficiently broad to enable the Attorney-General to respond in respect of the general area. However, as he is the Attorney-General, I am sure that he would be aware of the particular provision about giving a legal opinion and will adhere to it.
—And everything he says will be relevant.
—I do not and will not know until he gives his answer.

—I can assure you, Mr Speaker, it will be totally relevant. As the honourable member pointed out, there are a number of Australian states and, indeed, a number of countries which have enacted racial hatred legislation. I suppose the most extensive form of that legislation currently existing in Australia is in the state of New South Wales. It was introduced by the Greiner-Murray government in 1989.

PARA.TAB: Since the enactment of that legislation, there have been some 448 complaints of racial vilification made to the New South Wales anti-discrimination board. There have been no prosecutions under the criminal provisions. However, I understand that three investigations did proceed to a fairly advanced stage but did not proceed on the basis of the evidence at hand.

The important point I think to be made from that is that the existence of the law, and particularly the civil provisions, has enabled the anti-discrimination authority in New South Wales to successfully deal with a large number of complaints over the years and, in the vast majority of cases, to achieve a satisfactory outcome.

In relation to free speech, I do not know whether anyone could seriously advance that in the last five years the citizens of New South Wales have been somehow stifled in the expression of their views or ideas. I am not aware of any talkback radio host having been taken off the air in New South Wales in the last five years. I am not aware of any newspapers having been shut down, or articles having been edited, or anything of that sort having occurred. I do not believe that anyone could seriously contend that controversial—or even what could be regarded as very unpopular or extreme—views by the vast majority of the community have in any ways been stifled in the state of New South Wales.

I suppose the country which Australia would most look to as having a similar legal system and being similar in terms of the demographics and backgrounds of its people is New Zealand. New Zealand has had legislation of this type on its statute books since 1971. In that time many hundreds of complaints have been dealt with by the anti-discrimination authorities in New Zealand. Exactly the same conclusion can be made about the enjoyment of free speech within New Zealand.

The issue of free speech is a sensitive one, and any proposal which is put before this parliament or any parliament which in some ways infringes, limits or restricts the free expression of ideas needs to be treated with great caution. That is the approach which the government has taken both in deciding to proceed with legislation in this area and in the drafting of that legislation. It is not uncommon for there to be laws which in some form restrict free expression. Obviously, in terms of the criminal law the commission of counselling someone to commit an offence is a restriction on the expression of that person. The offence of soliciting is very much a restriction on free speech. Clearly, our entire censorship regime, including our restriction on child pornography, is a restriction on expression in that sense. Provisions in the Trade Practices Act dealing with false and misleading advertising or false and misleading representations are restrictions on people expressing themselves in that way.

At the end of the day, a balance has to be drawn between the importance of free speech and the overall public good or public interest which could be served in its restriction. It is my conclusion, and that of the cabinet and caucus, that laws in the area of racial hatred, on that balance, justify introduction and support by the parliament. That is obviously a position also agreed upon by the governments and parliaments of New Zealand, New South Wales, Western Australia, the ACT, a number of states in the United States of America, Great Britain, Canada and other countries which also have these laws and indeed have had them in place for many years.

There will not be, and nor should there be, any restriction on free expression of media reporting on popular or extreme views. That is the proper role of the media, and that particular role is recognised and supported by the legislation that we will be advancing to the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Attorney-General. I refer the minister to his proposed racial hatred act 1994 and, in particular, to part 3 which amends the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. If I were seated in a crowded restaurant dining with my wife and another patron came up to my table and in a loud voice said, `I'm going to bash you for staring at my wife, you bloody yank. Why don't you go back with all the rest of the septic tanks where you belong?' and I were offended—
—Good idea.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for La Trobe has the call. We do not often get backbenchers with a chance. Those on my right will also cease interjecting.

PARA.TAB: Mr Leo McLeay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Watson!

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. If you can quieten down that rabble over there, I will get on with it. If I were offended, insulted, humiliated and intimidated by that act, would it be the intention of your legislation that the person who uttered those words be prosecuted for his speech?

—I am very conscious of the fact that I am not supposed to give legal opinions, and that does somewhat constrain how I should answer the question. But I will attempt to answer it without contravening the particular standing order. In terms of prosecution, the answer to that would be no, unless you were individually threatening someone, and that, of course, could be an offence under the law of the state in which the offence was committed. If it was an offence based on race, it may fall within the particular provisions of this bill. It certainly would not be the incitement of racial hatred under the law.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question has been asked and the Attorney is answering.

—In relation to your first point about civil proceedings, whether you could take an action to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the potential is there for you to take such an action. The human rights commission receives many complaints each year. It also very speedily deals with vexatious and unmeritorious complaints and removes them. No doubt it would take your complaint seriously and would weigh it up on its merits.

PARA.TAB: But it must be understood that that is not a criminal proceeding; that is a civil proceeding which is no different from, say, a proceeding against discrimination under the Sex Discrimination Act or discrimination under the Disability Discrimination Act or a claim of, say, sexual harassment under the Sex Discrimination Act. We have a longstanding way of dealing with these matters and a good history of dealing with them through the human rights commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Minister, you would be aware of comments made in recent media reports, most notably on the Sunday program, where it has been implied that the Repatriation Commission's recent decision to accept an association between herbicides used in Vietnam and some forms of cancer has some relevance to the children of Vietnam veterans who suffer from birth defects. With that in mind, can you inform the House whether any connection could be made between the Repatriation Commission's decision on herbicides and service in Vietnam and the claims for compensation for birth defects in the children of Vietnam veterans?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. Naturally, I think everybody in this House would feel very sympathetic towards any Vietnam veteran who has children born with abnormalities. But when I announced the Repatriation Commission's decision to extend repatriation benefits to Vietnam veterans suffering from a range of five extra cancers and who could prove exposure to herbicides, I did make it very clear in this House in answer to a question that that did not extend to such things as birth defects.

PARA.TAB: The Sunday program did a story on it, I think the weekend before last, in which it intimated that some of the hopes and expectations of Vietnam veterans with children born with abnormalities could have been cruelly raised as a result of the decision. I want to put the record straight. Not only did I make that clear in this House but, during subsequent media appearances after that decision, even members of the Vietnam Veterans Association made it very clear that they were well aware that the decision did not, in any shape or form, extend to birth defects.

Having said that, the position quite clearly is that, under the terms of a generous repatriation system where veterans are given the benefit of the doubt, the onus of proof is on the reasonable hypothesis test. If, as I understand, a Vietnam veteran intends to take the matter to a civil court of law, the standard of proof will be vastly different. There will not be that generous nature and it will be a civil case where the standard of proof is much more severe.

As far as I am concerned, it would be very difficult for any Vietnam veterans to in any way progress what has happened here in terms of the extension of sufficient evidence to help them in a case for damages at common law. I want to make that very clear. At no stage was it ever envisaged that the decision to simply extend repatriation benefits to five extra cancers was ever going to extend to birth defects.

TALK.START.PARA: —A welcome decision in itself.
—Thank you. I hope that after today there will be no media reports that might suggest that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Why does the minister continue to preside over a family allowance supplement payment policy which is discriminatory against blended families? A payment of $64.20 per fortnight is normally made to families with one child under 13 years if the combined income threshold for the year is less than $24,689. Why is it that a one-child blended family in my electorate with an income of only $18,000 and an additional child support payment of $2,559 receives only $32.50 family allowance supplement when their total family income is well below the threshold? Why does the minister persist with such discriminatory policy against Australian families?

—I would have to look at the specific circumstances operating in that case. If it is a so-called blended family there may be maintenance being received which could be affecting the entitlement to an additional family payment. There is no discrimination in the government's policy towards blended families. If the honourable member wants me to look at the specific facts relating to that case, I will certainly undertake to do so.

—My question is directed to the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations and the Special Minister of State and concerns the Industry Commission's report on workers compensation. What action is the government taking to progress greater national uniformity and consistency in the area of workers compensation?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. The Commonwealth is greatly interested in national consistency in workers compensation. People will be aware that currently the system is administered by the states and territories and the Commonwealth with respect to its own workers. That has led to a situation where there is no single national market in workers compensation and, therefore, no competition. So any competition in, if you like, best practice in workers compensation occurs between states rather than between enterprises.

PARA.TAB: Rather than employers competing on safety and seeking the best occupational health and safety record for their employees, as well as for the employers, we have a situation where governments are competing unnecessarily to bid for employers who may be running very poor workers compensation schemes. This has resulted in very inconsistent benefits and practices between the states. For instance, there could be dramatic differences between premiums for firms with identical safety records but operating in different states. For example, the premium in housing construction in Victoria is just 2.7 per cent but in Western Australia it is 8.1 per cent. The level of compensation available to injured workers suffering identical injuries will vary widely between states. The Leader of the Opposition does not care a hoot about injured workers, does he? He is a very ignorant man.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The minister might continue his answer.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Get on with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will. This has to do with competition and I thought the opposition might be interested in it. The level of compensation available to injured workers suffering identical injuries will vary widely between states. For instance, the statutory death benefit in New South Wales is $223,000, but here in the ACT it is just $87,000. In Tasmania the benefit for the loss of an arm is $50,000, but in Western Australia it is $90,000.

PARA.TAB: These are enormous inconsistencies. For instance, after six months on compensation in one state an injured employee receives cash in hand benefits which may be barely little than social security payments, but in another state injured employees could receive the equivalent of their take-home wages. In one state, the maximum no-fault payout that workers suffering serious long-term injuries can receive is $72,000, which may be as little as two years salary to them, but in other jurisdictions, in other states, it is possible that the needs of those workers may be met for the rest of their working lives.

There is also an enormous difference in the competition between states as to how much weight the employer carries of these costs as opposed to the community and the employee. For instance, the percentage of costs borne by the community in Victoria—which is either by government welfare programs or social security programs—or the worker is 44 per cent as opposed to 56 per cent for employers. In stark contrast, the percentage borne by the community in South Australia is just nine per cent as opposed to 91 per cent for employers.

I make the plea currently that the states and the territories run workers compensation. The Commonwealth has made an offer to the states to negotiate national consistency so there would be no invidious competition for states to lower the standard of workers compensation. But it seems that the Commonwealth has an interest in establishing a national workers compensation system that is based on competition between firms and not states so that we can have some minimum acceptable national standards which are acceptable to all players. Currently, I am progressing talks between both employers and unions on a sectoral basis to see whether they can come up with nationally consistent schemes for workers compensation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Attorney-General. Could he please advise the House on progress made with the states on the introduction of relevant legislation relating to outlawing female genital mutilation? What plans are being made for the appropriate educational programs?

—I thank the honourable member for her question and acknowledge her very strong interest in this subject over some time in this House. The question of specific laws dealing with female genital mutilation was discussed at the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in Melbourne last week. I went there with a Commonwealth position that there should be national laws: laws in all parts of the country—not necessarily federal laws—dealing with the specific outlawing of female genital mutilation.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to tell the House that the attitude of the state attorneys was, on the whole, very positive to the development of such laws. I believe that only the state of Western Australia was somewhat equivocal about the idea of there being specific laws dealing with female genital mutilation. I am still hopeful that the government of Western Australia, seeing that all other Australian jurisdictions were moving down this path, may accept the spirit in which this matter is being progressed, change its position and adopt the Commonwealth's position. In fairness to Mrs Edwardes, the Western Australian Attorney-General, she did indicate a willingness on behalf of herself and the Western Australian government to look again at the issue in light of the views being expressed by her fellow attorneys.

In relation to the question of education, I should stress that the Commonwealth view—and, again, I think it is shared by the states—is that education is the appropriate means to respond to this issue and that legislation should come into being either hand in hand with an appropriate education program or some time after an education program is in place.

My colleague the Minister for Health, Dr Lawrence, will have responsibility for the development of an education program. This again will be raised in conjunction with the states. The Commonwealth will be contributing funds to the development and the promotion of the program, which will be directed at the specific communities that need advice and assistance in this area. To help the member further and for her information I will get her more specific details about the education program and the attitude of each of the states, as expressed at the standing committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Social Security and concerns income distribution. Is there any validity in the claims that Australia's income distribution is one of the most unequal in the world?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Such claims are rubbish. I will come to that in a moment. I might make a few general comments about income distribution throughout the developed world. A number of studies show that throughout the developed world over the 1980s there was a widening of earnings differentials. Explanations of that generally end up going back to issues such as the globalisation of the world economy, the impact of technology and the impact of structural change on the labour market. What we know from international studies is that the countries that have experienced the most severe opening up of income differentials have been those countries that have comprehensively deregulated their labour markets. That is very clear. The United Kingdom is the country among developed countries that has experienced the greatest widening of income differentials.

PARA.TAB: Who in this chamber wants to undertake a wholesale deregulation of the labour market and the stripping away of the award minima? They do. For them to come in here and talk about growing inequality is sheer hypocrisy. If you look at the specific policies of the coalition to slash social expenditures and the proposals we have seen come from that side of politics on families, whether it is income splitting, Tony Abbott's proposals to have, in effect, a single rate of payment to all families based on the number of children or the policies relating to family assistance, the one thing these policies have in common is their extreme regressivity. Without exception, every proposal and suggestion from that side of the House has made the position of those on low incomes worse relative to those higher up the tree.

What this government did over the 1980s—and this has been confirmed by a number of studies—was to counteract that underlying trend to greater earnings differentials through government policy through an efficiently and effectively targeted social security system, with major real increases in payments directed to those at the bottom, particularly increases in family payments and rent assistance. If you look at the social security payment structure measured against any poverty line, the outcome is absolutely unambiguous. Compared to when we came to office, things have improved substantially, both in real terms and particularly against any of the poverty lines in current use, whereas under the coalition things actually went backwards for people at the bottom of the income scale.

In an overall assessment of this country's income distribution compared to the rest of the world, responsible commentators have emphasised that you cannot just look at cash incomes; you have to look at the social wage, at the benefits people derive from assets, at the various services that people are able to access—free medical care, education and so forth. If you are making international comparisons, you have to have comparable statistics. That is not a trivial matter.

A major study has been undertaken over the past few years called the Luxembourg income study, which is a comparative study of 14 developed countries and in which an attempt has been systematically made to achieve statistics which are comparable between the various countries concerned. Studies that have taken advantage of that and looked at the whole array of factors that determine people's wellbeing do not portray the sort of picture the opposition has portrayed. The most up-to-date and comprehensive study of living standards that we have is one by Sue Richardson and Peter Travers called `Living decently', which was published last year. What was their conclusion? I will read what they conclude about the situation:

ANSWER.PARA: At the end of the 1980s most Australians were indeed living decently. Material affluence was at an all-time high. Australia was still ranked around the middle of the dozen most equal countries in the world.
This is in terms of inequality—
Australia is a world leader when it comes to social mobility. Our positive picture—

TALK.START.PARA: —Wind up.
—I know you do not like this stuff but I am going to persist anyway.

ANSWER.PARA: Our positive picture of high levels of affluence and of relative equality is at variance with the gloom and doom that is typical of many editorial writers and political social commentators.
The fact is that that is the situation that prevails here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. On 10 May, you issued an admonition to all ministers regarding the length of their answers. I invite you to apply that admonition in this case and I point out that the inequality is there for all to see. Australia is number two in the ranking of the Economist—
—Now you are debating the point. You have raised a point of order and I thank you for drawing it to the attention of the House.
—I reiterate: the studies that actually seek to systematically achieve comparability of statistics—
—You've seen this, have you?
—Yes, I have, and my point stands.
—How does it stand?
—Well, my point stands.

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The minister will conclude his answer and not respond to interjections.

—My point stands absolutely that those statistics in there do not seek to take into account the factors—the social wage changes, the tax changes and the various changes that are relevant. Such studies that do seek to take those factors into account lead to the conclusion which I just read out. I stand by that. But, again, the key point is—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. This minister is deliberately flouting your ruling, which was that he sit down.
—There is no point of order. The minister is concluding.

—In conclusion, I reiterate: if the member for Mayo read that article, he would see it confirms that countries that have experienced the greatest increase in inequality are those that have gone down the wholesale deregulatory route in the labour market. That is the key factor that differentiates those countries that have had the worst increases in inequality from the others. That is the reality and that is the impact of your policies—to make things vastly worse in terms of inequality than the current situation.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. Can the minister confirm whether or not sales tax of 22 per cent is to apply to signs, T-shirts and other equipment associated with the voluntary community crime prevention program, neighbourhood watch? If so, how does the government reconcile this with the encouragement of voluntary law and order support mechanisms? Is it not a bureaucratic insult to tens of thousands of community-minded Australians who give freely of their time and effort to reduce crime and lessen the otherwise heavy burden on government policing outlays?

—I certainly think that the neighbourhood watch scheme is an excellent service. It operates in all states now and in most neighbourhoods. It does a very good job indeed and most public officials have given every assistance to its effective operation. I shall, as a result of that question, refer the matter to the Treasurer, who has responsibility for sales tax matters, and get him to give the member a response.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for you, Mr Speaker. It concerns security of the non-public areas of Parliament House. A couple of times over the last several days, I have had occasion to intercept people wandering around the non-public areas. By wandering, I mean aimlessly, without direction and, indeed, not knowing where they were going.

PARA.TAB: Government members—Liberal Party members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those on my right! This is a very serious matter.

—As two of these individuals were in close proximity to your quarters, Mr Speaker, I ask: are you happy with the current state of affairs in allowing people into the non-public areas of this parliament and, if you are not happy, will you take it on board and advise this House of the outcome?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. It is not the first time that it has been raised with me in recent days in respect of people being in the proximity of non-public areas of this building and, when approached, having unaccompanied passes. There seems to be developing a tendency for some members and senators to be prepared to allow people to be signed into this place without taking the appropriate supervisory responsibility that goes with that.

PARA.TAB: I say to all members of this place—I am sure the President of the Senate will remind his colleagues—that if people are signed in with unaccompanied passes, a responsibility goes with that. That responsibility goes to the fact that this is a secure environment.
