TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The damage to Australia's international standing and the Australian tourist industry by the Prime Minister's failure to honour the Australia/New Zealand Open Skies Air Agreement.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —This Sunday, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) jets off to Jakarta where he is going to attend the summit of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Forum, APEC. As the Prime Minister has done during his previous overseas visits to APEC—and a lot of us would give him some credit for what he has done to promote free trade—he will again be promoting that concept and no doubt will be bleating on how well Australia has done. Yet in this last fortnight we have seen one of the most unbelievable backdowns by a government on an international agreement, namely, the Australia-New Zealand open skies policy for our aviation services.

PARA.TAB: I raise this issue today as a matter of urgency because the damage that has been done to this country and to the tourist industry is still to be realised. It is quite interesting that, at a time when the Asian countries within their own fora are talking about opening up competition and particularly with the Organisation of Asian Airlines talking about its free skies arrangement around Asia—and here is Australia allegedly leading the way and berating the OAA into going into a free market—what do we have? We have Australia reneging on an international agreement.

It is quite interesting that in the Asian Wall Street Journal, which is dated 10 November 1994, this issue has already been raised. Part of the commentary says that Australia has been sending a very negative message to Australia's APEC partners. This article suggests that Australia's commitment to regional trade liberalisation is rhetorical rather than real. That might be strictly correct.

Let us go back to the very origins of the open skies policy in February 1992 when the Prime Minister issued his One Nation package. The one thing that was highlighted and trumpeted by this government as being a major reform was the fact that it was promoting the concept of an open skies policy between Australia and New Zealand. It is quite fascinating to go back to the documents at that time and read some of the commentaries in the newspapers. A number of commentators thought that with the Prime Minister in his ascendancy there was to be a new broom in the relationship between the government and Ansett. Stories were abounding at that time that one of the prime reasons that this was introduced was that the government felt no allegiance to the old management of Ansett, that it did not have any loyalties to Ansett and that it was not there to protect Ansett. How things have changed now that Sir Peter Abeles has left Ansett.

In actual fact, I believe the issue that we are facing at the moment is about not only promoting the Qantas privatisation but also protecting Ansett. As the Prime Minister has admitted in a number of public statements, he is all about trying to get a merger between Ansett and Air New Zealand. We know the results of that. Air New Zealand has looked at the books and decided that it is all too hard. It will not cripple itself at this stage by having to take over a piece of Ansett.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who benefits?

—I will leave that to your imagination. You would not need much imagination to work out that there is a certain shareholding in the Ansett organisation that is very close to this government. This whole issue has been put on hold; this whole issue has been frozen. We are going to see some ramifications from that in Australia's growth and in the growth of the Australian tourist industry.

PARA.TAB: We are not here as apologists for Air New Zealand; we are here to highlight the fact that Australia's standing within the Asian community is going to be downgraded by this particular action. We are not denying that Air New Zealand has had some beyond rights and we are not denying that it is going to pick up some new rights, but the concept of the open skies arrangement between Australia and New Zealand is such that we had the capacity to lead the world in competition.

If we go back to the early documents and look at the statements of the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, on the advantages that were going to come out of this process, what we find is quite incredible. On 1 August 1992, when Senator Collins signed the agreement with the New Zealand Minister for Transport, Mr Storey, we showed that there was going to be a build-up of services offered by New Zealand and Australian carriers, that we were going to have open arrangements between and within the two countries, that we would have optimum competition, and that we would see a greater liberalisation of the aviation services and, ultimately, a reduction in the cost of travel to Australian and international visitors into the region. At the time the opposition backed the government to the hilt on what this particular arrangement was going to bring.

Only a week before the final episode of this particular chapter was to take place on 1 November, the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), unheralded and unannounced, faxed his New Zealand counterpart to say that the whole deal was off. Then we went into the mode where the Prime Minister started making all sorts of excuses—the principal excuse being that the government was worried about the Qantas privatisation and the float that is due for next year.

In August 1992, Senator Collins highlighted in his statement that this was going to help the Qantas float. He said that there would be a sense of certainty in the community about the arrangements. I suggest that, rather than assisting the Qantas float, the moves by the government in the last fortnight will probably put it in some jeopardy because nobody quite knows exactly what the arrangements are going to be further down the track. The Prime Minister came up with all sorts of other excuses. Most of them were quite wrong.

I was listening to the John Laws program in Brisbane and I got the shock of my life when the Prime Minister started doing the big bucket job on the free trade arrangement. He kept talking about Air New Zealand having 14 jumbos a week flying out of Australia and picking up passengers when, in actual fact, Air New Zealand has 5.5 jumbos a week. He attacked the single market because Air New Zealand was going to get the greatest share offer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Must be hard with half a plane.

—He does not know too much about beyond traffic, does he? The Prime Minister comes out with all this garbage when, in fact, the reverse is true. All honourable members have to do is go through the department's figures to see what the real story is. The figures on the fifth freedom traffic that operates between New Zealand and Australia are quite enlightening. Qantas manages to carry 200,000 people on fifth freedom rights over New Zealand every year. How many passengers does Air New Zealand carry out of Australia on fifth freedom rights? These are not Australians and New Zealanders travelling between the two countries; they are international tourists coming through. The answer is 50,000. It is two to one. This is really where the whole argument falls down.

PARA.TAB: If we look at an analysis of what New Zealand has done in opening up the whole of this south-west Pacific region, we find that the greatest advantage has come to Australia. I will be a bit parochial about this because some of the great advantages come to the south-east corner of Queensland. The analysis of the flights that Air New Zealand is bringing into Australia over Brisbane and then to Auckland is quite interesting. It would appear that the average number of Australian and New Zealand passengers using the service from Taipei to Brisbane and on to Auckland is seven, yet every flight is full.

It is interesting to consider that something like 150,000 new tourists have come into the south-east corner of Queensland since this facility was made available. The reality is that there is so much traffic coming out of South-East Asia at the moment that I doubt whether Qantas and Air New Zealand ultimately will have the capacity to handle it.

The forecasts show that the growth in tourism traffic from Asia into Australia over the remaining years of this decade will be phenomenal. The growth is estimated by organisations such as the Boeing corporation at 25 per cent. We are looking at 140 million Asians travelling offshore for holidays by the year 2000. If Australia and New Zealand are to take their present share of the traffic, Qantas and Air New Zealand will have to triple their fleets in that period. That is a big ask.

We really have to ask whether or not this government will be for real in the promotion of the tourist industry. The investment now starting to build up in terms of new hotels in Australia is phenomenal. It is taking place in Sydney partly because of the Olympic Games and in places like the Gold Coast and Brisbane certainly because of the increase of international traffic by virtue of these flights out of Asia. There are four new hotels on the books on the Gold Coast, a couple sitting there in Brisbane, and Cairns has a requirement of five new international hotels. Whether the investment in those hotels may be in jeopardy because of the government move we are not yet sure, but there is certainly some doubt as to whether this government is for real in terms of opening up that tourist business.

The minister at the table, the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley), shakes his head but, despite all the government's trumpeting, so far we have less than one per cent of the world tourism market. Thank goodness we have only got that. With the quality of investment we have and, indeed, the confidence of investment in new infrastructure here in Australia, we do not stand very high. While we might be doing very well at the moment, we have no idea of the potential if systems are opened up, if investment is allowed to take place.

The open skies arrangement between Australia and New Zealand was a tremendous opportunity to realise some of that potential. But there was another factor; that is, that part of the arrangement which allowed any carrier from either country to operate between or within either country. Subtitled on that is that the New Zealanders would have had the same opportunities to operate some limited domestic services in Australia as an Australian carrier has had in New Zealand. We then start talking about cherry picking.

Air New Zealand probably would have run the Brisbane, Sydney, Melbourne and maybe Cairns corridor to carry that tourist traffic. But despite the trumpeting of the government once again about opening up the market to domestic competition, what have we seen? We have seen two attempts to provide competition—Compass I and Compass II, both of which have failed. At least in this particular case we had a very solid airline that may or may not have come into that market and given true domestic competition.

Let us put the lie to this competition line. In the papers at the moment we are seeing full page ads for a number of specials—$149 from Sydney to Melbourne; $149 from Sydney to Brisbane—that will operate in the off-season. That is great and a lot of people have travelled under such schemes, but the reality is that the core fares within the Australian aviation network have gone up. If you want to see what can happen when you start limiting that competition, have a look at what is happening on the US route at the moment. Nobody will deny that the fares needed to be increased there to get some yield on them, but in actual fact the highest growth in airfares in the world at the moment is on the route from Australia and New Zealand to the United States because there is no capacity.

It will be very interesting to see what happens because unless we get our arrangements right and unless we take advantage of that I have no doubt that the American carriers who have rights there will ultimately come back into that market when they start getting their act together. Looking at the resurgence of the American air carriers at the moment, maybe that is not too far down the track. We had this opportunity to really crank up the south-west Pacific market. We had this opportunity for maximum competition between our major carriers and, by virtue of the government's move, I think we have jeopardised that to a very great degree.

The thing that worries me is that the words we are hearing from the government at the moment sound very similar indeed to those that were uttered by Mrs Thatcher's government in the early 1980s when it was trying to put British Airways up for privatisation. I have no hesitation in saying that I think that the British competition and privatisation program really has been a bit of a sham. What has happened over there is that, prior to the liberalisation of the British arrangements, British Airways had 80 per cent of the business; now it has 87 per cent of the business. It has been done through the collapse and decline of carriers like British Caledonian, Dan-Air, Air Europe and, of course, Laker Airways. British Airways has been in the courts of the United Kingdom and the United States paying out hundreds of millions of pounds in compensation to the carriers because of the various dirty tricks campaigns. At the moment there is more litigation going on in relation to the arrangements between Virgin Atlantic and British Airways. We do not want that sort of thing to come in through an overprotected industry. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that, though this was a backbencher's presentation from the opposition, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) was due the courtesy of a ministerial response, because he is one of the members in this House who takes the tourism industry and the aviation industry very seriously. He has had a breadth of view on those issues over the years. I suppose his last few remarks indicate how broad that view is, since he criticised one of the opposition parties' ideological mentors during the last decade and the process of privatisation and competition that the Thatcher government went through. There is no doubt at all in my mind that, in the area with which I am more familiar—telecommunications—the combination of privatisation of British Telecom and the introduction of competition led to a wasting of competition effectively for a decade as a result of misplaced policies in that regard.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, despite those words of unusual praise for a member of the opposition, I take issue with the member. I think his concerns are overdrawn and that they do not do credit to the totality of the MOU that was entered into and the concerns that the government has; the continued generosity of the treatment of Air New Zealand by the government arising out of the initial memorandum; and the requirement to ensure that Australian interests are protected, including the interests of the tourism industry, in every decision that we take in this area.

To make one partisan point against the member opposite—since he made a few against us—despite his substantial role over the years in devising tourism policy for the opposition, when he last presented himself to the electorate, he was obliged to do so on the basis that he was proposing a 15 per cent tax on every conceivable aspect of tourism activity in this country. He found himself, no doubt to his great personal discomfort, greatly at odds with the various industry groups, lobby groups and airline organisations with which he has dealt so comprehensively and on such a friendly basis over the years. It must indeed have been distressing for him.

Nevertheless, he saddled up, repaired his broken lance and sallied forth on the election highways and byways, and he got shot to pieces. I guess, for his own personal sense of satisfaction, he no doubt hopes that he will be able to run at the next election presenting something other than the proverbial sandwich that he operated with at the last one. He will not, however, find much comfort in this area, because his argument is overdrawn. You would almost have to believe from his remarks the notion that the opportunity for the airlines to effectively serve the tourism industry and the business community is a product entirely of a set of arrangements that were arrived at between Qantas and the government and between Air New Zealand and the government. That is hopelessly wide of the mark.

When I was aviation minister back in 1983-84, the situation was this: Qantas had 23 competitors; there was a two-airline agreement in operation which was absolutely rigidly protected; no competition to the position of those two airlines in the market was permitted; the discussion of bilateral arrangements for Qantas to operate internationally was accompanied basically by no set of assumptions that the tourism industry would be served; entire consideration was on the balance sheet of Qantas; and the mercantilist principles which then prevailed, and still largely do, in international aviation had full reign. From the Australian point of view, there was no negotiation basically of Australian routes; there was negotiation of Qantas services.

What is the picture today, after the years in office of this government? The picture is this: Qantas now has internationally 43 competitors operating into Australia—virtually double the number that was there at the time we assumed office. The massive capacity that has been brought into this country has, in large part, been a product of that—not of any agreement that we might have arrived at recently in relation to Air New Zealand.

One of the areas where that competition was most manifest was across the Pacific. A situation, to which the honourable member referred, of some raising of prices and tightening of capacity in the Pacific has virtually nothing to do with any lack of entitlement to fly the Pacific and everything to do with the fact that the US carriers have stopped dumping on the market. Any reference to any consistency of practice by US carriers over time, I think, has to be very carefully considered. The likelihood is that, as they have started to get a decent price out of that operation, the US carriers will be straight back into dumping capacity on that market and the situation that we find ourselves in at the moment will be a purely temporary one.

The agreement that was arrived at in the memorandum of understanding does not have legal force; it is not a treaty. It is an agreement in which there are two sides. A variety of matters were addressed—not just simply the matters associated with any particular rights of a domestic market or on-carriage by Air New Zealand. There are elements of that in it, but there are other elements as well. Very important from the Australian point of view were common border issues which have also had attached to them more up-front the question of passenger facilitation between the two countries. There has been no progress in that area. As far as the government is concerned, it takes two to tango on these matters: if the memorandum is there for consideration, then the memorandum has to be considered on all sides.

Included in the statements made by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) when he offered the advice to New Zealand, referred to by the honourable member, was the fact that there was a very generous provision of freedom rights. That was put in place in the course of those negotiations. Although not all services have been taken up—only those services across the profitable routes—I am quite aware that those services subsequently will be taken up. Those services amount to 12 per week and have increased Air New Zealand's capacity to undertake these activities by some 300 per cent.

It was not an invitation to Air New Zealand to fly to India, Bangladesh or any of the destinations which have not proved lucrative for entry into the Australian market. It was an offer to Air New Zealand, which it has taken up, to operate into the most profitable areas in east Asia into which our two carriers, Qantas and Ansett, operate.

Whilst not necessarily featuring in any set of bilateral arrangements that Australia would have with any of those countries served, when bilateral agreements are entered into and discussions had on them as they are from time to time under the treaty arrangements, even though we do not directly negotiate access for Air New Zealand—that is a matter for the New Zealand government and its bilaterals—the capacity is certainly given consideration by those countries with which we have that relationship. Again, it is a question of it taking two to tango; it is not just one person who is involved. They have to agree to any set of propositions.

It has to be said that mercantilist principles sit strongly in the minds of those countries with which we deal in east Asia, and that is perhaps one of the reasons why the routes are so profitable. Nevertheless, the general nature of capacity into and out of the place sits at the back of their minds even though it is not necessarily on the table in the course of bilateral arrangements. So the concessions that have been made to Air New Zealand, which are still in force in the statement made by the Minister for Transport, are very generous indeed and, at least in terms of the Australian carriers, over time will operate in a deleterious fashion for them.

As to the question of whether or not there is an impact as a result of alleged hard dealing in regard to domestic cabotage rights impacting upon the nature of the service and the cost of it here, several points need to be made. The domestic air fares offered by Qantas and Ansett have fallen in real terms over the period since 1990 by over 22 per cent. At the same time, passenger numbers have increased by some 46 per cent. The opportunity is there for domestic airlines in Australia to establish an Australian personality and operate against those two airlines. In fact, Ansett operates in New Zealand with a New Zealand personality, not an Australian personality. Under the original terms of the MOU, New Zealand would operate effectively in Australia with a New Zealand personality.

The tourism industry to which the honourable member has referred is now served by a substantial change in the way in which the government arrives at agreements with bilateral partners all over the globe on capacity, which is no longer dominated purely by a defence of one Australian carrier's rights. It is dominated by the fact that the government in those agreements goes in to bat not just for Qantas but for Ansett and other potential Australian carriers across those routes. It also goes in to bat on the basis of an understanding that we have let into this country something like twice the number of international airlines that operated in it at the time that we came into office. All of this has served to massively increase and improve the tourism industry, both domestic and international, in this country as the years have gone by.

I do not think anyone claims—and even in his more generous moments this includes the honourable member—other than that the government has served the tourism industry well over the last decade. There will be, from time to time, the odd finagle and disagreement. There are certainly things in taxation arrangements and the like that the tourism industry would like of the government, and it constantly puts propositions to us in that regard. But the fact of the matter is that the tourism industry has been very well served, and the proof of the pudding is in the eating: a massive increase in tourism into this country to the point where I think it is now our second largest export earner after coal. That is a very substantial achievement indeed over the period that this government has been in office.

The honourable member also referred to the requirement upon the government to establish clarity in all these areas by the time a prospectus is issued for the Qantas float. That is certainly the case. The Minister for Transport has indicated that he intends to do that, and he has time. This is not a matter on which we immediately need to arrive at a conclusion in the next week or two. He will discuss these and other matters with the New Zealand minister. In due course, a position will emerge that will be capable of incorporation in the prospectus that Qantas issues.

I return to the points that I made at the beginning of my contribution. There is much more to that MOU than the question of Air New Zealand's rights in Australia. The other side of the equation, which related to a resolution of common borders, simply has not been proceeded with effectively by our dialogue partner.

There is a requirement in any reasonable set of agreements that all sides of the agreement be effectively capable of being upheld. There is an anticipation, too, that associated with any establishment of a single market there would be a resolution of ownership and control issues at the same time. There has been effectively no resolution of those either. That is our side of the argument as far as this particular set of circumstances is concerned.

I repeat and draw attention again to the very substantial and generous treatment that Air New Zealand has been offered under freedom rights, most of which but not all of which it has taken up. The offers it has taken up have been in the highly profitable areas as opposed to the high risk areas, though I fully concede it will take those up as well. That was a generous act by the government. Our treatment continues to be generous. We have not withdrawn those rights that were put on offer at that point in time. In all the circumstances, I believe the government's actions have been entirely reasonable and in the interests of our tourism and aviation industries. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Truss Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) concluded his remarks by saying that his comments represented the government's side of the argument. All I can say is that, if that half-hearted, unenthusiastic, pathetic response is the government's side of the argument, its argument is indeed pitifully threadbare, and I notice he is so ashamed of it that he is choosing to leave the chamber. The reality is that the decision of the government to welsh on the agreement to develop a single aviation market covering Australia and New Zealand demonstrates, once again, that this government simply cannot be trusted.

PARA.TAB: The government's word is empty. Whether it is making a promise to the voters of Australia or signing an international agreement, its words are empty. I do not mind so much if the ALP wants its reputation with the Australian people damaged by being dishonest and by saying things to the Australian people that are untrue—though I wish our political system had not degenerated to that level—but when the government is dishonouring our country and the reputation of our nation by wilfully walking away from an agreement signed in all good faith and upon which other parties and other governments have acted I think that is a disgrace to our country and the government should be ashamed of itself. If the country with which we act so irresponsibly is our closest friend and ally, New Zealand, then that response is even less acceptable.

The government is living clearly by the doctrine of the Richardson book—lying is acceptable, necessary and even obligatory under the Westminster system. Frankly, that kind of attitude should never be accepted in this country. We have a clear obligation to honour the responsibilities and agreements that are made as a nation. Our government's action in this regard stands condemned. Let us make it quite clear that the government's response to this matter, its attitude to the open skies philosophy, has been quite unequivocal.

It is not as though Australia was dragged unwillingly into an open skies agreement. The One Nation statement brought down by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in 1992 stated that the Australian government was going to pursue the New Zealand government to obtain an `agreement to implement a single aviation market (including a common border) with New Zealand, allowing Australia and New Zealand carriers full access to the Australasian market. This would allow all Australian and New Zealand airlines to operate within Australia and New Zealand as well as across the Tasman'. The memorandum of understanding was signed in August 1992, and the open skies agreement was born. From November 1994, this month, Australia and New Zealand was to be one market.

Air New Zealand responded to those principles and established, with some degree of investment, a commitment to providing services to and from Australia. Air New Zealand's commitment was evidenced by the investment of the airline and the effort that it put into developing services from the growth markets of Asia into and through Australia and by establishing Brisbane as an Australian hub.

Air New Zealand's efforts were limited to the equivalent of 12 services of 747s weekly. Air New Zealand has delivered an additional 50,000 international visitors to Australia who have contributed an additional $100 million in visitor spending and supported an estimated 2,000 jobs. With more beyond rights, this contribution would even grow. Every 747 has the potential to increase visitor spending in Australia by close to $1 million. Those figures and that enthusiasm were supported by the Prime Minister himself who, in answer to a question on 8 October, with his usual flamboyancy, said:
By the end of 1994, Air New Zealand estimates that employment directly or indirectly generated by its operations in Australia will be nearly 10,000 . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I have never heard Air New Zealand claim more than 2,000, but the Prime Minister said 10,000. Frankly, with the government's jobs record I would have thought it would be thankful for 2,000. But the Prime Minister promised Air New Zealand's operations would add 10,000 to the number of jobs in Australia and add $90 million per annum to the economy. He went on to say:

This very good decision is good news not only for the people of Brisbane and Queensland but for the whole of Australia in terms of employment and the expansion of trade and international services—none of which are growing more strongly than tourism services and airlines.
So it was quite clear that the government had an enthusiastic commitment to the open skies policy. The Prime Minister was waxing lyrical about it, promising Australia 10,000 extra jobs.

PARA.TAB: Of course, one of the effects of the government's decision to welsh on this agreement has been quickly identified by the Queensland Minister for Tourism, Sport and Racing, Bob Gibbs. He has been quick to oppose the government's backdown and, of course, he is not a man without some influence in the ALP in Queensland. He just happens to be state president of the party along with being tourism minister. He rapidly pointed out the potential loss of jobs to Queensland as a result of this decision.

The airline's regional general manager, Mr Garry Court, was reported in the Courier-Mail on 28 October as confirming that a large number of potential jobs now may have been lost to Queensland. Air New Zealand is reconsidering the operations that it has been providing in the state of Queensland and the many jobs that have been made available in that state. So this whole move has a very significant potential impact on the tourism industry of our country.

Air New Zealand wants to build up its efforts and investment in Australia so it can spread the benefits that have already occurred in Queensland to the southern states. But one week before the permitted start-up of this agreement—just one week before Air New Zealand was to develop a program to start services around Australia—the agreement was frozen by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton).

Air New Zealand has been accused of cherry picking, picking the eyes out of the market. Let us remember where it made its commitment. Air New Zealand was prepared to set up at Brisbane's appalling international airport, offer services that Qantas has been neglecting for years and provide routes that are not available and which Qantas could have taken up but chose not to take up. It has been providing a service that Qantas declined to provide in so many regards. So to suggest that it is picking the eyes out of the market is ludicrous. It has been prepared to offer services that Qantas has neglected.

Air New Zealand has estimated that it is providing 50,000 extra international visitors to Australia as a result of its services. Some say that it is taking those services from Qantas. We have to ask, firstly: do we believe in competition or do we not? The Prime Minister parades around the world telling everybody we should have free trade. He goes off, as the previous speaker said, to international forums and lectures other countries about freeing up their markets, but he will not do it in relation to the services of Ansett and Qantas.

Why is there this double standard? There are plenty of obvious reasons. The government is concerned about the threat to its own Qantas float, and it needs the money to help pay the unemployment benefits. But I think the real message became abundantly clear from no other source than the former New Zealand Prime Minister David Lange. He was quoted in the Australian today as saying that the real reason `had more to do with Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation wanting to quit its 50 per cent shareholding in Ansett Australia than a breakdown in communications between the two governments'. David Lange, a member of the New Zealand Labour Party, stated:
There is a faction in Australian politics which has certain debts and certain obligations and certain associations.

SPEECH.PARA: He hit the nail on the head.
This faction wants to get Rupert Murdoch out of his liability in Ansett-New Zealand. Rupert wants out of the Ansett group altogether, and Paul Keating tried to help and is still trying to help.

So the old mates syndrome is back in operation again. Laurie Brereton, king of the mates, is there again. The man who does not want to be industrial relations minister, who cannot run a shipping line and cannot run an airline—but does not want anybody else to run one either—is caring, again, for one of the mates by bailing him out of his problems with Ansett in New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: In the process, hundreds of millions of dollars will be lost to the Australian tourism industry. The Australian and New Zealand governments commissioned a joint survey which estimated that there would be a $400 million dollar gain to Australia as a result of the open skies policy. That is now all to be ditched along with the benefits to local motel operators and tour operators who could benefit from the potential growth in the Australian tourism industry. None of that counts for anything when there is a mate to be helped, when someone needs to be bailed out. That is the reason the government has reneged on its responsibilities. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) finished on a very good note. He was talking about mates. Let us hear about the mates of the two-airline agreement and how they came down to Canberra in the dark of night, when the two-airline agreement was put together in secrecy, and the poor old minister for transport at that time did not even have a finger in it. Do not bring us those little stories. We hear the hypocrisy of the people on that side, who talk about competition in airline services. The fathers, the parents, the protectors of one of the most devious and rigid constraints upon airline growth in this country—the two-airline agreement—all sit opposite. This insidious document that they created is their perfidy, and now they talk about competition.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that, whenever you hear the opposition talk about international airline services, it is always the foreign airline that should be given priority over Australia. What is it about Australia? What is it about Australia's international airline services that the opposition cannot stomach and does not want to support. It is always the foreign airline, whether it is Laker, Air Chile or British Airways—I could go through the whole stream and read them into the Hansard. Always the Australian airline comes second. That preference for foreign airlines I fail to understand. To me it is a betrayal of the interests of this nation.

Here today, again, we are hearing all about it. It is always Australia's fault, and it is always Australia's operators that are wrong. Those champions of the foreign airlines say to us that, as a government, we should be ashamed of ourselves. I am proud as an Australian, and we on this side of the House are proud to be looking to the interests of Australian industry and to Australia's international airline industry. We would not be proud to be doing what you are doing. We do not want to put Australia's interests second to those of Air New Zealand.

The honourable member said that we should honour the obligations in the agreement. Yes, we will honour the obligations in the agreement, but we will do so in the manner that best meets this nation's interests and when the government of New Zealand honours its obligations under the agreement. To date, it has not done so. In New Zealand they are very good, with these kinds of arrangements and these problems, at whipping up the media. It is very easy to whip up opposition. When a foreign government can get the opposition in the Australian parliament working for it, it is really making a mark. That is what has happened here over past days, and that is what is happening here this afternoon. The New Zealanders have an obligation to honour the terms of that memorandum of understanding.

This issue is not new. It has been boiling up for some time. It was discussed by the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister of New Zealand back in July and August. Our Prime Minister expressed his concern about the failure of the New Zealanders to carry out their obligations—and I will deal with the detail of that a little bit later—particularly in regard to passenger facilitation, rationalisation of the industry and a common border. That was four months ago, and officials have been talking about it for much longer.

It is clear also that the New Zealand government does not want to go into passenger facilitation. It does not see a return on the money that needs to be invested to provide that set of procedures and operations. I want to emphasise the words of our Prime Minister on this issue. He said that what has happened in Australian terms is that it has been all give, give, give, and for New Zealand it has been all take. I will not have a bar of it. This is Australia, this is the Australian Parliament and it is our interests we are concerned with. If you want some numbers, just look at the trans-Tasman figures. In 1993-94, 2.156 million passengers crossed the Tasman. Air New Zealand carried 1.05 million of those; Qantas carried 821,000 and the remnant of Continental Airlines carried 58,000. So who is doing the lion's share of the business?

In recent times, New Zealand has been given approval to operate 12 services per week beyond Australia. Air service rights are a very valuable economic resource, and they ought to be managed in the best interests of this nation—not of the foreign nations or the foreign airlines that come to this country to share in our business. Those 12 services provide New Zealand with 3,600 additional seats per week on to places like Taipei, Bangkok, Osaka, Seoul and Los Angeles. That is a very valuable benefit to Air New Zealand and to the New Zealand nation.

If you look at the whole issue involved, it is very easy to see that Australia is being seriously disadvantaged because Air New Zealand, quite cleverly—you have got to give it marks for its cleverness; it always outsmarts the opposition and can pull it in to support its case—has picked the eyes out of the most valuable parts of the trade and it has gone slow on those aspects of the agreement that do not provide it with much return.

New Zealanders are superb at using the media in this country to whip up sympathy for the poor little New Zealand bleeder. David Lange was quoted in the Australian today, and to my mind it is a masterpiece of mock generosity. He is reported as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . allowing Ansett to fly New Zealand domestic air routes in 1987 without seeking reciprocal rights for Air New Zealand in Australia `was an enormous improvement of air services'.

Let me tell you the real story about the mock generosity that comes from David Lange, the former Prime Minister of New Zealand. New Zealanders were utterly fed up with the arrogance of Air New Zealand domestic services, with the unreliability and costs of those services, and they desperately wanted another airline to go there. So New Zealand approached Ansett. Ansett refused the first time; it was approached again. The minister rang Sir Peter Abeles a number of times and Ansett was finally cajoled and kidded into coming into New Zealand with a promise of great prosperity.

PARA.TAB: For Ansett New Zealand domestic services have been a financial quagmire. Who benefited out of this? Ansett lost, New Zealand got a better service and Air New Zealand got some competition—but there was nothing in it for Australia. We did not ask to go into New Zealand. The beneficiaries were within New Zealand. It is the height of hypocrisy to be putting forward to us that, in some way, Australia was being given a benefit by allowing Ansett to operate there. I am sure Ansett wished to hell it had never gone near New Zealand. It would be hundreds of millions of dollars better off. But it was brought in by the New Zealanders weeping and crying, who, some seven years later, are saying, `We did you a favour by letting you come in here to lose your money.'

Let us go back to the main points. Australia remains firmly committed to the concept of a single aviation market. It is because Air New Zealand has not been prepared to abide by the concept set out, as far as Australia and our government is concerned, that we have taken the steps that we have.

At the moment, New Zealand is trying to use a single market for its own advantage, for access to Australia's domestic and international markets. Give credit to the New Zealanders and the management of Air New Zealand. They will pick the eyes out of the traffic. They are very clever at it. But do not let us be the fools by putting our jobs second to their jobs, and our economic interests second to their economic interests. We do not want an advantage; we just want good partners working together—a fair go for each side.

A memorandum of understanding means that there is an obligation on each partner to carry out his or her responsibilities. It is a fair proposition, but in this case New Zealand has fallen short. We are not reneging on the 1992 memorandum of understanding. New Zealand is reneging on its obligations and that has forced us to say, `Enough, enough.' We have to look after Australia's interests.

That is all that is happening and the New Zealanders understand that. They play the harp over here and suck in some of the opposition, some of the Australian media. They are very good at it; they are probably the world's best at it. But the bottom line is that Australia's economic and aviation interests have to come first. That is all this government is doing and that is all the Prime Minister has said. The Prime Minister has said that the New Zealanders just take from Australia, do not accept responsibilities and do not share what they should be giving us.

The government remains available for further discussions. Our Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) will be talking with the New Zealand minister for transport. We are quite relaxed about this. We do get a bit puzzled sometimes at the histrionics and the nature of some of the media stunts that are pulled by the New Zealanders. We recognise that they are good at it, but this business is a little more serious than media stunts. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1994-95, together with Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2), which I shall introduce shortly, comprise the additional estimates for 1994-95. In these bills, parliament is asked to appropriate moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to the appropriations made for 1994-95 under appropriation acts Nos 1 and 2 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act. The additional appropriations in these three bills total some $1,082 million; $676 million is sought in Appropriation Bill (No. 3), $399 million is sought in Appropriation Bill (No. 4) and $7 million is sought in the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2).

PARA.TAB: These amounts are partly offset by savings in the appropriations made by appropriation acts Nos 1 and 2, 1994-95. Reflecting the government's determination to improve the efficiency of continuing programs, these savings, amounting to $365 million in gross terms, are detailed under the relevant appropriation headings in the document Statement of savings expected in annual appropriations, which has been distributed to honourable members.

After allowing for prospective savings, the appropriations sought represent a net increase of $717 million in appropriations for 1994-95, an increase of two per cent on the amounts made available at the time of the 1994-95 budget. While this is higher than the level of supplementation sought in 1993-94, it is less than the amounts sought in the previous two years. At the same time, the net increase does not impact on overall budget figuring as it is largely offset by reductions in the estimates of special appropriations. These reductions reflect improving economic conditions.

I turn now to the main areas for which the government seeks additional provisions in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1994-95 to meet payments for the ordinary annual services of the government. Although the budget figuring made allowance for prospective wage and salary increases, it is not practice to appropriate these amounts at budget time. Funds are now required to meet increases resulting from salary increases and they are included in the $167 million included in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) for increased running costs for all departments and agencies. This represents an increase of 1.4 per cent on the funding for running costs included in Appropriation Act (No. 1). Other factors affecting running costs include the impact of actual compared with estimated carryovers from 1993-94, transfers between financial years as well as some additional funding for departments associated with various government initiatives which have been previously announced.
Gross additional estimates of some $215 million are sought for the defence portfolio in Appropriation Bill (No. 3). This figure includes:

SPEECH.PARA: $186 million for equipment and stores provision, due mainly to a carryover from 1993-94, for the payment of fuel excise and the reprogramming of approved projects, together with a number of new equipment approvals;
$13 million for defence facilities, largely due to slippage from 1993-94 in the upgrade of sewerage systems at Holsworthy; and
$11.7 million for defence housing, mainly reflecting an increased capital subvention for the Defence Housing Authority.
The increases have been offset by reductions elsewhere in the defence appropriations, giving a net increase of some $194 million. In addition, Appropriation Bill (No. 3) includes provision for:
an increase of $30 million for labour market program assistance to job seekers and industry, reflecting the government's commitment to assist the long-term unemployed to return to work;
$35 million for child-care fee relief, which reflects growth both in average fee relief and in the number of private sector places; and

$86 million for the care of veterans in non-departmental institutions, reflecting changed funding arrangements and increased patient numbers following the sale of the repatriation general hospitals at Greenslopes, Heidelberg and Daw Park.

The balance of some $143 million in the amount included in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) is made up of minor variations across a range of programs in most departments and agencies. These additional appropriations are required to meet undertakings made by the government, as well as unavoidable cost and price increases and other economic parameter changes, since the budget was prepared. I commend the bill to the House.

Motion (by Mr Beazley) agreed to:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That:

(1)the resolutions adopted by the House on 9 October 1984 a.m., as amended on 21 March 1985, 13 February 1986, 22 October 1986 and 30 November 1988 relating to the registration of interests by Members, be further amended as follows:
(a)omit resolution (1), substitute the following resolution:
"That—
(a)within 28 days of making and subscribing an oath or affirmation as a Member of the House of Representatives each Member shall provide to the Registrar of Members' Interests, a statement of—
(i)the Members' registrable interests, and
(ii)the registrable interests of which the Member is aware (a) of the Member's spouse and (b) of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Member for support,

in accordance with resolutions adopted by the House and in a form determined by the Committee of Members' Interests from time to time, and shall also notify any alteration of those interests to the Registrar within 28 days of that alteration occurring, and
(b)the statement to be provided by a Member shall include:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask leave of the House to amend notice No. 4, government business, relating to certain amendments of the standing orders, so as to omit from the first line of the motion `with effect from 8 November 1994' and substitute `with immediate effect'.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, with immediate effect:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)the standing orders be amended so as to—
(a)incorporate references to Members in gender-inclusive pronouns;
(b)in relation to parliamentary committees, omit the term "chairman" and substitute the term "chair"; and
(c)make the amendments appearing under the heading "Other proposed changes" on page ii;

as identified in the paper "House of Representatives—Text of the standing and sessional orders prepared in pursuance of the resolution of the House on 30 June 1994", dated 19 August 1994, presented to the House by the Speaker on 23 August 1994; and
(2)the following further amendments to the standing orders be made:
(a)Omit standing order 160 and substitute the following standing order:
160.Except as otherwise provided, a motion not seconded may not be further discussed and no entry thereof shall be made in the Votes and Proceedings.
(b)Omit standing order 234 and substitute the following standing order:

234.When a bill referred to the Main Committee has been fully considered by it, the question shall be put forthwith and determined without amendment or debate, "That this bill be reported to the House, without amendment" or "with (an) amendment(s)" ("and with (an) unresolved question(s)"), as appropriate. If this question is agreed to, the bill shall be reported to the House by the Speaker at a time when other business is not before the House. A copy of the bill certified by the Clerk of the Committee together with schedules of any amendments made by the Committee and any questions which the Committee was unable to resolve shall be transmitted to the Speaker for report to the House.
(c)Omit standing orders 236 and 237, and substitute the following standing orders:

236.On consideration of a report from the Main Committee on a bill with amendments or unresolved questions, separate questions shall be proposed on each of the unresolved questions which shall be open to debate or amendment. A single question shall then be proposed, if necessary, "That the amendments made by the Main Committee be agreed to", no debate or amendment to this question being allowed. No new amendments may be moved except as necessary as a consequence of the resolution by the House of any question on which the Committee had reported it could not agree. Finally, the question "That the bill (or the bill, as amended) be agreed to" shall be proposed, no debate or amendment being allowed.
237.When a bill has been agreed to at the consideration in detail stage, the Speaker shall notify the House and a future day shall be fixed, on motion, for the third reading.
(d)Omit standing order 270 and substitute the following standing order:
270.A Main Committee is established to which:
(a)bills may be referred for consideration; and
(b)orders of the day for the resumption of debate on: (i) motions moved in connection with committee and delegation reports; and (ii) motions to take note of papers, may be referred for debate.
All remaining proceedings on such bills as are referred to it, to the completion of consideration in detail, shall be conducted in the Main Committee:

PARA.TAB: Provided that a bill or other order of the day may be returned to the House for consideration at any time during its consideration in the Main Committee by agreement to a motion which may be moved without notice by any Member (no seconder required) "That further proceedings be conducted in the House" which motion shall be determined without amendment or debate. If the Committee is unable to resolve this question the bill or order of the day shall be returned to the House. The House shall continue consideration at the point which had been reached in the Committee and shall resolve any other matters which the Committee reports in relation to the bill or order of the day:

Provided further that the House may at any time require a bill or other order of the day to be returned to the House for further consideration, on motion without notice by any Member. Any matter so returned shall be set down for consideration at a later hour that day.

SPEECH.PARA: (e)Omit standing order 274 and substitute the following standing order:
274.The Main Committee may meet at any time during a sitting of the House and the following provisions shall apply:
(a)the Committee need not adjourn between items of business;
(b)proceedings in the Committee shall be suspended by the Chair to enable Members to attend any division in the House;
(c)a sitting of the Committee may be adjourned on motion moved by any Member without notice;
(d)upon the adjournment of the House the Chair shall interrupt the business before the Committee and forthwith adjourn the Committee; and
(e)the Committee shall stand adjourned upon completion of consideration of all matters referred to it by the House.
(f)Omit standing order 276 and substitute the following standing order:

276.Every question in the Committee shall be decided on the voices and if any Member dissents from the result announced by the Chair, the question shall be recorded in the minutes as unresolved. Any unresolved question shall be reported to the House and included in a schedule attached to the report of the Committee to the House on the bill or order of the day.
(g)Omit standing order 278 and substitute the following standing order:
278.A motion contradictory of a previous decision of the Main Committee in relation to the same matter shall not be entertained.
(h)After standing order 280, insert the following standing order:

280A.Any matter to be reported to the House from the Main Committee shall be certified by the Clerk of the Committee and transmitted to the Speaker for report to the House when other business is not before the House. Except as otherwise provided, any matter so reported shall be set down for consideration at a later hour that day.

Obviously the date on the motion has passed us by and, therefore, `immediate effect' is a more suitable way of discussing it. These are a couple of changes to standing orders that will facilitate the more effective operation of the Main Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the House very long. This motion deals with some changes to the standing orders, the main preoccupation of which appears to be this absurd pursuit of so-called gender inclusive pronouns. I register on my behalf and on the behalf of many Australians, including, I think, a lot in your own ranks, that we regard this manic pursuit of gender inclusive language as the destruction in part of a beautiful language. Language terrorism is a very unattractive politically correct pursuit.
—Ha, ha!

—The honourable member may think my description `language terrorism' is some exclusive preserve of the right-hand side of politics, but it is an expression that was bequeathed to this House by none other than one of your own colleagues, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free), who has a damned sight better understanding of the quality and the beauty of our language than do apparently the people who are preoccupied with what I might call the appearances of equality as distinct from the reality of equality. I find this sort of thing really tedious and small-minded. People will, I suppose, be allowed to go on using the expression `chairman', or will there be some kind of language vilification legislation to prevent that being used?
—That's a thought.

—Be it recorded that there will be an amendment to the racial vilification act. I always support sensible amendments to the standing orders. I am not going to divide the House on this, but the opposition regards it as an absurd, small-minded, tedious exercise in political correctness which would be an embarrassment to the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), I am sure. It is certainly an embarrassment to the minister for education in the present government. I am sure it is an embarrassment to the Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Johns). I think if you went right through the other side you would probably find it was an embarrassment to a lot of the others. Concentrate on the reality of equality in this country instead of on some of the absurd forms which do nothing but undermine the most expressive language known to mankind.

—I want to make a couple of observations on this motion as the Chairman of the Procedure Committee. I start by making an observation about the remarks that were just made by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). I share to some extent the concerns that he has about the extent to which it is necessary to pursue questions of this kind, but I must also acknowledge and consider the fact that I am aware that some women who occupy the position of the chair are offended if they are referred to as `chairman'. I think it probably simplifies it in a case like this simply to use a gender neutral term like `chair'. If it happens to be a fellow who is occupying the chair, then he can be referred to as `chair' or `chairman'—whatever he indicates a personal preference for. If it is a woman occupying the chair, then in the same way she should be entitled to indicate her preference for the title that she would use in that position without our presumption that she is not going to be offended by the use of the expression `chairman'. So I think we have just neutralised it.

PARA.TAB: But I do agree with the member for Bennelong in many respects, not just in connection with the question of gender neutral expressions but in many other areas, about a conscious attempt to restructure the language rather than to allow it more properly to evolve as it has done ever since—I will not say `mankind'; I would have to say `humankind'—we started to communicate orally.

In connection with the essential matter, the proposed changes to the standing orders, as the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has indicated in the motion, are essentially of a technical kind. They have been endorsed by the Procedure Committee. I indicate my appreciation to the minister as well that, when the proposed changes were referred to the Procedure Committee for its consideration, there was one particular element among those that we believed would be more appropriately excluded at this stage and dealt with by a more comprehensive examination of the new procedures which the Procedure Committee will be pursuing from hereon in. I appreciate the fact that that was taken out so that more detailed consideration could be given to it by the Procedure Committee.

In connection with that, I want to emphasise that these substantially new arrangements have now been in place for almost one year. There was an understanding that the operation of the procedures would be reviewed around the end of this year or early next year. I indicate for the benefit of all members that the Procedure Committee will be undertaking such an exercise and is currently in the process of preparing correspondence to go out to all members. Attached to that correspondence will be a list of particular elements of the changes. Members might like to give their attention to them and bring any suggestions to the Procedure Committee so that they can be part of that examination. The letter will go not just to members but also to any other people—such as the clerks and other officers of the parliament—who have an interest in this area.

I indicate to the Leader of the House that the Procedure Committee supports these particular changes. They are simply technical changes at this stage to some of the procedural arrangements. They are simply designed to either facilitate the arrangements or remove some unintended and unnecessary impediments which have been identified as a result of the technical operation of some of the procedures. I conclude with the comment that the Procedure Committee endorses the proposition of the Leader of the House that we adopt those relatively minor technical changes at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to also briefly comment on the matters raised by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). When I noticed on the agenda the item we are now debating I wanted to make one last forlorn protest about the intrusion into the language of a word like `chair' and the loss of a word like `chairman'. I, for one, am thankful that we are getting only the word `chair' and not that appalling word `chairperson', which I dislike enormously. I suspect that the feminist movement does not like the word `chairperson' either, because that has `s-o-n' in it and that is a male word. If you are going to exclude all words with any degree of masculinity in them, I fear that there will not be much of the language left.

PARA.TAB: I certainly do prefer the term `chair' to `chairperson', but there is really no need to get rid of the word `chairman' at all because it is not a gender-exclusive word. The `man' at the end of `chair' does not have anything at all to do with the male sex. I am reliably assured and supported by the dictionaries that the `man' in `chairman' comes from the Latin word `manus', or hand, meaning the hand of authority. That hand of authority is equally present whether the person is male or female. So I am more than happy to use words like `chairman' to a woman or a man, recognising the authority of the office rather than believing it has anything to do with the sex of the individual. In fact, those who oppose this term may do their own cause a disservice by taking away from the authority of the office and placing too much emphasis on the gender of the person who holds the post.

But I recognise that the move has become unstoppable. It has been insidiously, by stealth, intruding on our language over some period. I commend the proposal to remove the gender-exclusive pronouns from the standing orders. I think that has merit. Many women are now part of the parliamentary process and that needs to be acknowledged. Let me compliment the government on eliminating gender-exclusive pronouns not just on 35 per cent of occasions but right throughout the standing orders, so the standing orders accurately reflect the circumstances that occur at the present time.

Words like `mankind', `manhole', `spokesman', `midshipman' and the like—which seem to be so offensive to the people referred to these days as feminazis—make up much of our language. They have never been intended to imply a sex or imply that a woman is not able to do the jobs involved just as well as, or better than, a man. In those sorts of circumstances, we do our language a great deal of damage for no value whatsoever.

I regret the fact that the parliament has been caught up in this seemingly unstoppable force, insidiously introduced right through our education system. It is now in our schools and I do not think that future generations will even know of terms like `chairman'. That position will always be referred to in the future as `chairperson', although I hope that the lead given by the parliament may encourage more people to use the word `chair', which at least avoids some of the contortion that has been added to the language in this regard.

I wish to make a brief comment about the Main Committee. I have never been a fan of the Main Committee but I have to admit that it has worked much better than I expected. The chamber lacks some atmosphere but as much as possible has been done to try to make that place a worthy room in which to hold parliamentary debates. Something is detracted from parliamentary debate that does not occur in this room but I recognise that it has enabled the parliament to deal with legislation in more detail, and that is to be commended. On that basis, the Main Committee may well have permanently entrenched itself in the processes of this parliament, and I will just have to get used to the fact that I wish it could all be done in this chamber.

I hope that at some stage we may deal with some of the less attractive changes that were introduced at the time the Main Committee came into being. For instance, the rostering for question time is a diabolical abuse of the parliamentary processes. We also need to re-address the hours as we have now had some experience with the current process. I welcome the earlier closures but we need to look at some degree of flexibility in sometimes sitting a little later to allow us the opportunity for an occasional meal break.

That is obviously not part of the motion before us at the present time. I hope it is not forgotten and that we will one day return to a proper question time and can again review the question of the hours. As far as the Main Committee is concerned, it is well established and I am going to have to overcome any regrets I have had. I have to admit that I have not yet had an opportunity to make a speech in that chamber, although I have been in the chair on a number of occasions. My main reason for speaking was to express regret at the passing of the word `chairman' from our language and to express some relief that we are at least having the word `chair' and not the horrible word `chairperson'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without wishing to delay the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) too long, I want to make some brief comments. I regret the sensitivity that has perhaps been shown by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) about the changes included in part one of the motion. I think that those changes to the standing orders reflect contemporary wishes of the Australian community. There has been agreement about the use of gender-inclusive pronouns. The term `chair' has come into common usage around the place and that is appropriate. Terms such as `chair' have been used throughout the standing orders, and these changes only tidy up the cases in the standing orders in which the terms have not yet been altered.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the belated conditional support of the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) for the Main Committee. I understand his comments about the atmosphere. That is something that we can perhaps look at but, certainly, the operation of the Main Committee has assisted not only the efficiency with which we look at legislation but the detail in which we have been able to look at it. As I have commented before, the proof of this pudding is in the eating, and I hope the measure has continuing support. I believe that the comments made by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) that it is appropriate to review the overall changes should have the support of all in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will respond to the debate, which was a little more extensive than I thought it might be. When I initially moved this motion, it was nevertheless appropriate. These various changes are not inventions of the government but recommendations of the Procedure Committee for a change in the standing orders. The bulk of them do not go to the gender issues associated with the standing orders but are related to the procedures for the operation of the Main Committee.

PARA.TAB: Those that do go to gender matters involve, by and large, the inclusion of both gender pronouns in the course of the standing orders. So that where `his' appears, `her' appears likewise. The standing orders are a bit inconsistent on that count, because some have been altered to reflect that change while others have not. This motion does that to the lot of them. I cannot really see how there can be any conceivable objection to that form of gender inclusiveness. But one cannot really make the accusation of the language being murdered when both words being incorporated into the standing orders have pretty common usage.

The use of the term `chair' merely reflects the fact that language changes from time to time. Shakespearian English is beautiful, but it is not now in use. I do not think we consider the English language to have been murdered because that style of English is no longer in use. The fact is that for political and social reasons—a whole range of reasons—our language is changing almost on a year to year basis.

I recollect when I went to Gallipoli with the veterans of the Gallipoli campaign what an extraordinary delight it was to talk to them, not least because of their wide experience of life in Australia but because of the extraordinarily archaic language and slang that most of them used when they were talking about their experiences, cobbers, and all the other—

TALK.START.PARA: —Michelle Grattan uses the term `cobber'.

—Michelle is pretty old-fashioned, too. Their language had a really delightful ring to it; nevertheless, a lot of their usage of the language has passed from normal Australian discourse. That did not make any less interesting the opportunity of having that discussion of life with them.

PARA.TAB: I recollect at the time an informal survey as to who they thought was the best Prime Minister of the country. It came as something of a surprise to the journalists present at the time who informally conducted the survey that there had actually been a Prime Minister of Australia called Billy Hughes.

TALK.START.PARA: —An unrepresentative sample.

—I have to say that it was a fairly unrepresentative sample. But the second part dealing with the Main Committee is worth some reflection. Normally at this stage of the year—in fact, slightly earlier than this—I would be hunkered down with the Parliamentary Liaison Officer working out a guillotine and crunching legislation through the House in order to get it into the Senate.

PARA.TAB: There may be a requirement at the end of the day to guillotine some legislation. But the process which we have gone through in the past has been completely obviated. The reason for that is that something like 30-odd bills have gone through the Main Committee without the gag. Members have had the opportunity to fully discuss them, albeit that they are the sort of non-controversial things which would have appeared on the Notice Paper in a guillotine for a half an hour or an hour's discussion—and there would have been half an hour or an hour's discussion.

In the Main Committee, honourable members can bat through legislation at precisely the pace they think they ought to bat through it. When they have talked themselves out, that is the end of the matter. The effect of the Main Committee on the decency of procedures in the House has really been quite manifold. But, while we have incorporated it into the standing orders, as opposed to sessional orders, so it therefore stands for all time until altered by the House, it is still in the experimental phase. We will probably have to constantly receive advice from the Procedure Committee about adjustments that we ought to make to those standing orders to ensure that what is a very good innovation continues to proceed effectively.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In November 1993, 2,200 calls to the New South Wales Police Service related to domestic violence. This is a frightful figure when one realises that these 2,200 calls in one month represent a small fraction of the actual total. That total could be anywhere from 10 to 50 times the reported figure.

PARA.TAB: A calculator is not required to see that violence against women is tragically well entrenched in parts of Australian society. There are claims that between one-fifth and one-third of all households in Australia are the site of some level of violence against women. A review of the literature on this topic is quite sobering and not a little uncomfortable.

Throughout the 1980s, the Office for the Status of Women monitored attitudes to domestic violence. The report concluded that not only was there evidence of higher levels of violence but also there were clear signs of overseas born women and Aboriginal women being further disadvantaged through cultural isolation and the failure of shelters and assistance organisations to meet their cultural needs. Other studies have identified particular migrant women—particularly Asian women who marry through networks and Muslim women in arranged marriages—as often, but not always, being at risk.

A common misconception concerning violence in the home directed towards women is that it is alcohol based. This is only true in about half the cases. The other half are caused by non-intoxicating factors. Fortunately, the situation is not utterly bleak. Over the past 20 years, Australian governments—state and federal and Labor, Liberal and National Party based—have worked steadily at the outskirts of this problem. I say this not in any sense of criticism; I know that the basic problem is an individual, cultural and psychological one that is not completely accessible to government action. Sadly, the situation will be with us until a different cultural circumstance takes place in an individual's life. The government can only do so much. No government of either persuasion has ever been cold-hearted or indifferent in this matter.

Part of the approach by all governments besides tightening the compliance provisions—something this bill does—has been to spread education on these matters of violence throughout the community. Fortunately, these attempts to help difficult situations get better have had strong bipartisan support in this and previous parliaments. This level of bipartisanship is what the community wants. We should make an even greater effort to discuss and formulate legislation that attracts a high degree of general consensus rather than find some technical point that reduces a piece of legislation into being passed on party lines. Australians want unity, not division.

In concluding my remarks on this bill, I hope that this legislation can help break the generational cycle of violence and shattered marriages. The work initiated by the National Council on Violence Against Women must continue. The Commonwealth has made a commitment to the aims of the council by providing nearly $2 million until June 1997 to extend work under the national strategy of violence against women.

Hopefully, one can say that the glass is half full. Changing a culture that is permeated with attitudes supportive of violence towards women will not be quick or easy. However, this bill and other initiatives can give us some hope that we may finish this decade with fewer bashed wives, fewer divorces and a great deal less of the awful emotional stress on children and other family members that is brought about by divorce. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When family law is mentioned, most Australians think of the Family Law Act, which is a statute that was enacted by this parliament in 1975. The enactment of that bill in 1975 reflected changes to matrimonial laws in much of the Western world.

PARA.TAB: Prior to 1959, divorce law in Australia remained under the jurisdiction of the seven states. In that year, the Commonwealth government, pursuant to section 51 of the Australian constitution, introduced its own legislation in the form of the Matrimonial Causes Bill. The effect of this bill was to consolidate the laws of the states into a code of general application throughout Australia. That act provided 14 grounds of divorce.

As we know, the Commonwealth parliament subsequently dealt with the formalities of the creation of marriage in the Marriage Act 1961. Fundamental changes were then proposed when former senator Lionel Murphy, the then Commonwealth Attorney-General, introduced a series of bills in 1973 and 1974, culminating with the Family Law Act in 1975.

In tracing the normative influence of the Family Law Act, it is necessary to trace the two fundamental principles which underlie this legislation: firstly, the centrality or importance of family in society and, secondly, the rights and obligations of spouses both during the marriage and upon its dissolution. Many people, when they hear that the Family Law Act was intended to reinforce family and marriage, are surprised that that notion is one of the underlying principles of the legislation. Yet it is quite clear from the debates in the parliament leading up to the introduction of the act and the terms of the legislation that this was one of the pillars upon which the edifice of family law was constructed in Australia.

In a series of debates prior to the enactment of the Family Law Act, reference was made to United Nations documents, in particular the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which former senator Lionel Murphy referred in his second reading speech. This international covenant recognises the centrality of family in society when it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to protection by society and the State.
The covenant also provides:
