States parties to the present Covenant shall take appropriate steps to ensure equality of rights and responsibilities of spouses as to marriage, during marriage and at its dissolution. In the case of dissolution provision shall be made for the necessary protection of any children.

The Family Law Act is quite clearly built on these two pillars which are set out in the international covenant. Hence, the bill introduced in 1973, upon which subsequent bills were drafted, was based on a series of stated principles, the first of which was that `a good family law should buttress rather than undermine the stability of marriage'.

PARA.TAB: The central importance of family was explicitly recognised in section 43 of the Family Law Act. This section provides that, in making any adjudication, the court must have regard to a series of factors: firstly, the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman, to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life; secondly, the need to give the widest possible protection and assistance to the family as the natural and fundamental group unit of society, particularly while it is responsible for the care and education of dependent children; thirdly, the need to protect the rights of children and to promote their welfare; and, fourthly, the means available for assisting parties to marriage to consider reconciliation or the improvement of their relationship to each other and to the children of the marriage. The parliamentary debates of 1974-75 indicate that these provisions were afforded considerable weight in those debates.

The other pillar of the Family Law Act is reflected in the replacement of the grounds of divorce based on matrimonial fault with a single ground; namely, the breakdown of marriage evidenced by 12 months separation of the parties. Two decades after the introduction of the Family Law Act, this pillar—namely, the divorce of the parties—remains the only operational basis for the legislation. The neglect of support for marriage and family is obvious. If government funding were the only measure, expenditure on the Family Court alone would be fourfold the expenditure on marriage education and reconciliation counselling. If the cost of welfare benefits for sole parents were added, the figure for the cost of marital breakdown in this country would be conservatively estimated—I emphasise the word `conservatively'—at some $3 billion a year. The neglect of support for marriage and family reflects the failure of will on the part of the Family Court and governments over the past decade.

I wish to comment on a number of aspects of this bill against the broad, general background of the underlying pillars of the legislation. The first relates to the notion of parenting plans which has been introduced to replace the terms `custody' and `access' in the current legislation. This arose as a recommendation from the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act in November 1992. In turn, the committee's report and recommendations were based on the Family Law Council's report entitled Patterns of parenting after separation, in which the Family Law Council said that the broad aim of a parenting plan was, firstly, to promote a wide acceptance of the idea that separating parents have a responsibility to cooperate in making joint decisions about arrangements for the care of their children and, secondly, to encourage the use of alternatives to litigation, such as conciliation or mediation.

These parenting plans have been introduced in the United Kingdom via the Children Act. They have also been introduced in a number of states of the United States of America. Whilst support from the Family Law Council was advanced for this notion in the report of the joint select committee, it is interesting to note that the Family Court was much more cautious in recommending parenting plans. The Family Court's submission suggested that parenting plans may not offer sufficient protection for children at risk. That relates to the proposal which has been advanced previously in this place by members on this side of the House that that aspect of the legislation ought to be looked at in more detail in another place.

This raises questions about the effect of divorce on children, which is quite clearly the intention of the legislation. The whole issue of the effects, particularly the long-term effects, of divorce on children was touched on in a book by Judith Wallerstein and Sandra Blakeslee which was published in 1989. This book was described as the first ever long-term study of children and divorce. In this book entitled Second chances: Men and women and children a decade after divorce, Wallerstein and Blakeslee reported that many of the children of 60 middle-class divorced families from the San Francisco area, which they studied over a 12-month period, experienced difficulties in education and social and interpersonal relationships. Many of the children felt intense rejection, anger and loneliness at the time of divorce. While some of them resolved these problems over time, other children who seemed to be adjusting well developed severe emotional reactions to the divorce 10 or 15 years later.

Wallerstein found that, 10 years after their parents had divorced, 34 per cent were depressed, could not concentrate at school, had trouble making friends and suffered a wide range of other behavioural problems. The remaining children were doing well in some areas but were faltering in others. In an article published in the magazine accompanying the New York Times, Wallerstein described the 37 per cent as a `powerful statistic' and declared:

SPEECH.PARA: It would be hard to find any other group of children—except perhaps the victims of a natural disaster—who suffered such a rate of serious psychological problems.
The publication of this research sparked widespread debate about the impact of divorce, particularly on children. That debate is continuing today.

PARA.TAB: I want to quote a couple of passages from the book which touch on this issue. In dealing with the notion of custody, access and parenting arrangements, there are some interesting observations not only in Second chances but in some subsequent studies which have been undertaken. In Second chances, Wallerstein and Blakeslee, in dealing with this subject, say:

Overall, the joint custody children resemble not so much children from intact families but rather children raised in traditional sole custody households. About half are developmentally on target, happy and spontaneous at home and at school, while an equal number are anxious, having difficulty with peers and showing symptoms such as insomnia, phobias, and withdrawal, not unlike children this age in sole custody. Joint custody does not undo the child's distress. The central worry for young children in both custodial arrangements remains the same: fear of abandonment. The creation of two homes, from the child's perspective, still adds up to less stability than the one home where mother and father live together with the children under one roof. Moreover, the transitions between the two homes can easily reinforce anxiety about constancy and reliability of people and places.

SPEECH.PARA: They go on to say:

Two years after divorce, children raised in joint custody households are no better adjusted than children raised in sole custody homes. Despite more access to both parents, joint custody children show neither less disturbance nor better social adjustment than sole custody children. Unfortunately, joint custody does not minimize the negative impact of divorce on children during the early postdivorce years. The custody arrangement itself exerts but a minor influence on the psychological adjustment of children. Other, more familiar factors weigh more heavily—the mother's anxiety or depression, the parents' emotional functioning at separation, the amount of conflict between the parents a year later, the age and sex of children, and the children's temperaments.

It is quite clear on the basis of this study that, whilst there may be some advantages in the sorts of arrangements proposed in this bill, it is certainly not a panacea to the problems created by divorce. Towards the conclusion of this chapter the authors say:

PARA.TAB: At its best, joint custody enables children to maintain a close relationship with both parents and to enrich their lives with membership in two functioning households. At its worst, joint custody can lock children into a destructive relationship with a violent or otherwise inadequate parent or into a continuing, bitter struggle between angry parents, so that the child runs the gauntlet in both homes—and feels that he or she has no home anywhere.

Worse, perhaps, joint custody exposes the children of divorce to a potential but devastating psychological blow: If and when a parent pulls out of joint custody, there is absolutely no way the child can attribute his or her loss to the parents' rejection of the marriage. The child can only perceive in his or her heart that the loss of commitment is really rejection of the child himself or herself.

SPEECH.PARA: Even though the terminology is different and they refer to joint custody, what we are dealing with is a notion which is picked up in this bill in terms of parenting plans. It is a notion which I think we will need to monitor very closely if this legislation comes into operation in its current form. There have been subsequent studies undertaken not only by Wallerstein but also by others in America. Time permits me to mention only one of these, but it does reinforce some of the matters which they found in the first study. A further study published in Pediatrics in review stated:

PARA.TAB: Although there was no clear evidence that children were better adjusted in either custody type, joint custody has highly related to more frequent access/visitation, and we found consistent evidence that children who had more frequent access to both parents were more emotionally troubled and behaviourally disturbed.

SPEECH.PARA: I interrupt that quote to say that the object of this parenting plan is that children can go from one house to the other and they can do so in a way which will mean they are going to be less emotionally disturbed. It is interesting that, as the authors expected, the studies found quite to the contrary. Therefore, it seems to me that there are real concerns about what is being envisaged in this legislation. I return to the quote from Pediatrics in review:

Children who shared more days each month with both parents were significantly more depressed, withdrawn, and noncommunicative, had more somatic symptoms, and tended to be more aggressive, according to the perceptions of their parents. Boys, in particular, were less socially competent: that is, their school performance, involvement with friends, and outside activities appeared to be disrupted by more frequent movement between parental homes.

The rationale for the removal of the terms `access' and `custody' and the introduction of the parenting plans and orders is the anecdotal evidence which is brought forward, and which I accept, that the notion of custody implies winners and losers, that is, somebody wins the battle for custody and therefore somebody loses the battle. Because of that notion, there are people who feel that they have gained something or who are bitter because they have lost something, namely, the custody of and access to their children. Therefore, that continues a cycle of aggression or bitterness between the formerly married spouses.

PARA.TAB: For that reason alone, I support the introduction of this notion, but with the qualification that the studies that have been undertaken indicate that this is certainly no panacea. They indicate that the object which is sought by this sort of change in the legislation may in many cases not be achieved and in fact the opposite consequence may be the outcome.

The other reason I support this legislation in general terms is to go back to my opening remarks about the twin pillars of this legislation, which involve both rights and responsibilities, and that over two decades the notion of responsibility and obligation seem to have been lost. At least this legislation is some attempt in a small way to bring back into the legislation a notion of responsibility which places on the parents a sense of obligation to come to some arrangement in respect of the children of the marriage. However, it is a very limited response and one which certainly does not go to the heart of the problems in the Family Law Act.

In the time available to me, I will touch briefly on one other matter, and that is the provisions in proposed new sections 14C and 14D of the legislation which encourage mediation and counselling. It is interesting that comments have been made about how this will improve the situation. If we look carefully at the wording of proposed new section 14C, we find that it simply says that a judge must consider, from time to time, the possibility of the reconciliation of the parties; and proposed new section 14D says that a legal practitioner must consider, from time to time, the possibility of the reconciliation of the parties.

It seems to me that, if one looks at the evidence of the Family Court itself, this is simply window dressing. Speaking in 1991 the Chief Justice of the Family Court, Justice Nicholson, conceded the failure of the supportive provisions in the legislation when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Originally it was thought that the court would play a role in the promotion of reconciliation, but the experience of the past 15 years has been that by the time that a couple approaches the court, there is little room for reconciliation, and such reconciliations that do occur are of uncertain and doubtful duration.

Here we have basically an encouragement to the court to do what it has already been encouraged to do in the original legislation. I suspect that this is simply window dressing and is not going to have any real effect in terms of seeking further counselling in a different form. At the present time, the counselling which is provided through the Family Court system is conciliation counselling. That is, the object of the counselling is to bring the parties together to mediate their differences through the divorce process and that they do that in a way that does not involve as much bitterness and perhaps does not involve litigation to the same extent.

PARA.TAB: Reconciliation counselling, which is aimed at reuniting the spouses, has been largely consigned to marriage counselling agencies. The bias against reconciliation counselling—that is, the bias against obligation and responsibility in this legislation or the way in which it has been enacted—is further reflected in the inadequate funding of counselling services. If we look at the funding of preventative programs, we find that marriage education gets just over $1 million and marriage counselling in the latest figures gets something like $15 million, yet we know that each year conservatively it costs the nation some $3,000 million in the costs of family breakdown, separation and divorce. There is no balance whatsoever in terms of providing the support for that other pillar of the Family Law Act, namely, the obligation and responsibility of parties to enhance, support and encourage marriage and family life in Australia.

In conclusion, I submit to the government that, if it is serious about bringing about some real changes that will enhance family life in this country, particularly in this International Year of the Family, it needs to address the other pillar which underlies the Family Law Act and not simply play around the edges of provisions. This is the most inquired into and examined act of law in Australia, with the possible exception of the Income Tax Assessment Act, yet here we are almost 20 years after the introduction of the Family Law Act and the same problems exist. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate on the Family Law Reform Bill [No. 2] to support the concerns of my constituents in Cowan who are suffering the trauma of marriage separation and divorce. In my electorate office the number of complaints about the Family Law Act and the Child Support Agency are second only to immigration problems. We have in Australia a major social and cultural problem—the breaking down of the Australian extended family and the associated community values system.

PARA.TAB: We should never forget the enormous social cost of family breakdowns to families and the community as well as the economic cost. Every day in our community, we witness the breaking down of family values, which can be directed to the laissez faire attitude we have towards the importance of the family. We are often reminded of the negative effects of family breakdowns in the attitudes and behavioural problems of our children. We have many community actions impacting upon the family. Through the growth of political correctness, we have stopped supporting the vital need to protect the need for the extended family and its importance to the community. However, the broader community needs to accept that family breakdowns, as uncomfortable as they make us feel, are a part of our evolving community, sad though it may be.

There is no doubt that the Family Law Act was long overdue when it was introduced in 1975. We had the situation where blame needed to be apportioned with divorce. There were many relationships that were not loving and even violent. It was an act which the community wanted and needed. At the time, on the figures available, to give an indication of the divorce rates, we could see that divorce law reform was needed. Prior to 1975, on a per thousand basis, statistics indicate that four women per thousand had divorce status. Soon after 1975 this increased dramatically to 19 per thousand and now it is steady at 11 per thousand. We now have in Australia about 45,000 divorces every year compared with about 120,000 marriages. Estimates are that marriage is likely to end in divorce in about 40 per cent of first marriages. In second marriages the likelihood of divorce is around 50 per cent and, if you want to go for the trifecta, the divorce rate is even higher in third marriages.

As traditional carers find new roles, the pressures of family life and financial needs during difficult economic times has meant that family breakdowns have become more common. Divorce is having a significant impact upon the community, and the most recent harrowing statistic was that single parents are one of the poorest groups of Australians within our community. It should be remembered that about 83 per cent of single parents have come from marriage. I pose these rhetorical questions: why is this happening? What are we doing wrong when we have these laws to help us? Or is the Family Law Act, so much wanted in 1975, beginning to impact upon our community in a very negative sense?

I and the coalition welcome family law reform because it is quite clear the current law is not effective for the community needs of today. It seems its time has passed and it is in urgent need of reform. This bill goes some way to addressing these urgent needs.

The 1975 act tried to reduce the process and costs associated with the divorce system. However, we have a system now which is complex, costly and focuses too narrowly on traditional litigation. The current system is an ugly adversarial system which determines, by perception, a winner and a loser. Yet I imagine that the reality is that all parties are losers, with the biggest loser more often than not being the children associated with divorce.

Ten years ago the biggest fear amongst children in Australia was a nuclear holocaust. They feared the bomb and what it could do to the world. Now reports indicate the biggest holocaust fear that children have is the parting of their parents. Divorce must be very serious if the children of our nation consider the worst thing they should fear is the parting of their parents.

Marriage is a marvellous thing. Most of us who choose to move into marriage do so with high emotion and mostly subjective decision making. We have no need for contracts or arrangements of property prior to going into a marriage. We do not recognise any of those things, because we are totally and utterly high on emotion and all we need is a certificate of marriage to legitimise our act. There is no need for counselling because we assume that love will conquer all. Yet the current divorce arrangements and the current rates of divorce illustrate that we need a clear view of marriage and its effect on ourselves and the community. The current divorce arrangements are very much a legal routine—something we never think about when we enter into marriage. As I said before, perhaps we should all consider why 40 per cent of first marriages are likely to end in divorce.

So love really cannot conquer all, but in relation to divorce the current act does. It is interesting to note government expenditure on these matters. For marriage and, in particular, premarital counselling, we as a nation invest the stunning amount of $1.1 million or thereabouts per year. That is a very stunning amount when compared with expenditure in other areas. Perhaps we should encourage greater participation by couples in a wide range of counselling pre marriage, during marriage and during marriage breakdowns. Perhaps consideration should be given to teaching young Australians not specifically about the dynamics of marriage but about the dynamics of relationships at a much earlier age. We put a lot of emphasis on relationships when discussing them with children in their teens, but we do not seem to be addressing the notion of education.

A conservative estimate of expenditure on divorce in Australia is a staggering $3 billion. We spend around $3 billion a year on divorce and associated matters, and only $1.1 million on marriage or premarriage counselling. This $3 billion figure is quite astonishing. Although I do not wish to play politics on this issue, it is important to know of this difference in expenditure as it continues the Labor government's idea of how to solve problems which is to spend money on the cure of the community ills rather than focus or attack the prevention of community ills. The government seems to throw a lot of money at the problems of social security, health and even Aboriginal affairs to solve them rather than being strong and convicted enough to develop policies of prevention.

I believe our community should be working towards keeping families together rather than promoting divorce. Although we do not go out of our way to promote divorce, we seem to make it much easier for people to move in and out of relationships these days. That is not to say that they should not. There are a lot of relationships that break down because they are violent or traumatic. I think we should be placing more emphasis on premarriage counselling, assistance and education. What assistance can we give to young Australians in developing their appreciation and knowledge of relationships? I think this can be directed straight back to education. I believe we are not doing enough in that area.

The splitting of a former loving couple does not end at the distribution of accumulated assets and the determination of the responsibility of parenting. It also involves the extended family. Grandparents do not stop loving their grandchildren because their children get divorced. Aunts and uncles and cousins do not stop loving their relations because someone gets divorced. Yet we seem to be ignoring these people when it comes to divorce. We have no provisions anywhere for grandparents to continue their relationship with their grandchildren. If a couple divorces, the extended family disappears.

I was at a committee meeting in Sydney recently on Aboriginal affairs, at which an Aboriginal woman expressed her concern about the breaking down of the Aboriginal extended family. I put the notion to her that not only the Aboriginal community but also the greater Australian community were concerned about this. We should be concerned about the breaking down of extended families. What is replacing extended families at the moment? None other than government services. Government services have a lot to be commended for, but I do not think they replace the notion of extended families and the benefits coming from them. Our current family laws do not consider these aspects of extended families; I believe it is time that they did. I am given to understand that some further reform of this act—other than through this bill—will occur either this year or next year when more reports are tabled.

The family law court matters relating to children constitute the second largest section of matters requiring settlement in the Family Court. It seems that children are the ultimate discriminated against group in the process of divorce. Yet we continue not to seek solutions which are beneficial to the children of broken marriages. This bill goes a small way towards addressing these issues; but in my mind the reform in the bill does not go far enough, and we as legislators should be treating this matter with urgency. Just as the causes of marriage breakdowns are multifaceted, so too are the methods we should be employing to reduce the negative consequences of marriage breakdown.

The whole concept of the Family Court is one based on conflict. We should perhaps review the court system; in particular, I question the need for the court at all and the high costs associated with running it at the moment. For instance, why are we not placing more emphasis on mediation to seek solutions rather than on a court process which increases costs and places huge demands on legal aid, which usually goes to only one of the people requiring the divorce. Legal aid cannot go to both people requiring a divorce. That process leads to an adversarial system.

We place too much emphasis on judges having the wisdom of Solomon when it comes to the best future prospects of the child. These judges may be great property arbiters, but what qualities do they have above others when it comes to human relations? Of course, they are only humans themselves and they do not have the great wisdom of Solomon.

The biggest challenge we are faced with is the custody provisions of the family law. That is indicated by the enormous file that I have in my office about these problems. Some of the proposals of the bill look directly at this challenge. In particular, the altering of the perception of the terms `custody' and `access' is an important and highly relevant initiative.

The bill acknowledges some of the principles drawn from the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. The first principle is that children have the right to know and be cared for by both parents, regardless of whether their parents are married, separated, have never married, or have never lived together. The second is that children have a right of contact, on a regular basis, with both their parents and with other people significant to their care, welfare and development—which, I assume, would include the extended family. The third principle is that parents share duties and responsibilities concerning the care, welfare and development of their children. The fourth is that parents should agree about the future parenting of their children.

This bill addresses a number of these issues, but again I say that it does not necessarily go far enough. Changing terminologies and introducing parenting plans and parenting orders, all with the best interests of the child in mind, is good but it is not enough. The bill is not a panacea for the difficulties of the family law in Australia; however, it does go some way in charting a new direction, and we desperately need a renewed system.

The effectiveness of legislation in changing people's attitudes and behaviours is often disputed. We should be aiming to ensure that, in the wider community, there is occurring a wider attitudinal change in the way we view marriage and, more particularly, marriage breakdowns.

I strongly concur with my colleagues, in particular the member for Chifley (Mr Price), the chair of the parliamentary committee reviewing further the current system. The member for Chifley clearly calls for more to be done in the review and ultimate reform of the act. This bill is worth while as it begins this process. I support its intentions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the first thing that needs to be said is that considerable resources go towards our attempts to redress the effects of the breakdown of marriage, yet little is spent on counselling services at the beginning of the process. Many members have today spoken on that matter; I think it is almost paramount. Perhaps what is even worse is that less money is spent by government on the enrichment and support of marriage, whereas we can find all sorts of minority groups in the community to whom we can direct special and targeted resources. As a short preamble to my contribution, I make an appeal this afternoon for organisations like Centrecare, Anglican Family Care and, of course, similar bodies in the other churches, and community organisations which provide an immense yet often unrecognised contribution in family support matters.

PARA.TAB: I share with the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) a sadness that so much emphasis is given to alternative lifestyles and so little to the traditional family. Notwithstanding this unfortunate trend, we have to accept that separation, divorce and break-up of families become sad facts of life. It is in that spirit that I would like to make a small contribution to the debate on the Family Law Reform Bill [No. 2].

In my electorate office, matters of access and custody, along with the associated area of child support, would rank with social security as the greatest single items of constituent concern. It is a sad commentary on our so-called enlightened society that one-third of all marriages end in divorce and that 60 per cent of those divorces involve children. In 1993, almost 50,000 children under the age of 18 years were involved with divorce. The fact that there were 15,000 custody and guardianship applications processed in 1992-93 and nearly another 15,000 access applications indicates the depth of the problem.

I commend aspects of this bill which go to the heart of dispute resolution. I have seen so many horrific cases of separated parents indulging in a totally self-destructive process of custody and access orders and property settlements. What is even worse is that the process becomes so bitter and vindictive that the ability of the former parents to rebuild their own lives is itself destroyed. As one associate of mine has said, the situation becomes a benefit for the lawyers and a desert for the children.

So often we hear of cases of the breadwinner arriving home at night to find the family home totally denuded, the spouse and the children gone. Often the spouse who leaves the matrimonial home is advised to be as inaccessible as possible for as long as possible. Sadly, there are lawyers around who give that sort of advice. The premise for this is that, if you can keep yourself hidden away for a while, you will establish some sort of de facto recognition of the fact that you are the best custodian of the children. Eventually, the departing spouse is found and the totally corrosive tit for tat contest ensues.

Several speakers in this debate today have said that the children of these broken marriages are little more than goods and chattels, and indeed they are. Possessions—not love, affection, certainty and stability—have become all important in these contests. I have even seen cases which, to my horror, have involved one spouse, through some totally Machiavellian advice, being advised to accuse the other partner of sexual abuse of the children.

I have had a leading citizen of Bundaberg in tears in my office—a man with a completely unblemished record, totally convulsed in tears and absolutely devastated by the fact that, as a final vindictive act of separation, his former wife accused him of the sexual abuse of his children. She did this quite callously with a view to making his life as hard as possible while he was trying to rebuild it and have reasonable access to his children.

While we are dealing with this matter, I look forward longingly to the completion of the report on the Child Support Agency and to new mechanisms to see whether some of the abuses and injustices in that system can be ironed out. As I have said, custody and access and the Child Support Agency are often inexorably connected.

I call to mind one particular constituent of mine, Mr Curnuck, who has been to see me on a number of occasions. His case is one of the saddest and most unfortunate I have known. I preface my remarks by saying that I am not just taking the side of the father or male participant in this debate; I am just taking a couple of examples at random to illustrate the sorts of things that go on. Mr Curnuck lived in Queensland, as did his wife, but she left and went to New South Wales. The custody and access hearings eventually came to court in Sydney. He had so little in the way of resources, his children having been snatched from his home, that he had to hitchhike to Sydney, often travelling by semitrailer, to appear in court. Despite the fact that his former wife got legal aid and that his children were represented in court, he received no legal aid and had to represent himself. This eventually destroyed his business—as a plant operator he had to be fairly mobile—and he virtually had to give up everything to contest this case. In addition to that, he again tried for legal aid, unsuccessfully, on the premise that he had little chance to win the case. I thought that the ruling was quite unjust.

Eventually, Mr Curnuck was reduced to living in a rented home in a small country town near Bundaberg and, although at the beginning of this dreadful process he had been able to care for his children, he was not in a position to mount a case for their continued care. His former wife, who by then had engaged in a new de facto relationship, obtained custody of the children, all bar one, and left him to a fairly lonely existence. He was also unable to obtain justice before the law.

This new bill has some pleasing features about it. I for one applaud the fact that it will facilitate the greater use of mediation, counselling and arbitration. I applaud the provision of mechanisms for community based counselling and mediation by organisations. I commend the expansion of opportunity for organisations to be recognised by the Family Law Act and the extent of the immunity that will be given to people who provide these services. I also feel that the mechanisms taking the adversarial nature out of the contest may prove to be a godsend in many of these cases. There has been some debate in the parliament today as to whether the change of terminology will do that job. There is at least some anecdotal evidence from the British experience that that might be the case.

I find one thing a little strange—I do not wish to intrude upon bipartisanship with this comment—that is, the government, the great promoter of international conventions, has not taken into account how badly Australia stands up under the United Nations Convention on the Rights the Child. I for one do not think such a measure should be necessary for Australians. But, given that we are a signatory to that convention, perhaps we should look at how well we perform under that code of conduct. Three of four key areas—that children have the right of contact on a regular basis with their parents and other people significant to their care and welfare; that parents share the duties and responsibility concerning care, welfare and the development of their children; and that parents should agree on the future parenting of their children—have not been featured in totality in our existing laws.

There are countless cases where there is no right of contact and where, because of the frailty of the court system, parents do not share the duties and responsibility concerning the care, welfare and development of their children. There are other cases where parents have not been given the opportunity to agree on the future parenting of their children. To that extent, I think the bill has a lot to offer.

I will not go over territory that has been canvassed quite adequately by both sides of the House other than to say that, in the cases I have cited to you today, had those mechanisms been in place—had a parenting agreement been required, had parents had to share the responsibility concerning the care and welfare of their children and had the right of contact been available on a regular basis—and enshrined in the previous acts of this parliament, perhaps we would not be where we are today. So, in a limited sense, I feel that this legislation goes some way to correcting anomalies that exist throughout the whole family law system and that we might see emerging from it a better lifestyle for the children and the parents in these broken relationships.

I would in particular like to commend one speaker in this debate. The honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) and I probably do not share much in common politically, but his views on these issues coincide almost exactly with mine. I think the costs of lawyers, property settlements, custody and access procedures and quality of justice are key issues that we should be looking for in all these activities. The rectification of the Child Support Agency and the enshrinement of a non-adversarial form of activity in decisions regarding divorce, parenting and the former access and custody matters should be paramount. I hope that, as further bills ensue from this matter, as the government has signalled, we will be able to attain a better regime for use by those young Australians who make up the third of all Australian marriages which break down and the 60 per cent of children who, up until now, have had an horrific and unstable lifestyle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst the Family Law Reform Bill [No. 2] does not put forward compulsory conciliation, I think it goes close and moves a step towards it. This measure has been needed for some considerable time. It follows from an idea that former senator Lionel Murphy introduced into this place. One thing I agree about with so many people in former senator Lionel Murphy's fan club is that Australia was never the same place after he had been in the Senate and moved the sorts of laws that he moved. What he did was facilitate people walking out of the marriage relationship upon a whim.

PARA.TAB: There are some very rare cases—I have not encountered them—where both parties are happy for the marriage to drift apart. One party is usually left heartbroken, with his or her entire life shattered and ruined. People teeter on the brink. I think it is very seldom that one of the partners does not contemplate suicide in marriage breakdowns. That is the extent of the devastation which is wrought upon one party, while the other party waltzes off into a fairly happy sort of situation. It is grossly unfair that the laws of the country facilitate this sort of behaviour. That they dramatically protect and facilitate the party that walks out of the marriage is deplorable in the extreme.

A lot of young people say to me, `Our marriage broke down.' I have a standard reply to them. `Yes, mine does too—about five times every day.' How ridiculous! It is a matter of whether people have a desire to and are expected to make the marriage work or whether they are quite happy at the slightest whim to simply walk. Today, at the slightest whim, people walk.

I suppose everyone has seen the children who are the victims of a broken marriage. I derive great pleasure every Sunday out of watching my son play football. As a kid, I very much appreciated the rare occasions on which my father was able to watch me play sport. I think there would be very few children anywhere in the world who do not appreciate their father taking them to the football, going shooting as we used to do in our youth, although that is probably not available these days in Australia, or doing whatever it is that makes things enjoyable: surfing, boating, going bush together—any of those things. If children are deprived of the love of a mother or of the presence of a father, I think they suffer greatly. There is no way that society can make up for the loss of one of those partners. This place should be condemned for the fact that it facilitated the breakdown of marriage in Australia and made it easy for people to do the wrong thing instead of helping people who want to do the right thing.

I think a lot of people read this week of the horrific case in the United States where a young mother murdered both of her children. It was interesting to read the history of that young woman. She had come from a broken home, and the father had come from a broken home. She had enormous stress upon her. Quite frankly, she could not pay her bills. She had a broken romance. Her own husband took no interest whatsoever in her. Her stress levels caused a collapse. Every day in Australia, in one way or another, people are failing to cope. Who can blame them for failing to cope with the stress levels placed upon them?

One of my first actions as a member of parliament was to get in touch with a young lady at a late night diner who asked to speak to me. She understood that I was in politics. She said to me, `I have gone hungry regularly.' I asked why. She said, `Because my husband walked out on me. He went on the dole rather than pay any maintenance, and in any event he took off and I couldn't find him. But I have had to raise our little daughter myself from the age of six.' She gets paid something like $15,000 a year, and it costs her $100-odd for a place to rent in Tully, which is the town she comes from. That leaves her with under $200. People need a car to get to work—that is, if they can get a job. If they cannot, they just have to exist on that money. She detailed the other costs, and it was quite clear that she had gone hungry.

Society does not have the money necessary to look after every single wife with a child who is abandoned by a husband. Husbands cannot afford to look after two homes. To carry two households on one income is nigh impossible. I will return to that shortly.

I deeply regret to say that, in my own home town of Mount Isa, our office has taken down the names of some 72 cases of violence in the last five or six weeks. Juvenile violence is a dreadful problem. I attended a public meeting which I called on the weekend, and people kept standing up saying, `The parents should be made to take responsibility for their children.' This was rather an intriguing proposition to put up because society has now made it illegal—in Queensland anyway—for parents to chastise their children in any way. Firstly, if parents physically chastise their children, they are liable to have the children taken off them. I will return to that theme in a moment. The only other way that parents can apply discipline is to apply some judicial mental pressure. Children in the state of Queensland have been approached by social workers and told that they can simply walk out the door and be looked after by the state if parents apply judicial mental pressure.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville), mentioned a case in a town in Queensland where, after a social worker visited the children at a school and told them that they could walk out if they were unhappy or were being oppressed at home, 15 of them—a significant proportion of the entire senior school—walked out. The social worker set up 12 of them in free accommodation with unemployment benefit or some similar benefit flowing to them. Not unnaturally, these people who owed responsibility to no-one for anything became little monsters who rambled around the town bashing people up. When someone interfered with their bashing activities—a father of five—they hit him with a steel bar and stove his head in.

Quite frankly, whilst they should be punished, I think the social worker and the legislators who were responsible for the creation of this society should also be punished. This is what happens if we tell a 14- or 15-year-old that he has no responsibility to anyone for anything and if he knows that no punishment will be applied to him.

We had a case in Charters Towers where a person had been up on seven convictions and had been away twice to the reformatory. He said that he really liked going away because the circumstances were a hell of a lot better than those at home. Subsequently, far from seeing it as a punishment, he said publicly to the journalist of a newspaper that that was his position. I knew the fellow. He was not a bad young lad. He just weighed it in the balance and felt that he was looked after a hell of a lot better in the reformatory than at his own home.

I know of a case in Charters Towers—for those who think I am exaggerating, I can provide the name of the family—where a child was caught thieving. The police took him home and said, `Your child's been caught thieving. The businessman is not going to prosecute.' The father gave the child a good hiding. Two weeks later he was caught thieving again. The police took him home again and the father gave him another hiding. It was not much of a hiding, because the social worker turned up and took the child to the doctor and the doctor could not find a single mark on the child. But that was sufficient for the social workers to take the five children away from the parent.

The guru, the leading figure in social work in Queensland for many years, the dean of the faculty of social science at the University of Queensland—one of the four biggest universities in Queensland—was Sugata Das Gupta. He was a person I liked and admired greatly. He was a very courageous man. He fled from tyranny in India and was gaoled when he returned to India for having the courage to speak out against the oppression that was taking place in his home country.

Sugata used to say again and again to his social workers, `If what you do as a social worker breaks the parental bond and the parental sense of responsibility, duty and control, then, by definition, what you are doing is an act of violence upon society.' Sugata was right. Would to heaven that the people that administer social work in Queensland today had been educated by or had listened to a person who knew what he was talking about.

In the Charters Towers case, the father and mother turned up at my office and sobbed their hearts out, because there can be nothing more cruel for parents than to have their five children taken away from them. They were not educated people. They were not the sort of people who could contest in a court of law. But this couple were very lucky because it just so happened that one of their children not only happened to play and be very good friends with the daughter of the member of parliament for the area—me—but also used to stay often at our place.

You, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, as a person in this place who is a little bit enlightened about Aboriginal affairs, would appreciate just how much some of these people are treated as second-class citizens. For all the crying and howling of the paternalists on the other side of the House, when we really get down to it, they are the people who end up taking the kids away from the parents. We heard a lot of churches condemning this behaviour when we were in government in Queensland. I always used to think that was rather good coming from people who had taken three generations of children away from their parents! Any relationship those so-called missionaries would have had with the little carpenter in Nazareth would have been purely coincidental, in my opinion.

But the social workers in Queensland, the bleeding hearts club that is exemplarily represented in this House, are taking children away from their parents every day of the week in Queensland. They did it to this couple and they were terribly unlucky. It so happened that I knew one of the children and she was anything but an oppressed child. She was not the one who had been stealing; that was her brother. But they were good, outgoing, well-behaved kids, who said `Thank you', `Please' and called you `Mr'. They were good kids. But that did not stop the social workers, like the missionaries, coming in and taking the children away from the parents. Can there be anything crueller than that?

Mount Isa held a public meeting. There were about 120 people there and all of them stood up and said, `There should be more discipline.' I do not know how the parents can apply discipline; any effort to apply discipline results in their losing their children. I do not mean just physical discipline; I mean mental discipline, as in the Murgon case I cited earlier.

The parental bond is breaking down completely in Australia. There had not been a mass meeting over juvenile misbehaviour and violence in living memory in Innisfail, nor in Charters Towers, Mount Isa or Mareeba. All of those towns have now had mass meetings. I know that Bundaberg—the honourable member for Hinkler will back me up here—is another town that has had a mass meeting, but I can only speak with familiarity about my own electorate. I do not for one moment think we are any better or worse off than the rest of Queensland.

Juvenile crime is a rampant, raging fire out there. In one year alone in Queensland—I think it was between 1990 and 1991—juvenile crime leapt by 29 per cent. The geniuses who are sitting opposite and some of the grinning idiots who are advisers—I withdraw that term; some of the grinning people who are their advisers—have been responsible for the laws that have resulted in this statistic: a 29 per cent increase in juvenile crime in one year. Almost every single city in North Queensland has had mass meetings to deal with the problem of juvenile crime. We have the highest juvenile suicide rate in the entire world.

As I have asked before, who do we blame for this? Have the eskimos come in and created this situation in Australia? Let us blame the media. Let us blame everybody except the people in this place. The people give us leadership whether we like to think so or not. Whether we set standards or draw the line in the sand—I notice that statement has been used by many people in newspapers and letters to the editor over the last few weeks—is a matter to be determined in this place.

Let me conclude with another roaring tragedy in Australia at present. We had a problem some years ago where wives were abandoned, the husbands would pay them nothing and they found it very difficult to stay alive and to make ends meet. I have dealt with many of those cases over the years in my office. They were heartbreaking cases. The government moved to fix the problem—and that was a good thing. But, instead of swinging the pendulum back to centre point, the pendulum has now swung out widely in the other direction. I will cite this case because I did not believe it; nor did I believe the other cases that were coming into my office. I will mention the man's name because he said that I can—Mr Kerry Bolton.

One week Kerry's take-home pay from the railway was $147, another week it was $124 and another week it was nothing at all—zero. After he had paid his wife the amount of money that she was entitled to to look after the two children, after he had paid his tax, after he had paid the lawyers—he owed them money and that had to be paid off over a period of time—after he had paid his medical insurance and his union dues at work, he was left with that amount of money. It would really be a challenge in a place like Mount Isa to stay alive on $124 a week. That most certainly would be a challenge. Kerry is a pretty skinny bloke. Clearly, he is doing it very hard.

His wife has a clerical job. I would think she would be on about $20,000 a year. She is now married to a lawyer. I assume that he would be on the average legal income of a person of his age and standing of about $45,000. So that is $65,000. She gets $12,000 from Kerry. That brings the total household income to $77,000 a year. She is sitting on the coast with the kids, with a husband and a household income of $77,000 a year, while poor old Kerry is out there at Mount Isa trying to stay alive on $124 a week. He has no wife, no kids and, because of the laws passed in this place, he will live in grinding poverty for the rest of his days.

If Mr Bolton had held up a bank with a gun and someone had been shot and killed in the hold-up, he would have been sent to gaol for seven years, of which he would have been expected to serve 3 1/2 years. In 3 1/2 years he would be out, away and clean. He could go out, get a job, earn some money, get married, have kids and have a happy life. But, until Mr Bolton's kids turn 20 or whatever the age is—I am not too sure what it is—and he no longer has to pay this amount of money, he will live in grinding poverty. He cannot get married. He cannot have any more children. He is forced to live on virtually nothing. No matter what his income is, that is what is going to happen to him. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank all honourable members who spoke in this debate on the Family Law Reform Bill [No. 2]. There were many of them. It was, as evidenced by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), a wide-ranging debate, but I think it was largely constructive. I compliment all members who took part in the debate on the serious way in which they approached these very important issues, which are high on the scale of issues dealt with by this parliament.

PARA.TAB: There can be few matters of greater importance to the average citizen in this nation than those covered by the Family Law Act. This bill, dealing as it does specifically with issues relating to children affected by the breakdown of marriages and with mediation, is a very important piece of legislation in the overall scheme of things.

In summing up, I will deal with a number of the matters raised by particular members. I will deal first with the issue of mediation and so-called alternative dispute resolution, which in this piece of legislation is referred to as `primary dispute resolution'. We are seeking in this bill—I think it is important to understand this—to move away from the traditional way in which matters have been dealt with under family law legislation in this country. We want to move towards a situation where the parties own the process far more, towards a situation where it is not simply a case of the parties being processed through a court proceeding or, as some people have described it, a litigation model.

We want to move towards a situation where people see that it is in their interests—financially, socially and otherwise—to try, with assistance from professional mediators, to reach satisfactory accommodations so that they are not put in the position of having to go to court, with the attendant costs and stresses of that, and finally have a judge make determinations on particular matters when those determinations may not satisfy either party. Frequently that happens. We hear people say, `We went to court and nobody was satisfied with the outcome.' We want to try to empower people so they are better able to resolve their disputes themselves.

I think the suggestion made by a couple of members that some of this so-called alternative dispute resolution, mediation and the like should be compulsory flies in the face of the whole notion of mediation. The parties must come together with a degree of goodwill towards the process. I think compulsory mediation is a contradiction in terms. Certainly, that is the belief of the government and a number of the key players in this area. Although the government gave careful consideration to this, we have rejected the notion that in any way mediation be forced upon parties to divorce proceedings.

Having said that and having pointed out to the House how central we see the changes in relation to mediation as being, I deal with the suggestion raised by the member for Tangney (Mr Williams) that it should be put into the bill that consent orders be subject to the best interests of the child test. The Family Law Reform Bill, tabled on 30 June 1994, contained a requirement that consent orders be subject to the best interests test. The provision has been the subject of much comment during our consultations with the Family Court, the Family Law Council and the family law section of the Law Council of Australia.

In brief, the history of the matter is as follows. As I mentioned, the draft of 30 June contained the requirement that consent orders be subject to the best interests test. However, the best interests test was removed after representations by the Family Court and the Family Law Council as imposition of the test was not consistent with the purpose and practice of the making of consent orders. Critical comments were then made by some judges at the sixth National Family Law Conference in Adelaide in October and there was a call for consent orders to be subject to the best interests test.

The view of the Law Council was that consent orders should be subject to the best interests test and that there was a need to ensure that the arrangements made by the parties always be scrutinised by the court. Following that, advice was received from the Family Law Council on 8 November that the current drafting was, in its view, correct and that the Law Council of Australia misconceived the purpose of consent orders. There are, as one can see from this, many differing views and it is proposed that the Family Law Council's advice be accepted.

The arguments in favour of the current bill are, I think, very strong indeed. Family law is essentially a private dispute between the parties. The purpose of consent orders is to allow the parties to reach an agreement without going through the expense of litigation. Parents are usually in the best position to know what is in a child's best interests and concern about duress being used to arrive at a consent order can be allayed by one of the following. Once made, at least, a consent order is just like any other order of the court and the enforcement provisions apply. If there is concern about the welfare of the child, further application can be made to vary the parenting order, or application can be made under the welfare jurisdiction of the court.

Parenting plans are also not subject to the best interests test on being registered, but the court is given power to vary provisions relating to the welfare of the child if it considers that it is in the child's best interests—see proposed section 63E(2). Finally, the role of the Family Court is not to investigate each and every matter but to be satisfied that proper arrangements have been made for the child's welfare—see section 55A, for example. This is not an application of the best interests test but simply evidence that proper arrangements have been made. This requirement does not apply to de facto couples, but the Family Court has its ex parte powers.

It seems to me that introducing this test would fly in the face of what the government is trying to do through mediation. We want to see the parties owning the process, mediation agreements being reached between the parties and the registration of those agreements in the court. Obviously, if it were the case that the court would frequently, of its own motion or otherwise, seek to overturn agreements reached in mediation, then the whole purpose of the legislation in trying to reduce the cost to many parties of family law actions would be defeated. The government is not at all enthusiastic about the suggestion that these orders be subject to the best interests of the child test.

There was some suggestion that this bill would go to a Senate committee. That no doubt will be a matter for determination in another place. But this part of the package of reforms to the Family Law Act was, as were the other parts of the package, the subject of wide-ranging consultations from about 1991 onwards.

It is critical that we introduce this legislation at the earliest possible time. The reforms contain important changes in respect of not only children's matters and mediation but also family violence initiatives relating to inconsistent orders which were agreed to at the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General on 20 July 1994. It is certainly the government's hope to introduce this legislation at the earliest possible time. Given that the matter has been subjected to consideration by the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, I would have thought that every opportunity for airing views on this matter had been provided and that the matter ought to proceed to debate and finality in the Senate at the earliest possible time.

I conclude by again thanking all of those members of parliament who contributed to the debate. I thought this debate was dealt with in an appropriate manner, given the serious nature of the subject matter. I believe that we have in this piece of legislation a far-sighted and visionary set of laws which will ensure that the original vision for the Family Law Act, as set out by Lionel Murphy, will be taken a stage further.
