SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEVIS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill provides the basis for a more competitive mail system in Australia. It also sets the ground for continued improvements in Australia Post's services to customers by providing greater flexibility for offering customers choice of price and service quality options.

PARA.TAB: A key objective of the government's micro-economic reform strategy is the efficient and cost-effective delivery of services by its business enterprises. The bill takes these objectives forward by:
.reaffirming the government's social objectives to make a letter service available to all Australians at a uniform postage rate. This service is to continue to be provided by Australia Post;
.providing greater opportunities for private mail operators to develop value-added services and niche markets in express mail, time sensitive and higher value bulk business markets;
.furthering the commercialisation and corporatisation of Australia Post;
.providing for the prescription of performance standards in relation to Australia Post's mail services; and
.reaffirming that Australia Post will remain in public ownership to operate a national postal network.
Before outlining the detail of the legislation, it is useful to look at the reforms from a broader perspective.

The government's reforms recognise the importance of the uniform postage rate as the principle that allows for universal access to a postal service. This objective is shared by all countries, regardless of their different regulatory arrangements.

In recent years, Australia Post has successfully changed from a public service entity with a poor industrial record to an efficient, profitable enterprise that operates at the forefront of world's best practice and delivery service. As a result, Australia Post enjoys strong community support, particularly in rural areas, which rely heavily on the post as a community service. The benefits achieved so far are evident not only to the government, but also to Australia Post workers and consumers.

It is time to build on this solid base, while setting in place some changes to the regulatory framework to provide a continuing competitive discipline to ensure that services are provided efficiently and economically to Australian businesses and households.

The Industry Commission's 1992 review of the mail, courier and parcel industries found that entry barriers to the market were low and that vigorous competition already existed in the courier and parcel markets.

In addition to this direct competition, new technology options for telecommunications and electronic data interchange provide significant indirect competition to the written message market. With these substitute services developing, the current restrictions on competition based on the physical size, weight and the means of carrying a mail message are unduly limiting businesses that wish to access a range of communication networks.

Further reform is now needed to recognise these changes. The bill amends the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989 which provides the base for Australia Post's operations. Australia Post will remain in full public ownership, but will face competition in some new areas.
In the domestic market, some greater competition will be permitted in the letter market:
.Competitors will be able to carry letters that are charged at four times the standard letter rate. This is a reduction from ten times.
.Competitors will also be able to carry letters weighing more than 250 grams. This is a reduction from a 500 gram weight limit.

SPEECH.PARA: These changes are expected to open up greater opportunities for consumers and service providers in the large letter and express mail markets.

PARA.TAB: The operation of document exchange networks will be recognised in the legislation, by allowing the movement of documents within an exchange service. The collection and delivery of letters from a member's address to the document exchange service centre will continue to be subject to the exceptions to the reserved service.

The carriage of letters by a third party from one location to another location of the same organisation will also be permitted. This will give businesses greater flexibility to determine the best and cheapest arrangements for their mail deliveries.

Amendments will clarify the position of newspapers, magazines, books, catalogues and leaflets which are directed to a particular person or address. These amendments ensure that newspapers, magazines, books, catalogues and leaflets are exceptions to Australia Post's reserved letter service, irrespective of whether they are directed to a particular person or address, and whether or not they are enclosed.

The intention of the amendment is to ensure that the exception in relation to these items applies even if the definition of a `letter' or `standard postal article' in section 3 of the act also applies to the article. However, it is intended to ensure the reserved status of a generic letter under the act. By generic, I mean a mass-produced letter which has an identical message, an identical or unique salutation, and is addressed to a particular person or address. I table a series of examples of generic letters to which I have referred.

It is also intended that bundles—for example, packages or parcels—of catalogues or leaflets with a letter attached to, or included in, one of the catalogues or leaflets in the bundle, or as a part of the bundle, remain reserved to Australia Post unless another exemption in section 30 of the act applies. These changes to Australia Post's reserved services will be achieved by amending section 30 of the act.

The bill also establishes new arrangements for bulk mail interconnection. Letters that are lodged in bulk at specified mail centres that are equipped to accept bulk mail will receive discounts based on the transport costs avoided by Australia Post where an operator has undertaken part of the carriage. Discounts for interconnection will be subject to independent scrutiny by the Prices Surveillance Authority as part of the authority's review of standard letter prices.

In the case of a dispute between Australia Post and a bulk mailer on the interconnection discount, the Trade Practices Commission will have a role in investigating the dispute and providing advice to the minister on the rate reduction. Regulations will provide a power for the minister to direct Australia Post, if he or she thinks fit, to act in accordance with the Trade Practices Commission recommendation.

Turning to international mail, the government's intention is that charges are set commercially to reflect the costs of delivery.Currently, charges for mail exchanged between countries are set under treaty arrangements by the Universal Postal Union—a United Nations agency of which Australia is a member country. Rates are based on world average costs and bear little relation to the actual costs of delivery in Australia. The arrangements have meant that Australian postal users have been subsidising the users of higher cost countries.
The amendments will allow Australian companies to capitalise on growing international mail competition. The new arrangements are structured in such a way to ensure that:
.the government continues to meet its treaty obligations to provide universal access for letters; and
.that private international mail operators are treated on the same basis as domestic customers, once mail enters Australia.
The bill provides for the following changes:
.Outgoing international letters will be deregulated. This means that consumers will be able to use any service provider to transport mail for delivery outside Australia.

.Incoming international letters will be deregulated subject to a requirement that only Universal Postal Union member countries are able to lodge with Australia Post's network at treaty rates and other international operators interconnect on the same basis as domestic operators.

.To ensure that Australia Post is not unfairly disadvantaged by the requirement to meet the government's treaty obligations, the bill provides that Australia Post may return incoming international mail that tries to bypass the domestic delivery network or take advantage of low-cost treaty rates. I will be asking Australia Post to establish internal policy guidelines governing the exercise of these treaty provisions and to report to government on its compliance with these policies.

The benefits of competition are balanced by the government's ongoing commitment to provide for its community service obligations to make a standard letter service reasonably available to all Australians at a uniform charge, wherever they reside. Community service obligations will continue to be funded by a cross-subsidy on the letter service. This is an efficient and equitable approach that shares the cost of providing the service among all postal users.

It is important that all Australians have a say in what they want from a postal service. Australia Post's service to rural and remote communities will be subject to a parliamentary review conducted once during the life of each parliament. I will be asking the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure to complete the review by 1996-97. Representatives of rural and remote communities will be invited to work with the committee.

Australia Post is also to be made more accountable for its discharge of these obligations through an amendment that will require Australia Post to report at least annually on how it complies with its community service obligations.

As part of its community service obligations, Australia Post is required to ensure that performance standards for its letter service reasonably meet the needs of the Australian community. To reinforce the importance of Australia Post's community service obligations, the bill allows for regulations to be made setting out performance standards in relation to Australia Post's letter service. The standards may cover such things as mail deliveries, availability and accessibility of mailing boxes and availability of postal outlets. The regulations will not be made, however, until the HORSCOTCI review into Australia Post's community service obligations is completed.

The bill also provides for Australia Post's performance against the standards to be measured and reported on by the Auditor-General and for Australia Post to prepare a service improvement plan for tabling in parliament if standards have not been met.
To ensure that the reforms deliver benefits to consumers in choice of price, services and quality, the government has established a number of competitive safeguards that include the following:
.remedies against any infringement of Australia Post's remaining reserved services will continue to be provided through the Federal Court;
.other operators will be able to take remedial action under the Trade Practices Act 1974 against any misuse of market power by Australia Post or other operators;
.Australia Post will be required to publish annually aggregated financial data on reserved and non-reserved services, to demonstrate that there is no unfair cross-subsidisation of services;

.price restraint for the standard letter will be formalised by amendments allowing the minister to consider movements in the consumer price index as one of the relevant matters, when considering whether to disallow price increases for standard letters;

.the Prices Surveillance Authority will continue to monitor Australia Post's service prices on those areas of the letter market that are open to competition until price competition is achieved in any particular segment. Australia Post will need to establish a case that it is no longer dominant in a particular market.

The effect of these changes will be monitored closely and a further review of the remaining restrictions on competition will be undertaken in 1996-97. The terms of reference for the 1996-97 review will be consistent with the government's determinations on the findings of the national competition policy review, the Hilmer report. This approach reflects the government's view that a public monopoly must justify the continuation of its monopoly position.
In addition to these competitive reforms, the government is also introducing changes to further refine accountability and reporting provisions already in the act.

These changes were announced by the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) last year. These amendments are best seen as running adjustments to the accountability relationship between the government, as the shareholder and owner, and Australia Post.

Ministerial powers of direction that are exercised in relation to community service obligations, financial targets and dividends will be amended to require the direction to be laid before both houses of parliament within 15 sitting days. This amendment provides greater transparency for ministerial powers of direction.

As reflects the commercial relationship between a shareholder and board, an amendment will require the minister to consult with the chairman on the appointment of directors to the board. An amendment will also clarify the board's power to recommend an interim dividend, which reflects general commercial practice.

Secrecy of mail provisions has been revised substantially. Regulations dealing with the opening and examination of mail by authorised Australia Post employees have been brought into the act. This honours a commitment by the former Minister for Land Transport to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances.

Prohibitions on disclosure have been expanded to cover a broad range of postal information. A new provision will make it an offence for an unauthorised disclosure of postal information. It will also be an offence to use or further disclose information if the purpose of the disclosure is different from the original purpose for which it was disclosed. A penalty of two years imprisonment will apply for a breach of these provisions.

The bill also sets out the limited range of circumstances where access to postal information may be disclosed for law enforcement and national security purposes by Australia Post employees and former employees. Access to the actual contents of mail is not permitted under this act, except to enable Australia Post to fulfil its obligations to deliver mail and comply with Commonwealth, state or territory warrants.

The bill sets out the circumstances where an Australia Post employee may open or examine mail. For example, these purposes include repairing mail, to obtain sufficient information to deliver the mail, or to destroy dangerous articles to protect public safety.
Australia Post will also be required to report annually on the number of enquiries it receives from agencies seeking access to postal information.

A number of other amendments reflect changes to Australia Post's operations, recognising that Australia Post has been made subject to state and territory laws. Other changes update references to the Companies Act 1989 to refer to Corporations Law and clarify the board's power to set terms and conditions covering the retail sale of postage stamps by post office agents and licensees. The latter amendment is needed to support the uniform pricing policy for standard letters.

Consequential amendments are proposed to part VIIA of the Crimes Act 1914 postal offence provisions to prescribe the carriage of certain dangerous goods. These changes are needed for public safety requirements to bring Australia Post into line with international aviation security standards.

Consumers and businesses have received substantial benefits from government reforms in telecommunications, aviation and the waterfront. This bill extends the industry reform process in the postal sector, and sets the framework for further improvements to customer service, choice and service quality while safeguarding the basic letter service. I commend the bill to the Committee and the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the parliamentary secretary's speech, implicitly he sought leave to table certain documents.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak on this Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill, having opened two or three post shops, as they are known now, in my electorate over the last few weeks. I am reminded of the historical role that Australia Post has played in our history, even to the point where the state manager was advising me that the expertise of Australia Post is now sought overseas. I am sure most members would share with me the experience that whenever a post office is under threat of closure members are sure to get a number of phone calls about the concern. Therefore, the role that Australia Post plays in all of our lives is very important.

PARA.TAB: This bill implements the government's response to the Industry Commission's Report on the efficiency of mail, courier and parcel services industries. It lowers the price and weight of Australia Post reserved services protection. It also opens up incoming and outgoing international mail to greater competition and provides for more flexible interconnection arrangements.

The bill requires the minister to take CPI movements into account when considering a proposed change in the rate of a standard postal article. It tightens Australia Post reporting obligations by requiring ministerial directions which vary financial targets, dividends or community service obligations to be tabled in both houses. Australia Post will also be required to publish in its annual report disaggregated financial information in relation to its reserved and non-reserved services.

The bill also sets out the circumstances in which Australia Post employees, former employees and other persons may open or examine mail. Finally, it specifies circumstances in which postal information may be disclosed, making it an offence to use or disclose postal information for other purposes.

The bill removes references to registered publications from the principal act. Australia Post will cease its registered publications service from 1 January 1995. The definition of `office' has been extended to include agents and licensees who have been given the responsibilities of post offices.

The bill removes from the definition of reserved services the carriage of letters between Australia and places outside Australia. Australia Post will continue to have the exclusive right to carry letters within Australia, irrespective of the origin of the letter. The amount that an international mail service provider pays Australia Post will generally be the amount set out in a convention with the sender country. If no convention exists, normal domestic charges, terms and conditions will apply. A new section will authorise Australia Post to exercise Australia's treaty rights under international convention to return mail to foreign postal authorities. That is, Australia Post may return incoming mail which tries to bypass the domestic delivery network or take advantage of low-cost treaty rates.

The coalition welcomes the deregulation of international mail services, but notes that it is only a partial deregulation. Australia Post will retain its monopoly over domestic carriage of international mail. Deregulation is subject to the proviso that only countries which are members of the Universal Postal Union, a United Nations agency of which Australia is a member country, are able to lodge with Australia Post network at treaty rates. Other international operators must interconnect with Australia Post on the same basis as domestic operators.

A number of changes are made to the exceptions which currently exist to reserved services in the principal act. The most important is the exception of the carriage of letters within Australia for a charge or fee which is set at a minimum of four times the rate for a standard postal article. At present the fee is 10 times the standard article rate, or a minimum of $4.50. The bill also lowers the weight limit of a standard article from 500 grams to 250 grams. Below this limit Australia Post has a monopoly on the provision of services.

The Industry Commission's report on mail, courier and parcel services released in October 1992 recommended a progressive reduction in Australia Post's monopoly on ordinary mail. Specifically, it recommended that the weight limit be reduced from 500 grams to 250 grams and that the reserved service rate be reduced to $1.20 from 24 January 1994—it is now November 1994—and thereafter progressively reduced at a rate of 10c a year for five years to 70c with a full review in 1997 of how the system will operate after the year 2000.

Overseas experience has shown that the gap between the standard letter rate and the reserved service threshold must be quite narrow before any effective competition eventuates. New Zealand Post indicated to the Industry Commission that its margin of 35c—less than twice its current standard letter rate of 45c—provided adequate protection of its core letter service from potential competitors. Australia Post indicated that its preferred threshold is five times the standard letter rate, and the government's response to the Industry Commission report, as evidenced by this bill, is close to this position. There is no provision for the phased reduction of the reserved service threshold as recommended by the Industry Commission. It is unlikely that the setting of the threshold at four times the standard rate will result in any significant increase in competition for the benefit of consumers. The coalition calls for greater urgency in the reform process.

The current blanket exception for catalogues and leaflets is to be removed and replaced by an exception for unenclosed catalogues or leaflets; enclosed catalogues or leaflets addressed to a particular person or address; and catalogues or leaflets enclosed in a transparent cover and directed to a particular person or address. These provisions mean that catalogues or leaflets not enclosed in a transparent cover and addressed to a particular person or address will be reserved for carriage by Australia Post. Concerns have been expressed that catalogues or leaflets enclosed in opaque or paper wrappers and addressed to a consumer will become reserved services. It is claimed that this amendment will widen the reserved services monopoly held by Australia Post by preventing its competitors from engaging in activities currently allowed under the principal act.

There is also concern that the inclusion of subscription notices with an otherwise exempt publication may render the package a service which is reserved to Australia Post. Such amendments may have a significant adverse effect on the business companies which currently carry such packages. Amendments were moved in the Senate by the coalition and by the Democrats to maintain the status quo. The government's proposed removal of the blanket exception for catalogues and leaflets would have unduly restricted current practices. Senator Ferguson pointed out in the Senate that the coalition was `seeking to ensure the maintenance of existing provisions and practices that still enable Australia Post to make a very reasonable profit.' The amendments put forward by the Democrats were agreed to by the coalition and by the government.

Let us move to contracting out and document exchanges. The exception provisions in the bill will allow organisations to contract out the carriage of letters between offices of the same organisation. An exception will be inserted to allow the movement of documents as part of a document exchange service. However, documents could no longer be carried from one document exchange service to another, nor could they be delivered directly to the addresses of the individual members, even though this practice has been widespread for some years.

Ausdoc, a major national document exchange service, has expressed concerns that the provisions applying to document exchange and internal mail will reduce its ability to provide its current level of service. It is concerned that it will no longer be able to provide a courier service between its clients' offices and its document exchange service centres. Ausdoc is also concerned that the strict definition of the word `organisation' contained in the bill will prevent it from continuing to offer government and private business a courier service which is competitive with Australia Post. Ausdoc is further concerned that the requirement in the bill that it charge for every item contained in a satchel, according to the reserved services conditions, will prevent it from providing a competitive bulk mail courier service. In all three cases, Ausdoc contends that the bill will restrict it from continuing to provide the service which it currently provides.

The coalition will move an amendment relating to the service centres of document exchanges—that is, amendment No. 2. This amendment seeks to allow document exchanges to continue to provide to members an end-to-end service by providing an exception to reserve services for the carriage of letters to or from a service centre of a document exchange. The opposition regards this as important to maintaining the status quo—and that is all it is, the provision of an existing service for those who use document exchanges. The proposed prohibition by the government would only serve as another impediment to efficient business practices.

Concerns have also been raised over the definition of the word `organisation' in the bill. The Victorian government is currently investigating whether the definition of the word `organisation' will prevent it from using non-Australia Post carriers for interdepartmental mail. Once again, the amendment which I shall be moving on behalf of the coalition—amendment No. 3—is to ensure that current practices are not limited. The definition of the word `organisation' contained in this bill is excessively narrow and will mean that many businesses and community groups will not be covered by the exemption.

The amendment seeks to extend the definition of the word `organisation' in the bill to include related bodies corporate, within the meaning of the Corporations Act 1989, bodies with a common board of management, or those which carry on business or conduct operations under the same or substantially the same group name. As it stands, the bill does not treat a company and its subsidiaries as related bodies, and treats government departments as separate entities which may not, as a result of this clause, have a private contractor carrying their mail from office to office. Without the amendment proposed by the coalition, if the legislation is passed as drafted, letters carried between offices of an organisation may not be carried in that way. That may impose an extreme penalty on some.

Let us move onto the bulk interconnection service. The minimum terms and conditions for Australia Post's new bulk interconnection service will allow mail service providers, other than Australia Post, to transport bulk mail for final delivery by Australia Post. Australia Post must designate the mail centre where such articles must be lodged, and provide a reduction in its charge for the final delivery of the article, including a component based on Australia Post's estimate of the average transport costs per letter avoided because other mail service providers have used the bulk interconnection service.

The bill allows Australia Post to negotiate with a customer the agreed terms and conditions for the supply of a bulk interconnection service. Regulations will be made to enable the Trade Practices Commission to inquire into disputes about rate reductions, and make a recommendation to the minister who can direct Australia Post to act in accordance with the commission's recommendation. Private mail operators will be able to interconnect with the Australia Post system at designated mail centres and obtain a discount from Australia Post based on the transport costs per letter Australia Post has not incurred because it has not been required to carry the letter for the whole of its journey.

During July, Australia Post indicated that it would offer discounts of between 1c for standard letters and 14c for 250 gram letters per item on bulk mail which is lodged in the state in which it is to be delivered. It is questionable whether these discounts will entice private operators to take advantage of the interconnection provisions contained in the bill. The Major Mail Users of Australia have expressed disappointment with the interconnection rates.

The rates put forward by Australia Post must be approved by the Prices Surveillance Authority which, it is believed, is concerned that the discounts will apply only if the bulk mail has been transported interstate by the private mail operator, rather than applying to both interstate and intrastate mail. The coalition is concerned that the discount does apply to intrastate mail as well as interstate mail. The bill, as it stands, makes no distinction between the two, but the coalition will move, as amendment No. 4, that the rate reduction apply to intrastate mail.

Regarding the carriage of dangerous goods, a new part is inserted into the principal act entitled `Dealing with articles and their contents'. This requires Australia Post employees and others not to disclose postal information. Unauthorised use or disclosure of information or documents, unless made in good faith, is prohibited conduct incurring a penalty of imprisonment for up to two years. Other provisions cover the opening and examining of mail and the carriage of dangerous foods. These are not contentious.

In relation to other matters, a new section is inserted into the principal act preventing postage stamps from being sold at less than the usual retail price to ensure that Australia Post can meet its community service obligations to provide its letter services at a uniform rate of postage. The coalition will move to oppose this clause. It has been claimed by Australia Post that some postal agents and licensees have been selling stamps to customers at discounted prices. The agents have asserted that Australia Post itself effectively discounts by allowing bulk mail and advertising discounts. Even though special conditions apply to these discounts, the fact remains that they are available only to Australia Post post offices, and not to post office agents or licensees. Australia Post has a special advantage in being able to offer discounts which post office agents and licensees are not allowed to offer. Such a position cannot be supported by the coalition.

Both Australia Post and post office agents have said that the issue of selling discounted stamps is not a large problem. The provision in this bill allows Australia Post to take out a Federal Court injunction if there is evidence of discounting. Such a step would seem to be rather excessive. The coalition does not believe that bulk mail and advertising discounts should extend only to post offices run by Australia Post, and there would seem to be little evidence to suggest that such draconian measures are warranted.

Another provision of concern to the coalition is that which provides that the managing director will be appointed by the board, not by the minister, but that the minister may terminate the appointment of any member of the board. Such a degree of control is ludicrous. The minister will effectively have the power to intimidate the board. This sets a dangerous precedent which should not be tolerated, and the coalition will move amendment No. 6 to omit the offending sections of the bill.

A matter which the Industry Commission referred to in its report, but which was not dealt with by the government, is the issue of postal services in rural and remote areas. The Industry Commission recommended that, where roadside delivery is made only once a week, this be increased to twice a week. The coalition has long held the view that roadside deliveries should be made at least twice a week. In our regional communications policy at the last election, we made a commitment to increase the maximum once-weekly service to rural and regional Australians to a minimum twice-weekly service.

Despite the government's rhetoric, in particular the hollow boast contained in the 1994 edition of The Rural Book that every effort was being made to provide at least two services per week to those in rural areas, including those in the most remote areas, this is not happening. The government's neglect of rural and remote Australia is typical of its reaction to the Industry Commission's recommendations in relation to this sector. It totally ignored them. As Senator Alston pointed out in the Senate, the government has made it abundantly clear that it is not particularly interested. The coalition is interested. Accordingly, amendment No. 1 will be moved to enshrine a minimum of two roadside deliveries a week for those households to which a roadside delivery service is available.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government recommends the Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill to the Main Committee and urges the Committee to reject the amendments that have been foreshadowed by the opposition. I will have something to say about those matters later. This piece of legislation will bring Australia Post into the 21st century. It will put it in a position where it will be able to compete with other modes of delivery of information. It will also ensure that there is competition which will keep Australia Post up to a measure of micro-economic reform.

PARA.TAB: Since the government's 1988 government business enterprise reforms, Australia Post's performance has improved significantly. This legislation will improve it even more. Australia Post's performance has improved, not only in relation to financial affairs but also on price, service, quality and productivity. The pre-tax profit of Australia Post has increased by 540 per cent, from $46 million in 1988-89 to $249 million in 1992-93. A stronger result is expected for 1993-94.

Annual returns for Australia Post, including income tax to the Commonwealth, have increased from $4.6 million in 1988-89 to $162.7 million in 1992-93. Australia Post has provided for a dividend of $62 million to the Commonwealth for 1992-93. A $200 million capital repayment from Australia Post to the Commonwealth was made on 31 March 1994, and Australia Post is expected to make further capital payments of at least $100 million in the next two financial years.

Since 1975, the price of the standard letter has been maintained at an average of two per cent below the consumer price index and no price increase is expected before 1997. That is a very significant result over 20 years. Labour productivity increased by 5.1 per cent in 1992-93, which was a record, and 92 per cent of envelope mail was delivered on time in the last financial year.

Those are good results for a public corporation which has been put under considerable stress by informal competition. As has been mentioned by the honourable member for Grey (Mr Wakelin), one of those areas is document exchanges which, if they have been operating in the way suggested by the member for Grey—delivering from one place to another letters that were lighter than 500 grams or cost less than the required amount—they may have been breaching the law. I will return to the topic of document exchanges later.

The Communication Workers Union and Australia Post have negotiated an innovative enterprise agreement which will deliver further productivity improvements over the next two years. The union is to be commended for the work that it has done in ensuring that the changes that have occurred in this industry have occurred with the agreement and support of the work force. The agreement that Australia Post entered into with the union is a model agreement that other enterprises are copying.

The government considers that the further reforms in this bill will provide a framework for continued improvement in performance, while allowing Australia Post to meet the government's expectations in respect of its community service obligation. The bill implements a package of postal industry reforms and further enterprise reforms for Australia Post that was agreed to by the government in November of last year. These reforms build on the government's strategy of the micro-economic reform of key industries, continue the commercialisation process of Australia Post, and work towards changes that were recommended by the Hilmer report. The package continues the impetus for further improvement in service to customers, and offers greater flexibility in choice of price and service quality.

The Australia of the 1990s is well served by Australia Post and the workers in the postal industry. By any measure—comparison with its peers, improvement on the past or absolute measures of efficiency and productivity—Australia Post is a very successful undertaking, and the government intends to ensure that it continues in that fashion.

In response to the government's reforms, the board and management of Australia Post have stabilised prices, improved services, eliminated unfair pricing in loss-making operations and sustained necessary levels of community service to rural and remote Australia. I might just say that some of the worries that the coalition seems to have about the service to rural areas being, all of a sudden, dramatically reduced are really a little bit of scaremongering. Australia Post has had a long history of providing an excellent service to people in rural and remote Australia, and will continue to do that. The government has a view that these services are ones that must be maintained.

It might mean that, in some ways, there are changes in the way that deliveries are made. I think that people ought to consider that there are changes occurring in the cities, as well as in rural Australia. Australia Post has to be an organisation that can look to the future. In looking to the future, Australia Post has to look at different delivery modes. In the cities, that has often meant that post offices have closed and postal agencies, or Australia Post shops, have opened. Rather than having very large buildings, Australia Post has got down to smaller buildings in shopping centres. It has got down to having agencies in shopping centres, rather than post offices, which were often a long way away from where people went to do their business.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is still only one mail delivery a day.

—My colleague on the other side says it is terrible that in the city they have only one mail delivery a day. I suppose that, if he had been here a few years ago, he would have attacked his own party when it reduced the delivery service in the cities from two deliveries a day to one delivery a day.
—What about rural areas?

—The fact is that people in rural areas are now getting a delivery every second day. I think my colleague on the other side would agree that he probably spends more time in his electorate office ringing people up than writing people letters. Nowadays, people deal with their urgent business through those newfangled inventions called the telephone and the fax machine. Letters are things that are not as time conscious as they used to be, but we have to ensure that a service is provided.

PARA.TAB: Under the arrangements that Australia Post is talking about here, that service will be provided. The alternative is that we overload Australia Post with costs, to the extent that the price of letters or packages goes up so much that poor farmers or other low-income people cannot afford them. We will then see, because the price has gone up, people reduced to having less mail because they cannot afford it.

What we have looked for here is the sensible middle road and while people in the cities in the past would have said that they would like to have two mail deliveries a day, they have got on all right with only one mail delivery a day and people have made other arrangements for their urgent business. We ought to be looking to what we are going to be doing in the 21st century, not back to what we were doing in the 18th century.

I think that the Australia Post board and its management are responding to those things and that is what we have got in this bill. All this has been done while maintaining a fair and ethical commercial approach that recognises a need for profitability and shareholder returns, alongside a need for a customer and community service as an integral element of the accounting framework. At the same time, private sector competitors to Australia Post have provided valuable and valid competing and complementary services that have benefited customers in their own right as well as keeping Australia Post on its toes.

I might just mention here the question of document exchanges, which was raised by the honourable member for Grey. He seemed to think that one of the real problems with this legislation was that it was unclear what could happen to document exchanges, and he mentioned the question of Ausdoc in particular. One of the things that should be understood is that if people are delivering letters now, then that is illegal. If Ausdoc has set up a business that is delivering letters from one person to another and charging them for it, and the letters do not weigh more than half a kilogram and they do not cost 10 times whatever the cost of a letter is, that is illegal.

If the opposition is proposing an amendment that would allow some people who are already breaking the law to get some sort of redress by changing the law to suit them, then it ought to think about that again. But the government is willing to go halfway with these document services so that they provide the service that they are supposed to be providing, which is bulk movement of things within individual document exchanges.

The government gave specific consideration to the role of document exchanges and decided that the movement of documents within document exchange services would be exempted from Australia Post reserved services. The amendment to section 30 of the act will permit documents to be moved between members of the document exchange service from one location or another within the exchange business itself, but not between different exchange networks.

We are not going to allow people to set up another Australia Post. We are keeping the letter service within the parameters that are described in this legislation as a reserved service for Australia Post. Greater liberalisation would effectively enable those document exchanges to become other post offices and—we make no bones about it—we are not doing that. We are not doing that because that will put at risk the principle of universal access at a uniform price and it will put pressure on Australia Post's ability to maintain its community service obligation.

So my colleague on the other side cannot say it is terrible that we might be reducing services in the country and at the same time agree with his city based Liberal colleagues who want to see Ausdoc and other companies like that rip into Australia Post's base business. The opposition has to understand that while oppositions can propose all sorts of things, sometimes there has got to be an element of consistency. It cannot have one and not the other.

I think that the government's proposals go halfway and will ensure that Australia Post does become a competitive organisation. The amendments that the government has proposed are divided into two parts. Firstly, there are the postal industry amendments, which include Australia Post's obligation, the reserved service and the powers and operations. Secondly, the amendments refine the accountability and reporting arrangements, which we have not got at present, to include a tightening of the circumstances where postal information may be disclosed to law enforcement organisations and national security instruments. My colleague the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Bevis) went into that at some length before.

What we need to take account of here is that the government is saying, `These reforms are necessary and we want to have an open process here. We have put this piece of legislation to the parliament, we have got the agreement of the union and the Australia Post board to the changes and they seem to have been reasonably well accepted in the community. But we have also said that we want to see this reviewed in 1997.' So these things are not set in concrete; they are the way we go, we think, but we are going to have a review in 1997 based on Hilmer principles. That is the same approach that we have adopted in the telecommunications industry and we think that is a sensible thing to do. But we are not resting there. The government has also said that Australia Post will have to come up with performance standards and that those standards will be monitored by the Auditor-General. That is something that we have not had in the past.

As well, the government has said that in the life of each parliament it would like the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure to do a review. That gives members on all sides in this House a chance to have some input on behalf of their constituents. We are quite happy for a free and open assessment to be done on this because we believe that these reforms will be ones that will allow Australia Post to continue into the 21st century as a viable commercial organisation. Competition will keep it on its toes and the reserved business will give it a base by which it can provide a community service standard right across Australia, and that, we think, is one of the most important jobs that Australia Post has to do.

I might just mention at the end the issue that the member for Grey raised about how it was somehow terrible that the minister might have some power of direction of the Australia Post board and that the government might have some say in its obligations. I suppose it is rather peculiar that the people who own the show should actually have some say in what happens in the show. I would hate to think that the directors of Elders or of BHP were told by their shareholders what they had to do, and I am sure my colleagues on the other side would not think that was all that bad an idea. Maybe we would not have had John Elliott getting away with some of the things that it is alleged he was doing if the shareholders had had a little bit more say in what happened there.

The government is a shareholder in Australia Post, and that is what people should remember. The government is the shareholder, the minister holds the share, and because the government is the shareholder the government should have some say in the way the organisation works, because you can bet your life if it blows up you are not going to say, `That is all right, the minister had nothing to do with that.' The first thing you will be doing in the House is getting into the minister for communications and asking, `Why did you let this happen?', and if he ever stood up and said, `Look, it is the Australia Post board,' you would say, `Oh yes, but you appointed all the members and you can't hide behind the fact that the Governor-General did it, because you wrote him a letter saying who he should appoint.'

The government thinks that there is sense in section 41, which sets out audit requirements, requires the preparation of an annual report and requires that to be tabled in the House by the minister. We think there is sense in section 46, which requires the board to notify the minister of significant business activities, including the formation of subsidiaries and acquiring a substantial business or taking on a significant new business activity, et cetera. We think there is some sense in section 47, which requires the board to keep the minister informed of the operation of Australia Post and to provide some information or reports relating to those operations as the minister requires.

Those provisions reflect the government's policy to apply the same accountability and dismissal procedures to directors of all Commonwealth authorities and companies and do not provide the minister with any particular leverage over the board at all. The proposed amendment gives the minister the powers that anyone would agree the minister should have. The legislation in which these provisions will be given general effect, which is the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994, has also been examined by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which did not comment adversely on these provisions.

All in all, this bill should be supported. The amendments foreshadowed by the opposition will not add anything to the way Australia Post works. If the Committee passes this legislation and the House concurs, we will have given Australia Post a framework to continue to provide the service it does.

If we do not change the way Australia Post works, we will see some of the prophecies of its colleagues at Telecom coming true. We all might have seen some comments in recent months by Telecom executives that postal services were a thing of the past, a dinosaur; that everyone would have a fax machine on their hip by the year 2000 and that instant deliveries of letters would take place by means of the information superhighway that will connect to everyone's hip-pocket.

There is room for a plethora of services. The services that Australia Post will provide in the next century, which is only six years away, will be as significant, as timely and as reliable as they are now, and I commend this bill, which will allow that to continue, to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have appreciated the contribution of the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay). His experience of a career with Australia Post ought to be recognised. The opposition's concerns about rural mail delivery are not scaremongering; they are very real. Changes in delivery to rural people have already occurred under current regulatory reform, and I am particularly concerned that the amendments proposed and what we are debating here today will continue the momentum towards the demise of mail delivery in rural areas.

PARA.TAB: People out there depend on their mail delivery for their education, for the conduct of their business and for the delivery of their goods in order to conduct that business. Today I have brought with me letters from constituents in my area, north-west Victoria, where dramatic changes to mail delivery have already occurred. So it is not fair to make the allegation of scaremongering; it is already happening. The opposition's foreshadowed amendment is desperately flagging the need for the government to attend to the needs of rural people.

One of the recommendations of the Industry Commission itself in regard to roadside delivery was that it be available twice a week. The honourable member for Watson has referred to people in the city who have been asked to experience reform and change. That is true, but a delivery of mail once a week is certainly a much lower standard than a delivery once a day, particularly when the education needs of children, the conduct of business and the delivery of goods are dependent upon them.

It is true that political debate on the deregulation of Australia Post has not centred on whether Australia Post's exclusive right to carry letters should be totally removed. It seems to be generally accepted on both sides of politics that some degree of monopoly must be retained in the carriage of letters. However, in line with the recommendations of Hilmer, the exposure of statutory organisations of government to competition is recognised as a very healthy thing. Certainly, the people of rural Australia also recognise that fact because they also pay taxation.

So my plea today is to the minister. I noted in the second reading speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence, the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), that the government is committed to Australians having a say about their postal services, and that Australia Post services to rural and remote communities will be the subject of a parliamentary review conducted once during the life of each parliament. It has already been foreshadowed that that will occur through 1996 with completion by 1997.

I would like to urge today that the government and the members opposite give consideration to conducting that review, particularly in relation to its aspects of rural mail delivery, much earlier. Certainly it should be done next year, because there are changes occurring out there. As I have said, it is not scaremongering at all, it is real.

The member for Watson made reference to the way I conduct my office. Whilst it is true that I do make a number of telephone calls, many of those calls have been in relation to this very issue, and in relation to negotiations with the regional managers of Australia Post, who have been implementing substantial reform. I have had post offices close in the absence of a tenderer for a licence. As a result of that activity one of the largest shires in Victoria, the shire of Wimmera, can no longer boast a single post office. That is actually happening, and I would like to see those concerns addressed by the parliament a lot earlier than 1996-97. I would plead the case that the parliament give consideration to the actual impacts that these reforms are having.

Rural people do not want to ride on the back of other Australians. They are a fairly determined and resilient group of people out there: I think they have to be, to try to make a living out in those remote areas. But even though Victoria has a much denser population than other states in Australia, the reality is that in my electorate of Mallee, which embraces the two strong regions of the Wimmera and the Mallee—an area of 67,000 square kilometres—there are only 130,000 people. That is a density of about two people per square kilometre. In that sense, certainly compared with other parts of Victoria, it is a rurally remote area.

This issue is certainly very important to those people, and they take very seriously the removal of government services from their small towns. In a small town with a population of less than a few hundred people, a post office provides employment for one family—usually a family with children. If they are not there, that can then flow on and impact upon the school and so on. The repercussions are substantial, so I ask that the members opposite please give some consideration to people out there who are determined to make their contribution to the nation's wealth and who deserve some better consideration in terms of their mail delivery.

It is true that, as we proceed along the roads of development and advances in technology, the way we are going to conduct our businesses is going to change. That is true. But it seems that every time these advances occur, rural Australians have to wait and miss out on a service that is available to the people who dwell along the coastal fringes. This applies to telecommunications. A sophisticated information highway process may well replace the delivery of what we have been used to as communication in letter form over the last 100 years, but this is not in place in rural areas.

On Monday I introduced a private member's bill to the parliament to ensure that in their community service obligations the Telecom providers are required to address new technology. There is a certain amount of despair amongst the people in my electorate. Whilst they see their postal services eroding in quality, they do not see any alternatives being put in place. Being very brief this morning, I urge government members to advance to a much earlier time the aspect of the inquiry specifically in respect to rural areas; because, as I said, those concerns out there are very real.

I have had a huge number of constituents correspond with me on the matter. I will simply make reference to one constituent, Mr K. Cain. Mr Cain has a small enterprise atop the Grampian Mountains and he has had to suffer having his mail delivery reduced to one day per week, through a contract service organised through the Horsham post office. I have had some success in having his mail delivery suit him much better; it is not a formal process, however, but relies on private arrangements between him and an Australia Post contractor. It is an example in my electorate that the subject of part of the amendment that is being moved here today, that roadside delivery service be available at least twice a week, is an important issue. Mr Cain relies on that delivery for supplies to his kiosk. In the busy tourist season—in fact, at any time of the year—the Grampians area is an attractive place to visit. He relies on that delivery being one hour's drive from the main regional business centre in Horsham.

I conclude by reinforcing that plea. I want to know why rural people have to wait so long to have their needs addressed and urge a much earlier consideration of the rural service delivery than 1996. I thank honourable members in the government for their consideration on that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with the Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill 1994 I would like first to make some references to the amendment which the opposition appears to have considered to be the most important amendment, the one about which it is most concerned, and the matter which has just been addressed by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Forrest). That is the question of whether or not roadside mail deliveries, for which there is currently one service a week, should attract two services a week in terms of the recommendation which was made by the Industry Commission.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe that anyone in the parliament, whether from the National Party, the Liberal Party, the Labor Party or, for that matter, the Democrats or the Greens, or even the independent senator, would oppose the proposition that, as far as humanly and practically possible, services which are available to people in the more thickly settled urban areas, the metropolitan cities, the provincial cities, the rural centres, should be extended to those people who live in remote Australia.

I emphasise in connection with that, however, the question of practicality. I know that that recommendation was made by the Industry Commission. But Australia Post at the present time has, and always has had, the right to determine itself which deliveries would be made on the basis of one a week. Even if we were to include that requirement in the legislation it would not mean anything and could not mean anything, because Australia Post in the first place would decide which of those centres of mail delivery were once a week services in order to be increased to two.

I will make some more observations later about the general performance of Australia Post. I was very privileged, as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, to have ministerial responsibility for Australia Post during a period when quite substantial changes were made in its whole operation, particularly in the retail area. I remember the very useful and constructive negotiations which I was able to conduct then on behalf of the government with the union. I notice the union is represented by my former colleague, John Saunderson, in the gallery today—a person who we would hope will soon return, whether in the same constituency or another, and make another outstanding contribution to the conduct of the parliament.

We were able to pursue quite a number of very valuable and very useful negotiations. We were able to introduce very substantial changes without any industrial dispute at all. I know that more recently the Communication Workers Union, quite understandably, has drawn attention to a lot of the reservations which it still holds in connection with those changes.

I return to the issue of increasing once a week deliveries to twice a week. I have already given one reason why it is not practical. I was surprised that the opposition actually divided on this question, and only on this question, in the Senate. It is not possible, it is not practical and I do not know that it really addresses the substantial base of concern which was expressed by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Forrest)—that is, the general question about the adequacy of services for people in rural and remote Australia. If the service at centres which currently receive one service a week were to increase to two services a week, I understand that it would cost something like $5 million. Of course, that has to come out of the bottom line of Australia Post. I will make more reference to that later on.

Where is the concern for the service delivery points—such as households, farms and properties—that do not get a guarantee of one service a week? Why has that not been expressed by people who are speaking for rural Australia? Why did not the honourable member for Mallee, his colleagues and those in the Senate draw attention to the enormous scope of Australia and the widely dispersed people living in remote areas, which are incredibly difficult to get to. Apart from Antarctica, Australia is the most sparsely populated continent on this earth. Even if Australia Post wanted to provide one service a week, it would not be able to do so physically. In fact, if we required it to provide one service a week to some of those places in the wet season in northern Australia, we would break the law to do so.

Of course, we understand the concern on the part of the honourable member for Mallee and his colleagues about services to remote Australia. We have got to be sensible about it. The people in remote Australia own Australia Post the same as the other 17 million Australians do. That is their investment and they are entitled to expect that it will operate in a practical, efficient, proper and legal way. The proposition advanced, and the natural extension to that proposition, would offend against all of those requirements.

This is substantial legislation and I appreciate the fact that it has come before the parliament. Of course, the fact that it is being considered in the Main Committee indicates that the matters are not unduly controversial despite the fact that the opposition chose to divide in the Senate over a particular question. I understand that the opposition may not divide over this matter in the Main Committee. If there were a division, it would have to go back to the main chamber for determination. I hope there is not a division. It is not necessary, now that the legislation has been defeated in the Senate. The opposition did not get it through the Senate and it is not going to get it through in our chamber. We will not waste any time over that. One of the essential elements of this whole review—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about an earlier review? Why wait so long?

—On the question of review, I had ministerial responsibility for Australia Post. Australia Post is a national institution, a national corporation, a people's enterprise of very conscientious management. Australia Post, not only in connection with this area but also in connection with all other areas of its concern, is continually undertaking reviews, as it should and as it must.

PARA.TAB: I have no objection to parliament's undertaking any particular review at any time. Fortunately, that is one of the reasons that we exist. Reviews are one of the means whereby people can filter their concerns and expectations through to the parliament and the parliament can respond. Thank heavens we do. There could be a review by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure or whatever particular parliamentary body could best address that question. There is no reason it should not be looked at if it is seen as an issue of adequate priority.

We are all members of committees. In fact, I am supposed to be at a committee hearing now. I will guarantee that it is not operating as effectively as it would be, were I there. With the amount of work that we have to do in committees, we do have to determine our priorities, as we are flat out all the time. If there is a committee which can address that question and can fit it into its priorities, then I would have no objection.

One of the things that the bill does is to respond to and give effect to some of the Industry Commission's recommendations concerning increasing the level of competition in the delivery of postal services in Australia. Two particular provisions have been made in connection with that. The first one concerns price, and involves the protection from competitive postal services being reduced from 10 times the standard letter rate to four times. That is a very substantial reduction. I remember the extent to which we canvassed this issue at great length, covering all of the options that could have been available, not only arising from the Industry Commission's report itself, but also from the continuing consideration which Australia Post has, quite creditably, given to putting competitive pressures on itself, so as to make it respond more effectively to the need for efficiency, and to give it a more transparent capacity to deal with all of those competitors, and potential competitors, out there in the market. This is a very substantial reduction.

The other provision concerns weight. The limit has been reduced from 500 grams to 250 grams. That is a fairly substantial reduction. The government has more than adequately addressed the need for Australia Post to be exposed to competition and to respond to it. It has done that admirably. At least 60 per cent of the services being provided by Australia Post are already being provided in the competitive market. Many people, fortunately in decreasing numbers, think of Australia Post as being some great monolithic public sector monopoly, which is able to rip the people off, as a result of that monopolistic position. Not so. It just is not so. As I said, at least 60 per cent of Australia Post services are out there in the competitive market. Australia Post has performed very well indeed, and is performing even better.

When I had ministerial responsibility for Australia Post—I am not claiming credit for this—Australia Post's annual profit was about $40 million. By the time that my ministerial responsibility ended, it was $170 million. Fortunately, the people who followed me, especially my good friend and colleague the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee), have been able to maintain that momentum.

I note that in its last annual report, Australia Post states that it is now making an annual profit approaching a quarter of a billion—I think it was about $240 million. That is the people's asset. That is the people's investment. The people have a right to expect that, as with their own domestic investments, they will get a good return, and Australia Post is making sure that they do. We have got to temper all of our concerns about the way in which Australia Post operates with essential considerations of that kind.

I want to make a quick reference to the question of those community service obligations. Again, there is a whole range of ways in which they can be financed. One, of course, is from the budget. Australia Post has maintained the practice of cross-subsidisation. We expect those services to be provided, and if they are not profitable then Australia Post uses its profit in other areas in order to cross-subsidise. That is the way it should be. All firms do that.

There is for some reason an expectation that, of all business enterprises in Australia, only public sector enterprises are not going to cross-subsidise. That is an absurd proposition. It is said that the process has got to be transparent and should be taken off the budget, so everyone can know where the subsidies are. If we are not going to have cross-subsidisation within Australia Post, and if we are going to have cost recovery or subsidisation from the budget, what sort of practice would we adopt as far as standard letter charging is concerned? Will there be a distance charge, as we used to have, many years back? Or will we charge on a regional basis because we want to cost recover? Will we charge on a town basis, or—for God's sake—will we charge on a street by street basis? What an absolutely absurd proposition. What Australia Post has been doing is, of course, the correct approach, and I would hope that it will continue to do that.

The question was raised of the rural and remote communities. There is a guarantee in the provisions, of course, for the government to undertake at least one review during each parliament. That is built into the system.

I said I would take on board a lot of the concerns of the Communication Workers Union, and I am very conscious of the very responsible position which that union has adopted. Its organisers and advisers have always been more than prepared to enter into negotiations and to discuss the issues thoroughly. As a result, some very substantial improvements have been made which have been important to their own constituents, the people whom they directly represent.

I emphasise that Australia Post has become one of the most efficient—if not the pre-eminent—postal services in the world. A lot of developing countries come to Australia and ask us how to operate postal services. The Commonwealth of Independent States, the old Soviet Union, in restructuring its postal services, is seeking advice from us and looking at our model. This indicates that Australia can be very proud of its postal service.

I pay tribute as well to Maurice Williams, the chairman, and to all the members of the board: to Rae Taylor, the former managing director, who has now resigned and is chairing the coal inquiry, and to the new managing director, Graeme John, who came up through the system. Graeme John was one of a number of people who were being considered for that position, and as the managing director of Australia Post he is continuing the momentum of those important changes.

The Australian Postal Corporation was established in 1989. It pays all taxes and charges, as does any other private sector corporation; it also pays a dividend to the Commonwealth, and I have indicated what the bottom line has been for Australia Post over recent years. The restructuring of Australia Post generally reflects the government's policy and commitment to efficiency and the government's determination that the owners—all Australians, in this case—of public sector assets will get, firstly, the best possible return from them and, secondly, the best possible service from them. The board, the executive, the management and the work force of Australia Post, and the unions which represent the employees, are all of admirable quality. There has been enlightened cooperation from the union leadership and from union members.

It is not often understood that Australia Post employs about 30,000 full-time employees. I mentioned the profit increases that have taken place and the price of a standard letter. If the price of a standard letter had kept pace with inflation since the late 1970s when the old Postal Commission was established, it would not be 45c for a standard letter now: it would be about 70c. There has been, in effect, a real reduction in the price of a standard letter. That has been brought about as a result of efficiency gains and the productivity and cooperation of the work force, as I am sure Mr Saunderson would recognise and endorse.

The Hilmer report has often been referred to as in some way supporting the proposition that public sector business be privatised. Fred Hilmer has emphasised, and I want to emphasise it as well, that he made no suggestion that the privatisation of public sector enterprises—

PARA.TAB: This legislation now serves the purpose of introducing into the operations of Australia Post a number of very significant innovations and initiatives which have generally been talked through with Australia Post. While there would be some reservations, not only on the part of Australia Post's board and management, as I understand and appreciate, but also on the part of the employees of Australia Post, I think that they all come together in a very useful and important package to ensure that the service that Australia Post has provided to its shareholders in the past, and to the nation generally, will continue to be provided with increasing efficiency and effectiveness in the future.
