SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must comment on the usual colourful contribution of the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). I have to pick him up on a couple of points. Firstly, in terms of his earlier comments about referring matters to committees, he would be well aware that the minister gives those references and that it is not just a matter of a committee picking a matter up. Secondly, I was surprised to hear that he had ministerial responsibility for this area because he had made such an impact on the transport and roads area. That is the area that I was always haranguing him about.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the country areas, we are not just talking about wanting two deliveries a week, we are also talking about wanting to improve the quality of Australia Post's service to those remote areas that do not get any service at present. The honourable member also commented about the former member for Aston. There have been two members for Aston in history and both of them were in this room earlier. I am the only member here now. I am the one that will be staying here and I say that quite definitely.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—The honourable member will return to the subject matter of the bill before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the subject of Aston, let me say that I have 140,000 constituents. There are 42,000 houses. I have a large Australian mail centre and therefore the matters dealt with in this bill are very relevant to the people of my electorate and particularly the 6,000-odd businesses as well as the private householders.

PARA.TAB: This bill, the Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill 1994, is all about competition, or at least that is what the government tells us. In his second reading speech, Senator Bolkus said:

SPEECH.PARA: This bill provides the basis for a more competitive mail system in Australia.

A competitive, efficient marketplace is something that I and the coalition generally view as an absolutely essential element of any micro-economic reform agenda. I know that effective competition is also something that those many thousands of small and medium-sized businesses in my electorate view as a necessary ingredient for their long-term economic success. In the context of this particular piece of legislation, competition is central to achieving a much improved mailing system which will provide all Australians with the efficiency and service that they deserve. Therefore, as has been said, we support the bill, although we do not really believe that it goes far enough and we will therefore move some amendments which will at least improve some aspects of the legislation.

PARA.TAB: There is much support in the business community and elsewhere for the coalition's view that monopolies must be opened up as much as possible to a more extensive market competition environment. For example, in 1992 the Industry Commission report on mail, courier and parcel services stated that the greatest gains to these services would flow from `substantial changes to the legislative environment in which the services are provided in order to allow greater competition'. The Industry Commission stated that the monopoly afforded to Australia Post through its reserved services protection in effect restricts competition, gives Australia Post substantial market power and actually reduces the community benefits which would otherwise flow from increased competition.

The Industry Commission proposed that, through changes to Australia Post's core letter service monopoly, customers would have more choice, thereby placing more competitive pressure on Australia Post, and that Australia Post's opportunities to cross-subsidise would be reduced and new avenues for the use of technology and alternative supply methods could be freely explored. There is no question that over recent years Australia Post has made a number of moves in the right direction.

The other major contributor to competition policy has been the report by Professor Fred Hilmer, following the Hilmer Independent Committee of Inquiry into National Competition Policy. In simple terms, the Hilmer inquiry was asked to come up with a plan to make Australia more competitive and his brief was to develop a national framework whereby all business enterprises, both government and non-government, would be exposed to greater competition. Importantly, the Hilmer committee also had the agreement of all Australian governments.

Comments made in the Hilmer report which are specifically relevant to Australia Post related to regulatory restrictions and included the following views: that restrictions on the customer's ability to choose amongst rival suppliers should be justified by government; that proposals for new restrictive regulations should demonstrate that benefits outweigh the costs in terms of free competition; that existing regulation which imposes restriction on competition should be subject to regular review; and that reviews, when conducted, should be looked at from an economy-wide perspective.

Undoubtedly, where Australia Post is concerned, current structures are at odds with the thrust of the Hilmer recommendations. Consumers do not have any choice when it comes to posting a letter and I doubt whether the government can really justify why this is so.

The bill before the House sounds good. For example, it provides lower price and weight limits on Australia Post's reserve services protection, greater competition for ingoing and outgoing international mail and more flexible interconnection arrangements. The bill also requires the minister to bear the CPI in mind when considering a change in the rate of standard postal articles, tightens Australia Post's reporting obligations, sets out circumstances in which Australia Post can open or examine mail and details when postal information may be disclosed.

Those are welcome measures. So why do I feel more than a little sceptical when I hear in the second reading speech the government trumpeting that the Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill 1994 is a monument to competition?Why should we not believe this to be the case? I disbelieve this rhetoric because, in reality, I believe that the bill in some ways results in a widening of Australia Post's monopoly. Let us take a look at one or two of the examples provided by the government. The second reading speech made by Senator Bolkus states:

SPEECH.PARA: Competitors will be able to carry letters that are charged at four times the standard letter rate. This is a reduction from ten times.

Well, bully for him! In its submission to the Industry Commission inquiry, New Zealand Post indicated that its gap of 35 per cent, less than twice its standard letter rate, gives sufficient room from its potential competitors to allow it to provide a universal letter service. In other words, it was able to maintain its community service obligations whilst maintaining the gap at less than twice the standard letter rate.

PARA.TAB: In its 1992 report the Industry Commission recommended that Australia Post reserved services rate, below which it has a monopoly of carriage, be reduced to $1.20 in January 1994, and thereafter be reduced progressively by 10c a year for five years to 70c. Had those recommendations been instituted by this government, we would have seen Australia Post in much the same competitive situation as New Zealand Post has been since 1992. Here we are in November 1994 and the enabling legislation has not even been passed by this parliament. Not only that, but when Labor's reform mirage finally comes into effect, the commencing monopoly threshold will be $1.80, four times the standard letter rate, with absolutely no provision for progressive reductions.

For any business which wants to compete with Australia Post this means that it will have to charge at least $1.80 for the carriage of every item of mail, regardless of size, weight or destination. That is hardly an inducement for competition. This is a classic example of where the government is saying one thing—that it supports competition—but is doing another, when it has an ideal opportunity to get its act in order.

Another area highlighted in the Hilmer report which has direct relevance to Australia Post is the reference to public utility monopoly structures which restrict competition giving rise to a situation whereby the existence of a dominant public utility provider severely curtails competition. Of particular concern is the opportunity for these major public enterprises or utilities, such as Australia Post, to cross-subsidise a potentially competitive area from an area where they currently enjoy a legitimate natural monopoly.

Australia Post justifies its monopoly largely by claiming that it is taking on an unprofitable community service, and for this it has the privilege of a monopoly which virtually allows it to charge what it likes. I take up the point of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Charlton. Perhaps the government should pay Australia Post for its community service obligation and then throw everything else open to market competition.

Sadly, there are more of these mirage reforms contained in the bill. The introduction of interconnection arrangements is another clearly unsatisfactory area and one which the coalition amendments will address. By interconnection we mean that a discount is allowed when someone other than Australia Post carries mail over a set distance, thereby saving Australia Post costs. In relation to the necessity for the government to ensure interconnection, the Industry Commission stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The conditions of such interconnection must be fair to Australia Post and to the organisation seeking interconnection.

The Industry Commission recommended that interconnection with the Australia Post network be allowed under fair terms and conditions at any point between the sender and receiver up to the location of final sort before delivery to receiver. What we see in this legislation are interconnection arrangements which, for some inexplicable reason, relate only to interstate deliveries and the interconnection discount would only apply if the mail is delivered to one of Australia Post's bulk mail centres.

PARA.TAB: The point has been raised before by the coalition that there seems to be no logical reason why an interconnection discount should apply, for example, between Adelaide and Melbourne but not between Perth and Broome just because there is a state border involved. It seems nonsensical. Therefore, to correct what I believe to be a silly error in the legislation, the coalition has drafted an amendment. We support the interconnection provisions generally in the bill, but our amendment is there to ensure that the interconnection discounts apply to interstate and intrastate mail.

With regard to other amendments that we are putting forward, postal services in rural remote areas have already been expanded on at length by previous speakers. We want to amend Australia Post community service obligations to make it a requirement to provide a minimum of two roadside delivery services a week to those customers who already receive one delivery.

Issues with regard to contracting out and document exchange need to be addressed. For example, an organisation called Ausdoc, a national document exchange service, is concerned that the provisions applying to document exchanges and internal mail will reduce its ability to continue to provide its current level of service. One of the previous government speakers said that Ausdoc should not have been doing it in the first place, but the reality is that it is there; it is in the marketplace, and if it is a reality it has to be dealt with.

Ausdoc is also concerned that it will no longer be able to provide a courier service between its clients' offices and its document exchange service centres. It is also concerned that the strict definition of `organisation' contained in the bill will prevent it from continuing to offer government and private business with a courier service that is competitive with Australia Post.

Finally, it is concerned that the requirement in the bill that it charge for every item contained in the satchel according to the reserved services conditions will prevent it from providing a competitive bulk mail courier service. In all three examples, Ausdoc contends that the bill will restrict it from continuing to provide services that it currently provides. Our amendment is aimed at preserving existing practices at least.

In terms of the carriage of mail, we have an amendment that provides for a more complete definition of the term `organisation' which, if it is left unamended, raises questions regarding the non-Australia Post carriage of mail between offices of the same company which may have subsidiaries, or interdepartmental mail of governments. I believe the Victorian government, in particular, has some concerns on that front.

We have a fourth amendment concerning interconnection relating to that interstate and intrastate mail, as I previously mentioned. The fifth item on our amendment list is an item in clause 16, which we oppose, which relates to the section in the bill which prevents postage rate discounting for anybody other than Australia Post, as mentioned by my colleague the honourable member for Grey (Mr Wakelin). The final amendment relates to the provision in this bill which allows the minister to terminate any director on the board of Australia Post.

Basically, we support the legislation. Generally, we think that it does not go far enough but it is a move in the right direction. We have some amendments, which are not earth-shattering but will improve it in some ways. However, if the so-called reforms we see before us today in this particular piece of legislation are really an example of the commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to maximising competition in the Australian economy, I fear that the Australian people will face a very long haul indeed before we become truly internationally competitive. Of course, that is a prerequisite for the restoring of living standards, not only for today's generation but for future generations as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this Australian Postal Corporation Bill as a useful instalment on the introduction of competition policies for postal delivery services in Australia. Despite the scepticism of the opposition, this bill introduces four very important measures consistent with competition policy.

PARA.TAB: The first of those is to reduce the scope and scale of Australia Post reserved services by lowering the weight threshold on these items from 500 grams to 250 grams. The second measure is to encourage competition in value added services such as bulk mail, document exchanges, express mail and overseas items. The third measure is to reduce the protection on standard letter rates for Australia Post from the current $4.50, which is 10 times the standard rate, to $1.80, which is four times the standard rate. The fourth measure is to increase the proportion of Australia Post revenue exposed to competition from 40 per cent to 50 per cent. This is a very important initiative, phasing in competition policies for the delivery of postal services in Australia.

The honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) mentioned his scepticism about the significance of these measures. That seemed to imply that he would support a faster introduction of competition policy. The Committee and the government need to be aware of the international experience. We can learn from New Zealand, for instance, which reduced its price protection from 10 times to two times the standard rate in one step. This resulted in 600 post office closures over five years. It resulted in a reduction in New Zealand Post's net income from $31 million in 1988-89 to $5.4 million in 1991-92. It resulted in the imposition of an $80 annual fee for rural deliveries. In fact, the New Zealand government announced in June 1993 that the second stage of its postal reforms would not proceed because there was no proven benefit from further change. There is a lesson to be drawn from the New Zealand experience, and it is that phasing in competition policies in a managed fashion is sensible and it best serves the public interest. The opposition would be well served to understand the New Zealand lesson and experience.

This bill demonstrates the government's very strong commitment to national competition policies and the directions set out in the Hilmer report. Competition policies are an essential structural reform in Australia. In any system of production and distribution, competition is likely to enhance allocative and technical efficiencies. There is no better catalyst for continuous improvement in an economy with market features than competition for customers and revenue between service providers. Where users are able to choose between alternative suppliers, sellers of overpriced or inferior goods and services are likely to lose markets and profitability. Even the threat of entry by a new supplier can create competitive pressures. The threat of entry in the case of Australia Post, I believe, is a very important inducement to upgrading the quality and the efficiency of the service provided around Australia.

This approach has been the basis of economic reform in Australia since 1983. The dismantling of industry protection has exposed the traded sector to international market competition. The increasingly effective application of trade practices law has introduced competitive disciplines to the non-traded, services sector. The emerging framework for national competition policies will expose other parts of the non-traded sector—primarily government business enterprises and the professions—to domestic competition. This reform, and the public consideration of competition policies, should not be about public versus private ownership, but the huge differences in productivity between competitive and monopoly markets.

In February, the Council of Australian Governments, COAG, adopted the principles and approach of the Hilmer report on national competition policy. This represents the biggest bundle of micro reform in Australia in the 1990s. The pet shop galahs are already talking of nothing but Hilmer. The report recognised that, because of economies and distance, natural monopolies may exist in some industries. There may be some natural monopoly features for Australia Post in rural and remote areas. Duplication of these services, along with rail systems, electricity grids and gas pipelines is not economically feasible. The key to lower prices and greater efficiency in these industries is the creation of access for upstream producers and potential downstream competitors.

Hilmer recommended an open and transparent system of declared access to essential infrastructure facilities at fair and reasonable prices. Adherence to the principle of competitive neutrality would prevent governments from unfairly subsidising their enterprises in competition with private firms. Provision of third party access rights is an essential reform in all parts of the infrastructure sector.

In the absence of competitive markets, most of the productivity gains of public business enterprises in Australia have been realised as budget dividends for governments rather than price benefits for consumers. Railways are an excellent example of this trend. Between 1990 and 1992, for instance, labour productivity in the State Rail Authority of New South Wales improved by 12.7 per cent, Queensland Rail by 11.5 per cent, the Victorian Public Transport Corporation by 2.9 per cent and Australian National by 16.4 per cent. But the average cost of sending rail freight improved only at the margin. Costs to industry fell by 5.1 per cent in Queensland, 2.5 per cent in Victoria and only 0.6 per cent on the national line. With even more extravagant dividend stripping, the average cost actually increased in New South Wales by 5.1 per cent.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the large dividends and profits enjoyed by Australia Post will be reduced by the introduction of competition. The important thing, though, is that the price benefit goes not to government coffers, but to businesses and consumers, in the delivery of postal services. This is a very important micro-economic and competition reform for Australia. The government is phasing it in: not making the mistake made in New Zealand, but rather introducing a moderate set of reforms in the first instance with a review in 1996.
At its meeting in Darwin last month COAG agreed in general to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a package of reforms that comprises a regime to provide access to essential facilities such as electricity grids, gas pipelines, airports, rail networks, postal delivery services, communication channels and seaports.

The federal government is committed to the introduction of effective competition policies for postal delivery services. It has been declared in the COAG communique, and the government is delivering on that commitment. An important instalment is in this legislation, with further instalments and reforms to follow with the reviews in 1996 and 1997.

PARA.TAB: The government has now prepared a draft competition policy reform bill, which it hopes to introduce to parliament after the next COAG meeting in February 1995. The bill provides a framework for establishing when, and on what terms, access will be provided to essential facilities. If the owner of the facility and applicant for access cannot reach agreement, the matter will be referred to a new national competition council for the application of public interest considerations.

National competition policies will impact on other aspects of the public sector. It is intended to bring all government business enterprises, including Australia Post, under the coverage of the Trade Practices Act and competitive conduct rules. COAG will also have the opportunity in February to finalise national principles for the structural reform of public monopolies. These principles include the separation of industry regulation from the charter of public enterprises; the separation of natural monopoly elements and potentially competitive trading activities, a very important reform in prospect for Australia Post; the establishment of appropriate financial relationships between the owner and operator of the public enterprise, including rates of return, dividends and capital structure; and consideration of the need for community service obligations and the best means of funding and delivering these mandated obligations.

The removal of the shield of the crown and other pro-competitive reforms will inevitably diminish the capacity of government enterprises to cross-subsidise CSOs. Transparency is essential. Transparency is all-important. Transparency, in the medium term, should be delivered to the operation of Australia Post. The set of initiatives in Hilmer is a very important set of reforms. The COAG meeting in February is an historic opportunity for the states and the Commonwealth to reach final agreement about the nationwide implementation of these reforms.

Two reforms stand out with regard to Australia Post. The first, as recommended by Hilmer, is to end the cross-subsidisation of Australia Post services. Community service obligations should be used to maintain rural and remote area services at a standard letter rate, but they should be fully transparent. That is, they should be off government budgets. They should not be hidden in the cross-subsidisation practices of Australia Post, but should be fully exposed to the Australian taxpayers and public through budget arrangements for the payment of community service obligations.

The second important reform in the medium term is to continue the phasing down of the standard letter rate protection and the phrasing in of further competition. In this regard, the Industry Commission report in 1992 provided good guidance. I know that members, particularly the member for Wills (Mr Cleary), would be interested in the recommendations of the Industry Commission in 1992. At the very least, the commission recommended a minimum private letter rate of $1.20 and a phase-down over a further five years of 10c each year, bringing the standard rate to 70c and allowing competitors fair access to the Australia Post network. Competition under these arrangements, in the medium and longer term, phased in by a federal government committed to these reforms, is a good thing. It is good for consumers because it provides a diversity of service options. It provides competition in price, delivery, efficiency and basic notions of customer service.

Competition is good for business. It lowers business costs. The unit cost of business comes down and, as a result, we get an expansion in economic growth which satisfies the public interest across the country. In the internationalised Australian economy, competition—and these continual upgrading processes—is absolutely essential. If the economy is exposed to international competition in the manufacturing sector and some of the services sector then competition in the rest of the economy, including government business enterprises like Australia Post, is absolutely essential.

Even the threat of competition, as in the case of Australia Post, produces good outcomes. We have seen some of these things in the public sector already. Let us look at the example of telecommunications. Austel has calculated that consumers are paying $300 million less for telecommunications in Australia due to the basic duopoly competition between Telecom and Optus. The cost of peak-rate telephone calls between Sydney and Melbourne fell by 20 per cent between June 1992 and May 1993—a substantial improvement in price and customer service competition. And that is with a duopoly. Imagine how well the system will run and the sorts of benefits that will flow through to consumers and business from open competition after the next review.

Let us look at the example of airlines. The end of the shameful two-airline agreement, propped up by consecutive coalition governments in this country, and the introduction of competition saw air fares fall by 20 per cent from September 1990 to September 1993. This is a substantial benefit for business and airline consumers in Australia and a considerable attraction, as all the reports show, for the growth of Australian tourism industries.

The Industry Commission has produced a very interesting document, which I would recommend to all honourable members. It is an information paper produced in May 1994, entitled `Improving the efficiency of GBEs'. This is a collection of all the evidence and reports the commission has had about the impact of competition and micro reforms on GBEs. Its conclusion is very important:

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the inefficiencies which have been observed in GBEs are the direct result of lack of competition. For example, in the absence of competition, overinvestment in capital facilities can be supported by higher prices or low rates of return. Likewise, the absence of competition makes possible overmanning and other inefficient work practices which have often been characteristic of public enterprises. Consequently, the internal efficiency of enterprises may suffer and cost structures inflated.

The conclusion from a decade of Industry Commission research is that competition policies are effective in bringing down prices, improving work practices and improving the efficiency of the Australian economy, out of which we get a net gain in economic growth—essential in our internationalised circumstances.

PARA.TAB: Australia Post is absorbing some of these changes, but there is a lot more work to be done in the medium to longer term. Fifty per cent of the income of Australia Post is still sheltered from competition. Australia Post continues to be the only company entitled to carry letters weighing up to 250 grams for a price of $1.80 or less.

I was interested by the response of Australia Post to the Industry Commission report. It was entitled, `The government's decision and how we'll meet the challenge.' Towards the back of the document, the Australia Post managing director, Graeme John, started his overview with the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: The new rules add up to a challenge which will stretch us—but not beat us.

The commitment is there but it is still a little artificial to put these matters in such dramatic terms and conditions. The truth is that, under the arrangements to be confirmed by this legislation, Australia Post has the equivalent of a 300 per cent tariff as it would apply to the manufacturing sector. So I dispute the claim that the challenge will stretch us. The challenge should stretch it but the competition is not too raw and extreme at this stage.

PARA.TAB: If we had in Australian industry the maintenance, as the honourable member for Wills has often recommended, of a 300 per cent industry tariff, Australian unemployment would be double or possibly treble its current rates. Australia at that level of protection would not be able to force the sort of industry upgrading that is required to produce jobs and growth. These things should be put on as level a playing field as possible to make sure that, if manufacturing industries and service industries in Australia are being exposed to international competition, the introduction of competition for Australia Post is, through the medium term, just as rigorous and just as important in producing of reforms and improvements in the economy.

The impact of these competition policies has brought a range of responses across the country, as it has in this parliament. Last week Professor Hilmer invoked a plague on the houses of all governments, outlining his frustration—which I share—at the lack of progress in the introduction of his report and a framework for national competition policies. But the blame for this should be slated directly to the state governments. At the last COAG meeting they derailed reforms put in place, as recommended by Hilmer, by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear).

The Victorian Premier, with an absolutely astounding attachment to the lawyers, tried to freeze out competition in the professions, and to protect the Victorian Bar Association and his lawyer mates in Melbourne. This is an extraordinary argument from someone who touts himself around the national agenda as an advocate of micro reform. It is micro reform for everyone except the Victorian Premier's mates in the legal profession. The states were also united in some erroneous arguments concerning the impact of budgetary competition on their own budgetary situation. The truth is that in a competitive industry environment the profit margin is reduced by virtue of competition. As a result, the clawback into federal government tax revenue is a lot lower than the states have been speculating. That is a point that Professor Hilmer has now confirmed on several occasions.

If competition were to result in the privatisation of state enterprises, the states have argued that they would lose an income stream out of their monopoly rents and profits. The truth is that if they were to privatise, which is the practice and policy of some of the states, the income stream that they are losing would be built into the sale price. It would be factored in—not at the high rate of a monopoly market, that much is conceded—but an income stream would be factored in to the sale price, which they could invest in other business enterprises, or on investment markets to realise a return to their state budget.

I would argue that the question of federal compensation has been artificially inflated by the state premiers and their governments, for the purpose of holding back competition reform. We have seen, only yesterday, the resistance of the opposition to aspects of competition reform. In the main chamber, the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) was involved in a debate concerning the federal government's reforms for competition between private health insurance companies. The member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) outlined her resistance to competition for doctors and for private health insurance companies. The opposition and its colleagues, such as the Victorian Premier, Mr Kennett, have a very bad record on competition policies and competition issues. The truth is that competition is good for the country, irrespective of state and federal budget implications. The states should recognise that and they should support the phased introduction of competition policies, as demonstrated in this legislation.

Competition policy, and its economic growth implications, is not a zero-sum game. The whole economy benefits from micro reform, efficiency gains and the sort of growth that we need to compete on international markets. The states, I am pleased to note, have made some progress, isolated as it may be. Recently, the New South Wales government—after some delay but now to its credit—has introduced competition between private and public trains on the Hunter Valley coal rail haulage lines. That is, the government has declared the line as an essential facility but, consistent with Hilmer, has set up competition between public and private rail companies. Competition across the board should be accepted by the states, the union movement, the consumers, and the businesses of this country.

I look forward to the passage of this legislation and the agenda this government has launched, acting on Hilmer's report. Finally, in the national interest, I also look forward to some cooperation and substantial progress next February at COAG.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleary Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting to hear the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) genuflecting in front of the Industry Commission. I would have thought that was a bit like asking the Catholic Church for an opinion on birth control and basing a position on that. In fact, with his absolute obsession with competition—which is rife within the Labor Party—the member for Werriwa could fit very nicely on the Liberal benches. We have the president of the Labor Party, the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), here today, and it is most appropriate that we get to talk about competition today.

PARA.TAB: As for the discussion about tariffs, I do not know from where the member for Werriwa plucks the 300 per cent. Let me give him a little bit of education about tariffs. There is no level playing field. His government should have considered that. His government should consider the conditions under which goods are made in other countries, hence my child labour bill. In the context of the concern of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for Australian culture, those opposite should also think about those parts of our culture that are not up for grabs, that are not going to be given away, that they will stand up for and protect, and say, `No, that part of our culture stays and no multinational is going to commandeer it.' But that is another story.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Bevis) began the debate today. He pointed out that Australia Post enjoys strong community support and is an extremely efficient organisation. Therefore, why all the talk about competition? In fact, we are told, by one speaker after another, that Australia Post is one of the most efficient organisations in the world. Why is there the need for an amendment bill and why the need for further competition, as per Hilmer and the Industry Commission? After everything that we have heard, why does the member for Watson (Mr McLeay) want to argue that Australia Post needs to be brought into the 21st century? That is absolute rubbish.

Is the Labor Party simply addicted to the notion of competition? Nothing in the speech of the honourable member for Brisbane, apart from a vague and general reference to the role of new technologies in diminishing the activities of Australia Post, is provided to defend the government's decision to open Australia Post to further competition.

With all due respect to the honourable member for Brisbane, goals such as economic efficiency and consumer benefit need to be approached with caution. Honourable members on both sides of the House would be aware that such principles formed the very justification for the Kennett government's closure of schools, in both metropolitan Melbourne and rural Victoria. If I recall correctly, there were a number of members of the coalition who were up in arms about these efficiency driven closures. Down in Victoria, of course, there were plenty on the Labor side who condemned the Kennett government when it instituted these policies. Paradoxically, the Labor party in Victoria seems to have had a change of heart. It is now, through its financial management package, as hot to trot on the logic of efficiency as the Liberal Party is, so it has got a problem there.

Members can claim that these changes are, at worst, innocuous as far as Australia Post's interests are concerned, and, at best, a boon to consumers. But it is easy to see why some in the Communication Workers Union believe it is the thin edge of the wedge. It is all very well for the member for Watson to crow about an enterprise agreement achieved by the Communication Workers Union. He does not advise us, of course, that there are many within the union who are not happy about the changes. What the member for Watson also does not want to talk about is the fact that 4,000 jobs have been lost over the last three years. Is it via job losses that the member for Watson envisages the funding of Australia Post's community service obligations?

Why is the honourable member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) calling for greater urgency in the reform process? One wonders whether he has considered what might happen to heavily subsidised rural electorates if the kind of rabid competition recommended by the Industry Commission is implemented.

Australia Post returns a substantial dividend on its assets. This year it returned an after tax profit of $125 million, if the figures presented to me are correct. This profit subsidises Australia Post's community service obligations to rural Australians. All in all, it is a quality service that is provided. Australia Post admits that about 60 per cent of its market comes from letter delivery. Allowing competitors to carry letters at near the same price as Australia Post does will erode Australia Post's profit and place greater pressure on its ability to meet its community service obligations.

International mail freight provides Australia Post with substantial profits for its community service obligations. Removing the monopoly that currently exists would allow multinationals to cream off easy profits from the Australian postal industry—profits that quite rightly belong to the Australian people. Bulk mail interconnection would allow these multinationals, and other private mailing houses, to lodge all bulk mail and addressed junk with any specified delivery or mail centre, at reduced rates of distribution and delivery. Distribution and delivery are the costly sections of the postal industry. Interconnection with the Australia Post infrastructure amounts to unfair competition. It offers a subsidy to the competitor.

The government's obsession with competition really needs to be questioned. It is not good enough for the government to simply say it is better than the other mob while, at the same time, claiming to be concerned about fair play, equality and Australian culture, including economic culture. On page 5 of this morning's Age, there is an article entitled, `Culture drowned by US sports ads'. This comes in the wake of, and in contradiction of, the Prime Minister's much heralded cultural statement. It is a clear and unequivocal statement about the effects unbridled competition can have on the economic and social interests of a small country. In essence, the article claims that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian identity is being eroded by the effects of American culture swamping children through television advertisements . . .

PARA.TAB: I am not talking here in a jingoistic way about Australian culture either. If this has the effect of reducing the amount of locally produced drama, for example, as Mr Smythe from the Commercial Film Production Association suggests, will we consider that competition has been in the interests of the Australian economy and Australian culture?

I go back to the points made by the Prime Minister in his cultural statement. If competition is brought in and that erodes cultural sovereignty, that is something to think about. If that happens and statements are being made about cultural sovereignty, we are in a contradictory position.

By analogy, if competition means that Australia Post cannot subsidise rural areas and the people that the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) talked about do not have fax machines, will the honourable member for Watson be telling us what a great thing competition is? The irony in all of this, yet again, is that it is only honourable members of the National Party who rise in this House to question the free market and free trade position of the federal government.

The bipartisan addiction to the principles of competition pose a great threat not only to Australia's economic and social sovereignty but to its so-called commitment to egalitarianism and a fair go. Let us call a spade a spade and, instead of engaging in waffle of the kind produced by the honourable member for Watson, let us look honestly at the facts.

When the protection of Australia Post's reserved services is reduced, where does the money to fund cross-subsidisation of the kind the honourable member for Mallee alluded to come from? True to form it will come from job cuts, office closures, reduced services, reduced frequency of services and increased postal charges. They are the facts from overseas, from Thatcher's England.

The government will respond by telling us that this is all about restructuring—restructuring in the interests of efficiency. The problem is that a lot of us are getting sick and tired of this kind of restructuring. We are sick and tired of it in my electorate in the northern suburbs because restructuring has meant a loss of jobs.

It is instructive that hardly one speaker has put forward a comprehensive argument as to why Australia Post should face further competition. The kind of empiricism provided by the honourable member for Werriwa—and I think the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) might agree with me—is a particular kind of positivism. It is the point made by the Prime Minister yesterday when he tried to explain that the facts produced to support inequality in Australia were selective. I think the honourable member for Werriwa indulged in the use of selective figures.

The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) spoke glowingly about Australia Post before telling us that it should be exposed to competition. However, there was nothing in what he said that logically meant it should be exposed to competition. Why he did not bother to elaborate, I do not know. It is not just about financial return and profit for Australia Post. It is the social role that Australia Post plays that should be paramount in our thinking. The facts are as follows: firstly, over the last year within Australia Post, productivity has risen by 5.1 per cent; secondly, 92 per cent of letters were delivered on time—in Victoria 93 per cent; and, thirdly, Australia Post paid to the government a total dividend of $62 million.

In 1989 Australia Post produced a profit of $57 million. In 1993 it was $249 million, an increase of 400 per cent over that period of time. In 1993 Australia Post paid $273 million in taxes and charges to federal, state and local governments. Since 1989 approximately $914 million has been paid into government coffers. The government proposes further competition. The opposition demands more competition—more competition than proposed by the federal government. One wonders why. This is despite the fact that so much of the competition facilitated by the federal government has done no more than erode our economic sovereignty and diminish the social role of our public corporations. We are seeing that at the state level in particular.

As for the coalition's amendment, in essence it exposes the stupidity of this amendment bill. On the one hand, the government wants to expose Australia Post to competition and the coalition wants to expose Australia Post to more competition. On the other hand, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), in demanding that Australia Post maintains two deliveries to rural and remote areas as part of its community service obligation, puts forward really what is a contradictory position.

What a joke! When competition fails to deliver the appropriate social outcomes, the very defenders of competition immediately seek government regulation to solve the problem. It was the same story with National Party members and the World Trade Organisation bills. We have had orange juice delivered to us in the parliament recently. Again, that exposes the contradiction between the interests of the rural sector and our obsession with free trade.

The obsession with competition is truly out of hand. I simply do not understand, on the basis of all the arguments that have been put by various honourable members, why we are seeking further competition for Australia Post. The big question is: where will it really end?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My speech follows what was said by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary). If we expect what is now the 50 per cent revenue of Australia Post to be exposed to change, then the corollary ought to be freedom to compete in other areas. The strength of Australia Post is very important. The honourable member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) and the honourable member for Wills have both mentioned the effect of a decline in Australia Post's business on small rural areas and country towns. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would know what would happen, and you have probably seen what has happened.

PARA.TAB: Australia Post ought to be maximising government services in those towns. If Australia Post is going to be exposed to more competition through its traditional services, it ought to be able to compete in other areas. I compliment the government on Countrylink, which has given some post offices and other institutions the opportunity to compete. For instance, the post office in Narooma was able to adopt Countrylink. It was able to supply services from a variety of government departments.

If post offices can supply services from a variety of government departments, they are not only helping the local area, they are also strengthening the business of Australia Post. The Narooma post office was receiving $40,000 per year from Australia Post to supply services from Veterans' Affairs, Defence, Social Security, the Commonwealth Employment Service and a range of other government departments. It worked very well. It is still working particularly well.

I have visited the post office in Burra, South Australia. On its computer were 60 accounts for organisations, both state and federal, which allowed people to pay at the post office for rent for housing, motor vehicle registration and renewal of drivers licences. Consumers in Burra thus had the opportunity to utilise the post office, and Australia Post had the opportunity to increase its revenue through other businesses.

The post office at Huonville in Tasmania has a Medicare agency, as do other Tasmanian post offices. Medicare tried to avoid that facility spreading by telling me that it was worried about confidentiality. I went to Huonville, talked to the staff, obtained information from patients and doctors, and they all said that confidentiality was better preserved there than in some other agencies that are used by government departments. Because item numbers are used, confidentiality is built into the Medicare system.

I strongly urge governments at all levels to use Australia Post to a much greater extent and to take advantage of the fact that `post' does not necessarily just mean an item being sent. It can mean information being transmitted. The traditional post office can be used for that. Two or three years ago I visited Switzerland and saw how post offices can supply a wide variety of services.

For example, the local post office at Zermatt, a village where cars are not permitted to use petrol but use electricity, the local post office collected all mail and parcels from the railway station and delivered them around the town. The postal manager showed me a shoe box which contained a lot of money. I said, `What is that for?' He said, `We pay the pensions.' It would not necessarily work in Australia, but the post office people in Zermatt were taking the pensions to the pensioners in the village. That is an example of a government using the post as much as possible.

In Switzerland I also saw post offices which were combined with rail stations and neither had to close. We need this kind of initiative. If we are exposing Australia Post to more competition, we ought to allow it to compete more. I have had objections from my electorate to Australia Post selling cards. As far as I am concerned, we should not restrict Australia Post. If we are opening it up to competition, we should allow it to compete. It is a valuable business in every local area and it should be allowed to compete.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Bruce Scott interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to draw the lines in this debate. Marie McGrath-Kerr, who is Chairman of the Post Office Agents Association, has written to me. I have had a long-time friendship with her. I have also had a letter from Noel Hall, who is Manager of Brentford Square licensed post office, Forest Hill, Victoria. I respond to a couple of points they have made about clause 16 of the Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill. I think the opposition members have also responded to this.

PARA.TAB: Initially, the Post Office Agents Association was rather complimentary about clause 16. In fact, when I was convenor of the land transport and postal services working group of the government policy committee on transport, and when I was chair of the whole committee, post office agents made it very clear that they saw good reason for precluding licensed post offices from discounting stamps. In fact, I can recall the agents coming to see me and bringing examples of advertisements in papers. The licensed post offices were offering quite hefty discounts for stamps and this was, of course, competing not only with Australia Post but also with other licensed post offices. Apparently, in a submission to the Senate select committee, the Post Office Agents Association said:

SPEECH.PARA: In reviewing section 16 of the bill (proposed new Section 33A) the Association concludes that its purpose is to preclude LPOs from discounting stamps, for it prohibits the sale of stamps at less than retail price. The Association applauds this initiative as it will maintain consistency of approach in the distribution of postage in Australia and hence efficiency of the system.
Later on in the same submission, it said:

POAAL does not favour any activities which enable postage products issued or authorised by Australia Post to be sold at less than their usual retail price. Such activities undermine the viability of LPOs and can lead to uncertainty in distribution of postage products.
However, there was a change. In fact, Mr Hall, whom I mentioned before, called this a draconian power. He said:
It gives Australia Post draconian powers to crush the 7 licensees throughout Australia who are ALLEGED to be discounting stamps. There are 3,000 licensees in Australia.

Small businesses such as ours have made a massive contribution to the economy and welfare of the nation, risking our hard earned savings in doing so. I find it ludicrous for the government to support the demands of a giant corporation to overcome a minuscule problem.
Further, my friend Marie McGrath-Kerr, Chairman of the Post Office Agents Association said:

The section is also worded so ludicrously that a Post Office Licensee cannot give a stamp to, for example, his mother, without the potential for appearing before the Federal Court! Considering the significant financial investment by licensees in the postal network . . . is it too much to ask that there be a level playing field, i.e. same rules for Corporate Post Offices and Licensed Post Offices.
She also said
The draconian powers to be given to Australia Post under Section 16 must be of concern to all Members.

I certainly ask the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) to take that into account. I am not sure that either the Post Office Agents Association or Australia Post treat postage stamps in the way they should be treated. They seem to me to treat stamps as a good. In both Marie McGrath-Kerr's letter and Australia Post's briefing, it seems to me that stamps are treated as a good that is to be sold. What is a postage stamp?

PARA.TAB: I am inclined to agree with the union, which has talked to me briefly about this, that a postage stamp is a receipt which says, `Here is a receipt for a service that you have already paid for.' It is a receipt entitling a purchaser to a service. I have never heard of receipts being sold at a cut price. We need to take that into account. Australia Post can discount services that are being provided through licensed post offices if it wants to. Australia Post does discount its services, but it does not give people 45c postage stamps at the value of 30c, or something like that. The problem has been that we do not regard a postage stamp as being what it really is.

The answer to the query from Marie McGrath-Kerr whether a post office licensee can give a stamp to his or her mother without the potential for appearing before the Federal Court is—and this is the answer that I believe Australia Post would give—that the licensee can pay for the stamp. I was involved in running businesses for 25 years. When I took goods from the business I bought them so that it would be clearly shown just what I and my family had bought. Even if someone took a bottle of shampoo off the shelf, it would have been recorded as having been purchased. There is nothing wrong with licensees purchasing from their business—say purchasing from the post office a 45c stamp and giving it to the mother of the licensee. In a business which is properly run and uses that strategy, this sort of thing would not happen.

I do not want to repeat the points that have been made by other speakers. I simply reiterate that, if we are going to expose Australia Post to competition, we ought to perform the corollary, that is, allow it to compete, particularly in government business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill 1994 certainly drew my attention. The self-interest of one's own electorate demands that one has something to say on this bill. When the Industry Commission travelled through parts of my electorate in its deliberations prior to bringing down its report in 1992, I also had some involvement. Notwithstanding that, in the electorate of Maranoa we have over 180 postcodes, so I feel duty-bound to comment on this bill.

PARA.TAB: The bill implements the government's response to the Industry Commissions's Report on efficiency of mail, courier and parcel services industries. It was an excellent inquiry in which I had an involvement. When I heard that the Industry Commission was going to be holding public hearings in Canberra, Melbourne, Sydney and a couple of other provincial cities, I raised many of my constituents' concerns and, as a result of representation, the Industry Commission came to the western parts of my electorate. It was not until the Industry Commission travelled to some very remote parts of Australia that it understood that the mail not only gets delivered in capital cities but also gets delivered in remote parts of Australia where Australia Post has a responsibility to deliver mail.

In its findings the Industry Commission combines the need to make genuine reforms which would lead to reduction in costs to consumers, and the need to maintain and improve services in rural and remote Australia. The government's response to the Industry Commission report is not in any way as progressive as the Industry Commission report. The government has taken a piecemeal approach. It has adopted some of the recommendations in part, but in other areas, not at all.

The Industry Commission strongly advocated a reduction in Australia Post's monopoly. That was the overriding recommendation that filtered through the report. It recommended that competitors be allowed to compete for the carriage of letters for a fee of at least $1.20, that this rate be steadily reduced by 10c per year for five years, and that the weight limit for protected services be reduced from 500 grams to 250 grams. It was a progressive reduction, allowing competition to enter the market, and this monopoly area was not going to be king-hit overnight. It was a sensible recommendation.

The government has agreed to the weight reduction but squibbed on enhancing competition. This legislation will only allow competitors to carry letters for a fee four times the rate for a standard postal article. Essentially, competitors will be able to compete only if they charge at least $1.80 to deliver a letter. International experience shows that competition occurs only when the standard postal rate and the competition threshold are close. They have got to be very close together. They are still miles apart, and thus the likelihood of significant price reductions and service improvements is very remote. It is very important that, as price reductions occur, we see an improvement in the services as well, and that service is not sacrificed in the name of price.

It is extremely hypocritical of the government to wimp out of genuine reform. The federal government is demanding that states and local government embrace the recommendations of the Hilmer report, which is all about a national competition policy for this country. Yet when the crunch comes in Canberra the government fails to match rhetoric with action. We have only to look at what the federal government did with ANL when it comes to national competition policy. Here it is telling state governments to start to implement the recommendations or get on with the process of more competition where the monopoly services are provided by state and local government, but it will not match that rhetoric in Canberra when it has the opportunity to do so.

One has only to look at who are masters of this government to see that they are its union mates. It is the Bill Keltys of this world. The rhetoric is never matched by action. Quite clearly the government stumbled at this hurdle when it had an opportunity to implement more competition and introduce competition on a progressive basis. Quite clearly it lacks the courage and the fortitude to do it itself.

I want to touch now on some rural services, because what is conspicuous by its absence from this legislation is the recommendation of the IC report relating to rural mail services. The Industry Commission recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: Where roadside delivery is now only once a week, it be increased to at least twice a week.

I would have thought that a party that has tried to say, `We understand the problems of the bush. We are offering drought relief out there'—albeit at a very late stage of a natural disaster that is still wreaking havoc across rural and regional Australia—would have picked up that recommendation. All that recommendation says is that, where a roadside delivery is now only once a week, it should be increased to at least twice a week.

PARA.TAB: Mail delivery is an essential point of contact for those who live in remote Australia. They do not have milk delivered on their front doorstep every morning. They do not have the newspapers on their front lawn every morning. In fact, many of them do not even have an untimed local call to ring their local doctor, or their nearest town. They are charged trunk rates. I would have thought that anything that would improve access to service and the delivery of mail at least twice a week, as the Industry Commission has recommended, would have been something that was commented on in the proposed changes to this bill.

Mail in rural and remote Australia brings education material to the students who study through the School of Distance Education, it brings medical supplies, it brings food, and most importantly it brings contact with the outside world. The recommendation of the IC would have brought down an enormous communication barrier to those 3,000 households who currently receive only one roadside delivery per week. There are many thousands who receive no mail service at all. The industry commissioners recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government, in consultation with Australia Post, undertake a full and urgent assessment of the need for mail delivery services for those households not presently receiving a roadside delivery service.

To the best of my knowledge this has not been undertaken: a further illustration of this government's complete disregard for rural services and those people—very importantly, we are talking about people—who live out in rural Australia.

PARA.TAB: The main reason for more frequent mail delivery services is a very important one: the turnaround time for the lessons done by those students who receive their education through the School of Distance Education. With one mail service per week, students face a minimum of two weeks for the return of lessons that they do at home under the supervision of a governess or their parents—or alone, in many cases. It takes a minimum of two weeks for the return of lessons or assigned project material sent to the School of Distance Education.

This is quite unacceptable in the modern day. A Third World country would be doing better than that. Quite clearly, this government is prepared to see people who live in rural and remote parts of Australia still receive services of a Third World standard. Many remote students face hardships of such a level that average Australians would have no idea of them. They could not start to understand or appreciate the hardships under which some of these students are gaining access to education. The school is not just down the road. On many occasions it is 400, 500 or 600 kilometres away, and on a dirt road at that. The way their education is delivered is through an HF radio signal from a central point, often 400 or 500 kilometres away. The delivery of their lessons, their reading books, some videos and some cassettes is via the mail bag.
The submission to the IC inquiry from the Winton branch of the Isolated Children's Parents Association was very telling. I quote from its submission:

SPEECH.PARA: Out of the nine mail runs departing from Winton Post Office, two are twice-weekly and seven are weekly. We have forty-two children on these runs who receive their correspondence lessons from the Longreach School of Distance Education. The average turnaround time of lessons to Longreach and return, assuming the lessons are marked within a day of receipt is: for three of the mail services, one week; and for the remaining six mail services, two weeks . . . We would like to see all mail runs from Winton twice-weekly. The current weekly service is inadequate for modern education, commercial and social needs.

I might add at this point that next year, on 6 April, we will see the celebration of the centenary of the great poem and the great tune that we all identify with Waltzing Matilda, because Winton is the birthplace of Waltzing Matilda. On 6 April next year, all roads will be leading to Winton. Would it not be nice if we could see federal government members—people with the power to change legislation—going to the people of Winton and saying, `We have done something about your mail services,' and not just going there to be part of the celebration of the centenary of Waltzing Matilda?

PARA.TAB: I now quote from the submission from the Bourke public school in central north-western New South Wales which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Parents felt overwhelmingly that those children who had more than once weekly mail were benefiting more. Lesson material was delivered quickly, and children's return lessons are received more quickly so that didactic conversation between teacher and students is more efficient and effective.

At the time the Industry Commission was investigating this for the report, it was said that facsimile machines are often suggested as an alternative for the delivery of these lessons. Now these are used as far as possible, but are not really suitable for all material. We must also remember that many remote households have antiquated and unreliable telephone exchanges and limited access to electricity. So modern technology cannot take away the need for an efficient, twice-weekly at least, mail service for many of these people who live in remote Australia.

PARA.TAB: Contrary to the belief of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Bevis), technology revolution has not reached many people in remote and rural Australia. So it is most disappointing that the government has not accepted the recommendation which would have improved the delivery of mail. The great beneficiaries would have been the students out there in rural Australia. They are not only doing it very tough along with their parents but are trying to study and gain an education under very difficult circumstances.

It is also disappointing that the amendment which we moved in the Senate, and will be moving in the lower house, was not supported by the government or the Democrats. We gave the government the opportunity to support an amendment which would have picked up on that recommendation, which would have improved services to these students out in rural and remote Australia, but the government failed. So the rhetoric about understanding problems out there in the bush, as I said earlier, is not matched by the actions.

We felt this was the best possible approach. We support reform and greater competition as a means of generating cost savings for all Australians. Competition, however, will not work in some areas—in areas of low population in remote locations. They need to be treated separately and provided with assistance openly and transparently. That is what our amendment sought to achieve. We do not intend holding up efficiency goals, when those who are unlikely to gain from such progress can still receive improvements by dealing with their particular circumstances on a separate basis. We will continue to pursue this amendment and we hope that during the debate the government, and the minister particularly, will understand that they ought to put politics aside and look at what they could do for those students by supporting our amendment in this instance.

I would like to comment very briefly on something that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) raised—the matter of the licensed post office agencies of this nation. I, too, have met with the organisation that represents the licensed post office agencies across this country. I have recently received a letter from the Association of Post Office Business Agents, which is an alternative to the POAAL—the Post Office Agents Association Ltd.

I think there are still a great many differences between the understanding of the government and of the people who deliver these services through the licensed post office business agents. One of the concerns that the Association of Post Office Business Agents has is that it is not seen or accepted by the government as representing some of the licensed post office agents. It appears that the government only accepts one organisation as the body representing the licensed post office agents.

I would like the minister to look at the concerns of the Association of Post Office Business Agents, because it certainly has many concerns about some of the issues that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro raised, particularly in the area of discounting. At a recent meeting with me, the association raised the issue of discounting. There is certainly discounting going on out there, but the association indicated to me that it was not necessarily confined to the rural post office agents. Not all of the post office agents are based in the rural areas. Some of the post office agents who suggested that were in the capital cities, where we know there are licensed post office agents.

I think the minister would do well to at least hear out the Association of Post Office Business Agents, and to accept that there is another organisation which represents a particular view point of licensed post office agents. Whilst the association putting the view that is accepted by the government is certainly putting the points of many of the licensed post office agents—perhaps the majority—it should be noted that the other association does have a conflict with some of those views. I think it is very important in a democracy not to lock out the opinions of associations that have organised themselves in a voluntary capacity. I trust that the minister will look at the concerns of the Association of Post Office Business Agents.

We will not be opposing the bill but I urge the minister, and the parliamentary secretary, to take on board the concerns of our side of the House and let us see whether we cannot improve some of the services to those kids doing their education out in the bush. If honourable members want to know more about this issue, I recommend that they visit the back of my electorate, the back of Grey, the back of Kalgoorlie or parts of the Northern Territory and Aboriginal communities, to see for themselves that there would be benefits from more mail services. I do not think this legislation goes far enough and I am very disappointed that the government is not picking up the opposition's amendment. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Dr Theophanous) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel from each service are involved in the (a) advance party and (b) main body of Australia's Rwandan operations.
(2) What ADF equipment is being used.
(3) What usage of the ADF's aircraft resources is involved.
(4) What mode of travel is being used by the (a) advance party and (b) main body.
(5) Did the UN task the airlift of ADF personnel; if so, is the UN accepting financial liability.
(6) What is the anticipated (a) cost to Australia of the operations and (b) refund of the costs from the UN.
(7) Will the Department of Defence receive a supplementary appropriation to meet the additional costs of the operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The ADF deployed a total of 73 personnel in the advance party comprising 72 Army and one RAAF. The main body comprised 235 personnel consisting of six RAN, 213 Army (including five Army Reserve) and 16 RAAF.

(2) The contingent deployed with 43 vehicles (including six ambulances), four armoured personnel carriers, communications equipment (including satellite communications), power, refrigeration and water purification equipment. Equipment to support a 50 bed hospital with surgical, intensive care, preventive medicine, pathology and dental facilities has also been deployed.

(3) Two RAAF C130 transport aircraft were dispatched on 28 July 94 to transport urgently needed relief supplies to Rwanda. This mission was flown in support of AIDAB's humanitarian relief effort and not UNAMIR. As at 12 September 94 no ADF aircraft have deployed in support of Australia's contribution to UNAMIR II.
(4) The advance party deployed by United States Air Force (USAF) C5 aircraft. The main body deployed by a combination of USAF C5, C141 and USAF hired 747 freighter aircraft.
(5) The UN tasked and accepted financial liability for the airlift of ADF personnel and equipment.
(6) The indicative cost of the proposed twelve month commitment to UNAMIR II is AUD$25 million. At this stage UN recoveries of AUD$10.5 would be expected.
(7) Defence has been granted supplementation of up to AUD$25 million, with UN recoveries being returned to consolidated revenue.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of the Treasury: Electronic Information

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What services does the Minister's Department, or government enterprises for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility, provide, or will it provide, using public access points for the distribution of electronic information in regional, district or suburban centres around Australia.
(2) How will each service referred to in part (1) be accommodated and operated.
(3) What consideration has been given to using Australia's extensive network of municipal libraries to house the services and foster public access.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) In conjunction with the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS), an electronic version of the 1994-95 Budget papers was produced on floppy disc in May this year. This version (Budget Statements 1 and 2 and the Budget Overview and Economic Outlook) was sold through the AGPS bookshops and the Department is looking to produce more information electronically in the future.
In addition, the Treasury/Finance library will receive electronic copies of future publications for release through its normal networks.
(3) As yet, the Department has not considered distribution of electronic information through the municipal library network.

(1) and (3) The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) has established the Library Extension Program (LEP) which uses the public and tertiary library networks to distribute ABS publications for public access at no charge to those libraries. A range of electronic products containing statistics is also available from the ABS, but with the exception of certain products (eg CLIB91—a CDROM product containing the full published output of the 1991 Census), electronic products are not supplied free of charge.

The ABS is monitoring developments in electronic dissemination of information, including within the library sector. At this stage, few libraries offer public `hands on' access to remote electronic information sources, due in part to an inability to provide sufficient appropriate public access technology. As more equipment becomes available in libraries, the ABS will be seeking to deliver more of its products electronically via the public library network.

(2) The ABS will continue to make use of emerging technology to improve its products and the delivery of those products. For example, the ABS is aware of `touch screen' technology being deployed recently in some public areas of some jurisdictions for making government, and other information electronically available. The ABS is monitoring developments with this technology for possible future use for electronic delivery of ABS products to the public.

(1) The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has been working with the tax profession for the past 4 years to provide the Electronic Lodgement Service (ELS) network. During this time, the ATO has continued to expand the capabilities of the ELS system. Trials have also been conducted with a tax agent electronic bulletin board and an external electronic mail link. These trials have indicated that substantial benefits appear to be available with the provision of these services.

The ATO is beginning to look at new methods in providing direct electronic information to the community. The ATO is conducting a trial of electronic touch screen `kiosks', known as AUSTOUCH for use by the community.

(2) The AUSTOUCH kiosks are currently located in the country districts of western NSW and in the Parramatta/Penrith regions of Sydney. The AUSTOUCH kiosks have been placed in suburban shopping centres, local government centres, community clubs and municipal libraries.

These kiosks are stand alone units designed to provide taxation information to the community using multi media (audio, video, text and graphics). The information provided includes general income tax, Higher Education Contribution Scheme, superannuation and small business taxation matters.
The results of the trial will be evaluated and a report on the viability of a national implementation will be available towards the end of 1994.

(3) The ATO recognises that the continuing evolution of computing and communication technologies (such as AUSTOUCH) offer opportunities for new and better ways of providing a range of services to the community. One of the central themes of the ATO's Modernisation Program has been the provision of these services. As a consequence, the uses of municipal libraries have been included in the current trial.
(1) The Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC) has operated a `Public Access Database' since December 1992. It was introduced as a result of the Superannuation Guarantee (SG) arrangements.

The database contains contact details and the most recently available compliance status details for each superannuation fund that has lodged an annual return or registration form with the ISC. It presently contains details for in excess of 80,000 funds.
As SG contributions can only be paid into complying superannuation funds, the database can be used by employers to verify a fund's compliance status before making their contributions.
(2) Access to the database can be achieved by any of the following methods:
direct access for the cost of a local telephone call for those with appropriate computer hardware and software (most PCs and modems are compatible); and
by telephoning the ISC on its toll free number, 13 10 60, and requesting advice on the compliance status of a particular fund(s).
(3) Given the nature of this database product, there is no requirement to make use of additional library networks to make it more accessible.
